Once upon a time, there was a little girl named Lily. She loved to play outside with her toys. One day, she found a stick and started to measure things. She measured how tall the flowers were and how wide the trees were. 
But then, it started to rain and Lily got very wet. She was miserable because she didn't like being wet. She ran back to her house and her mom gave her a warm blanket to dry off. 
Lily was happy to be inside where it was warm and cozy. She realized that sometimes it's better to be inside when it's raining outside. She hugged her mom and said, "I love you."



Once upon a time, there was a little bunny named Benny. Benny loved to hop around in the grass and eat carrots. One day, Benny met a bossy squirrel named Sammy.
"Hey Benny, you should pass me one of those carrots," said Sammy.
Benny didn't like how bossy Sammy was, but he didn't want to be mean. So, he passed Sammy a carrot.
But as soon as Sammy took a bite of the carrot, he made a face and said, "This carrot is yucky! I don't like it."
Benny felt sad that he had given Sammy a bad carrot. But then, he had an idea. He hopped over to a different patch of carrots and found the juiciest, sweetest carrot he could find. He brought it back to Sammy and said, "Here, try this one instead."
Sammy took a bite and his eyes lit up. "Wow, this carrot is delicious! Thank you, Benny."
Benny felt happy that he was able to make Sammy happy, even though he was bossy at first. From then on, they were good friends and Benny always made sure to share his best carrots with Sammy.



Once upon a time, there was a little girl named Lily who loved to play with her toy cars. One day, she was playing with her red car when she realized it was out of fuel. She asked her mom if she could have more fuel for her car.
Mom said, "Sure, let's go get some fuel at the gas station." When they got there, they saw a man with a thin mustache who was having trouble with his car. Lily's mom asked if they could help him solve his problem.
The man was very grateful, and they all worked together to fix his car. After they were done, the man said, "Thank you so much for helping me solve my car problem. You guys are the best!" Lily was happy that they could help and she went back to playing with her toy cars, now with a full tank of fuel.



Once upon a time, there was a little girl named Lily. She loved to play with her toys and her friends. One day, Lily went to a race with her friends. They all wanted to win the race, but Lily just wanted to have fun.
During the race, Lily saw that her friend was really fast. She wanted to keep up with her, but she couldn't. She started to feel sad, but then she remembered that it's not all about winning. She felt happy just to be there with her friends.
After the race, Lily's friend won the first prize. She was very happy, but Lily wasn't sad. She was happy for her friend and kept a modest smile on her face. She learned that it's not always about winning, but about having fun and being happy for others.



Once upon a time, there was a little girl named Lily. She had a favorite doll that she loved very much. One day, Lily's little brother came and took the doll from her. Lily was very sad and cried a lot. She wanted her doll back.
Lily's mommy came and saw what happened. She asked Lily's brother to give the doll back to Lily. At first, he didn't want to, but then he saw how sad Lily was. So, he gave the doll back to Lily.
Lily was very happy and hugged her doll gently. She completed her tea party with her doll and her brother. They all had fun together. The end.



Once upon a time, there was a little girl named Lily who loved to dance. She would twirl and jump around in her room every day. One day, her mommy made her a cup of cocoa, which made her very happy. It was a normal day, just like any other.
But then, Lily's little brother spilled her cocoa all over her favorite dress. She was sad, but her mommy said she could wash it and it would be okay. However, when they went to the laundry room, they saw that the washing machine was broken. Lily's mommy said they would have to take it to the repairman.
The next day, Lily went to the repairman with her mommy. She was so excited to get her dress back, but when they got there, they found out that the repairman had lost her dress. Lily was so sad that she couldn't even dance anymore. She learned that sometimes, things don't always end up normal and happy like she wanted them to.



Once upon a time, there was a little girl named Lily. She loved to draw pictures with her white crayon. One day, Lily's mommy gave her a stamp to play with. Lily was so happy and started stamping everything she could find. She even stamped her daddy's shirt!
But then, Lily's mommy noticed that some of her important papers were missing. She looked everywhere but couldn't find them. Finally, she asked Lily if she knew where they were. Lily felt sad and told her mommy that she had put them in a sack and stamped them with the pretty stamp.
Lily's mommy was very upset but she didn't scold Lily. Instead, she explained that it's not okay to take things that don't belong to us and put them in a sack without asking. Lily felt sorry and promised to never do it again. From that day on, Lily learned that it's important to be honest and ask for permission before taking or using things that belong to someone else.



Once upon a time, there was a little girl named Lily. One day, she went to the park to play with her friends. While playing, she saw a raven sitting on a tree. The raven looked very big and Lily felt a little fearful.
Lily's friend, Timmy, saw that she was scared and asked her what was wrong. Lily pointed to the raven and said, "I'm scared of that big bird." Timmy smiled and said, "Don't be scared, Lily. Ravens are nice birds. They won't hurt you."
Lily felt better and decided to make a paper airplane. She asked Timmy to help her fold it. They folded the paper airplane together and had a lot of fun playing with it. Lily learned that sometimes things may seem scary, but it's important to not be afraid and try new things.



Once upon a time, there was a man who was very famous. He liked to sign his name on everything he owned. One day, he lost all his money and didn't know what to do. He asked his friends for help, but they didn't have any money either. 
The man felt sad and scared. He didn't want to be poor. Then, he remembered he had a special talent. He could sing! He went to the park and started singing. People liked his singing and gave him money. 
The man was happy again. He realized that being famous and having money wasn't everything. He was grateful for his talent and for the kindness of the people who gave him money. From that day on, he signed his name on his heart, as a reminder to be thankful and humble.



Once upon a time, there was a little bird. The bird loved to fly high in the sky. One day, the bird flew over a big field. The field was very clear, with no trees or bushes. The bird saw some bugs on the ground and swooped down to eat them. After the bird ate, it flew back up into the clear sky. The bird felt happy and free while it flew. The end.



Once upon a time, there was a little boy named Timmy who loved to play with his toys. One day, he brought his favorite toy car to school and showed it to his friend, Billy. Billy liked the car very much and asked if he could play with it. Timmy said yes and lent him the car.
After school, Timmy went to the classroom to get his toy car back. But when he arrived, he saw that the car was broken. He asked Billy what happened, and Billy said he accidentally dropped it. Timmy was very sad that his favorite toy was now broken.
The moral of the story is that we should be careful when we lend our things to others, and we should also be responsible for taking care of things that we borrow from others.



Once upon a time, there was a little girl named Lily. She had a fragile doll that she loved very much. One night, she had a dream that her doll came to life and they went on an adventure together.
The next day, Lily was playing with her doll when her little brother came in and accidentally kicked the doll. Lily was very upset and started to cry. Her brother said, "I'm sorry, I didn't mean to kick your doll."
Lily wiped away her tears and said, "It's okay, accidents happen. But please be careful next time." Her brother nodded and promised to be more careful. From then on, Lily made sure to keep her fragile doll safe and sound.



Once upon a time, there was a kind man. His name was Tom. Tom loved to cook yummy food. He made pancakes, eggs, and bacon for breakfast. He also made soup and sandwiches for lunch. For dinner, he cooked spaghetti and meatballs.
One day, Tom went to the store to buy a new motor for his car. When he got home, he put the motor in his car and fixed it. His car was now working again!
Tom was a very thoughtful man. He always helped his friends and family. He cooked meals for them and fixed things when they were broken. Everyone loved Tom because he was kind and helpful.



Once upon a time, there was a horse named Brownie. Brownie lived in a big stable with his horse friends. The stable was very dark at night, but Brownie was not scared. He liked to sleep and dream about running in the fields. 
One day, Brownie's friend Billy got lost in the woods. Brownie heard Billy shout for help. He knew he had to do something. Brownie ran out of the stable and into the woods. He searched and searched until he found Billy. 
Billy was so happy to see Brownie that he shouted with joy. Brownie was happy too. He led Billy back to the stable where all of their friends were waiting. They were happy to see Billy and they all shouted with joy. From that day on, Brownie felt very proud of himself for being a brave horse.



Once upon a time, there was a little girl named Lily. She loved to play with her blocks every day. She would build tall towers and knock them down with a big smile on her face. One day, her little brother came to play with her. He was very young and didn't know how to play with the blocks yet. He tried to bite them, but they were too hard. Lily showed him how to stack them and build a tower. 
Suddenly, their dog came in and started to play with the blocks too. He was very big and his bark was harsh. Lily and her brother were scared, but the dog just wanted to play. He tried to bite the blocks, but they were too small for his mouth. They all laughed and played together until it was time for dinner. From that day on, Lily's brother learned how to play with the blocks and the dog became their new playmate.



Once upon a time, there was a little girl named Lily. She loved to play outside with her friends in the park. One day, Lily's mom told her that they needed to leave the park because a big storm was coming. 
Lily didn't know what a storm was, so she asked her mom. Her mom explained that a storm was like a really strong wind and rain that could be very dangerous. Lily was scared, but her mom told her not to worry because they were going to be safe at home. 
As they walked home, Lily saw the sky getting darker and the wind getting stronger. She knew that her mom was right about the storm. When they got home, they watched the news and saw that there was a hurricane coming. 
Lily thought the hurricane sounded amazing because she had never seen anything like it before. But her mom told her that hurricanes were very dangerous and they needed to stay inside until it was over. Lily was sad that she couldn't play outside with her friends, but she knew that staying safe was more important.



Once upon a time, there was a little girl named Lily. She loved to ride in the car with her mommy and daddy. Every time they got in the car, her mommy would tell her to buckle up her seatbelt to be safe. 
One day, Lily's family was driving to the park when they got into a big accident. The car spun around and Lily felt very scared. But because she had buckled up her seatbelt, she was safe. 
After the accident, Lily's mommy and daddy explained to her how important it is to always buckle up in the car. Lily felt proud of herself for being safe and promised to always buckle up from now on.



Once upon a time, there was a little boy named Timmy who had a pet dog named Max. Max was an ordinary dog, but Timmy loved him very much.
One day, Timmy and Max went to a restaurant. The waiter came to their table and asked, "What can I serve you today?" Timmy looked at Max and said, "Can Max have some water, please?" The waiter smiled and brought Max a bowl of water.
After they finished their meal, Timmy asked Max, "Did you like the food?" Max barked happily, which Timmy took as a sign that he did. They went home and cuddled together, happy to have spent the day together.



Once upon a time, there was a little girl named Lily. She loved to play outside with her friends. One day, Lily's mom made her a sandwich with sour pickles. Lily didn't like the taste and made a sour face. 
Later that day, Lily's mom told her it was time for her nap. Lily didn't want to take a nap, but she knew it was important to rest. She thanked her mom for taking care of her and went to sleep. 
When Lily woke up from her nap, she felt much better. She thanked her mom again and went outside to play with her friends. They played games and had fun until the sun went down. Lily went home, took a bath, and went to bed. She felt grateful for a fun day and for her mom taking care of her.



Once upon a time, there was a little girl named Lily. She loved going to parades with her family. One day, she saw a crazy clown in the parade. He had a big red nose and a funny hat. Lily thought he was silly and laughed.
Later that day, Lily went to the park to play. She met the same clown there. He offered her a balloon and she happily accepted it. But then, the clown turned mean and tried to take Lily away. She screamed and her parents came running to save her.
From that day on, Lily never wanted to go to a parade again. She learned that sometimes, people who seem silly can be dangerous.



Once upon a time, there was a little girl named Lily. She loved to go on walks with her mommy and daddy. One day, while they were walking, Lily found a shiny penny on the ground. She picked it up and held it tight in her hand. It felt heavy, but she was happy to have found it. 
As they continued their walk, Lily saw a big dog that looked scary. She was scared and held onto her mommy's hand tightly. Her mommy told her not to worry, that the dog was friendly. 
After their walk, Lily went home and showed her penny to her big brother. He said it was very shiny and heavy for a little penny. Lily felt proud of her find and held onto it tightly.



Once upon a time, a lady was very excited to go on a walk in the park. She put on her pretty dress and went outside. She saw a bird and wanted to show it to her friends. But as she walked, she fell and hurt her head. She cried out for help, but no one heard her. Sadly, she never got to show her friends the bird and had to go home with a big bump on her head.



Once upon a time, there was a happy bird named Bluey. Bluey liked to fly high up in the sky and feel the warm sun on his feathers. He would flap his wings and soar through the clouds, feeling very free.
One day, Bluey saw a group of lively birds playing in a nearby tree. They were singing and chirping and having a lot of fun. Bluey wanted to join in, so he flew down to the tree and said hello.
The lively birds welcomed Bluey and they all played together. They flew around the tree and sang songs in the sun. Bluey felt very happy to have new friends and he knew that he would soar with them again soon.



Once upon a time, there was a little girl named Lily. She loved to play outside and catch butterflies. One day, she was walking down the road when she saw a terrible storm coming. She knew she had to hurry home before it started raining.
As she ran, she saw her friend Timmy playing in his yard. "Timmy, we have to go home before the terrible storm comes!" Lily shouted. "Okay, let's go!" Timmy replied.
They ran down the road together, trying to catch the last few butterflies before the storm hit. Suddenly, a big gust of wind blew and they both fell down. "Ouch, that hurt!" Timmy said. "Are you okay?" Lily asked. "Yes, I'm fine," Timmy replied.
They finally made it home, safe and sound. "That was scary," Lily said. "Yes, but we caught some butterflies and made it home before the storm," Timmy said with a smile.



Once upon a time, there was a little girl named Lily. She had a cat named Mittens. Mittens was very soft and had pretty eyes.
One day, Lily's mommy decided to bake some cookies. It smelled so yummy! Mittens was very interested in the smell and came to the kitchen to see what was happening. 
Lily's mommy let Mittens lick the spoon after she finished baking the cookies. Mittens was so happy and licked the spoon clean. The cookies were delicious and everyone was happy, especially Mittens!



Once upon a time, there was a little girl named Lily. She loved to play at the park with her friends. One day, they went to the park and saw a big slide. Lily was so excited to slide down it! She climbed up the ladder and slid down the slide with a big smile on her face.
After playing on the slide, Lily's friend showed her a map of the park. It showed all the different places they could go and play. Lily thought the map was really cool and wanted to see all the places on it.
As they walked around the park, Lily noticed how tidy everything was. The grass was cut and the flowers were in neat rows. It made her happy to see everything so tidy and clean. She knew it was because the park workers did a great job taking care of the park.



Once upon a time, there was a girl named Lily. She loved to read books, especially a big book called a novel. One day, Lily found a new novel at the library. It had a pretty purple cover. She took it home and read it all night long.
The next day, Lily wanted to tell her friends about the novel. She asked her mom how to do it. Her mom said, "You can record your voice and share it with them." Lily thought it was a good idea. She found a purple microphone and recorded herself talking about the novel. 
Lily's friends loved hearing her talk about the novel. They all wanted to read it too. So, they went to the library together and found more purple books to read. They all had fun reading and talking about the stories they found.




Sara and Tom were very happy. They were going on a holiday with their mom and dad. They packed their bags and put them in the car. They wanted to see the sea and the sand and the sun.
"Are we there yet?" Sara asked.
"Soon, sweetie, soon," mom said.
Tom looked out the window. He saw a big yellow sign. It said "Road Closed".
"What does that mean?" Tom asked.
"It means we can't go this way," dad said. "There is a problem with the road. We have to turn back and find another way."
Sara and Tom felt sad. They wanted to go to the beach, not to turn back.
"Can we still go on holiday?" Sara asked.
"I don't know, honey, I don't know," dad said.
They drove for a long time, but they could not find another way. All the roads were closed or busy or too far. The sun was going down and it was getting dark.
"We have to stop for the night," dad said. "We can't drive anymore. Maybe we can find a hotel or a motel or something."
They looked for a place to stay, but they could not find one. All the places were full or closed or too expensive. They drove and drove, but they could not find a place to sleep.
They became very tired and hungry and cranky. They started to cry and whine and fight.
"Stop it, stop it, stop it!" mom said. "This is not helping. We have to stick together and be brave."
But Sara and Tom did not stop. They kept crying and whining and fighting. They made mom and dad very angry and sad.
They did not have a good holiday. They did not see the sea or the sand or the sun. They did not have fun or play or laugh. They had a bad holiday. They wished they had stayed at home.




Sara was a squirrel who liked to collect acorns. She was very intelligent and knew how to find the best acorns in the forest. She had a big pile of acorns in her nest, and she was proud of it.
One day, she met a new friend, Tom, who was also a squirrel. Tom was very friendly and wanted to play with Sara. He asked her if she wanted to share some of her acorns with him.
Sara was not sure. She liked Tom, but she also liked her acorns. She worked hard to get them, and she did not want to lose them. She said to Tom, "I don't know. I have many acorns, but I need them for the winter. What if I run out of acorns?"
Tom smiled and said, "Don't worry, Sara. There are plenty of acorns in the forest. We can always find more. Sharing is fun, and it makes us happy. Come on, let's have some acorns together."
Sara thought about it. She realized that Tom was right. Sharing was fun, and it made her happy. She decided to give Tom some of her acorns, and they ate them together. They had a good time, and they became good friends. Sara learned that she did not need to worry so much about her acorns, and that she could be generous and kind. She was happy, and so was Tom.




Tom and Lily are hungry. They want to eat some food. But their mom is not at home. She went to the shop. She told them to be obedient and wait for her.
Tom and Lily look in the kitchen. They see a big jar of cookies. They love cookies. They want to eat them. But the jar is on a high shelf. They cannot reach it.
Tom has an idea. He says to Lily, "Let's solve this problem. We can use a chair and a stick. I will stand on the chair and poke the jar with the stick. Then it will fall down and we can eat the cookies."
Lily thinks this is a good idea. She says, "OK, let's do it. But we have to be quick. Mom will be back soon."
Tom and Lily find a chair and a stick. They move the chair to the shelf. Tom climbs on the chair. He holds the stick. He tries to poke the jar. But the stick is too short. He cannot reach the jar.
Tom says, "Oh no, this is not working. We need a longer stick."
Lily says, "Wait, I have an idea. I will go and get the broom. It has a long handle. It will work."
Lily runs to the closet and gets the broom. She brings it to Tom. Tom takes the broom. He pokes the jar with the broom. The jar wobbles. It falls down. It breaks on the floor. Cookies spill everywhere.
Tom and Lily cheer. They say, "Yay, we solved the problem. We can eat the cookies."
They jump off the chair. They run to the cookies. They pick them up. They eat them. They are happy.
But then they hear the door. Mom is back. She sees the mess. She sees the broken jar. She sees the cookies. She is angry.
She says, "Tom and Lily, what have you done? You were not obedient. You made a big mess. You ate all the cookies. You are in trouble."
Tom and Lily are scared. They say, "Sorry, mom. We were hungry. We wanted to eat some food. We tried to solve the problem. But we made a mistake."
Mom says, "You should have waited for me. I bought some food for you. I bought some fruit and some milk. They are healthy and yummy. You should eat them instead of cookies. Cookies are not good for you. They will make you sick."
Tom and Lily feel sorry. They say, "We are sorry, mom. We will not do it again. We will eat the fruit and the milk. We will be obedient."
Mom says, "I hope you learned your lesson. Now, help me clean up this mess. Then we can have some fruit and some milk. And maybe one cookie each. But only one."
Tom and Lily say, "OK, mom. We will help you. We love you."
Mom says, "I love you too. But next time, listen to me. And do not try to solve problems by yourself. Ask me for help. I will always help you."




Lily and Ben like to collect rocks. They go to the park and look for rocks that are shiny, smooth, or have funny shapes. They put the rocks in their pockets or in a bag. They are happy when they find a new rock.
One day, they meet a boy named Sam at the park. Sam has a big box of toys. He has cars, trucks, dolls, and balls. He sees Lily and Ben with their rocks and laughs.
"Rocks are boring," he says. "They have no value. You can't play with them. You should get some real toys like mine. They are fun and colorful."
Lily and Ben feel sad. They like their rocks. They think their rocks have value. They think their rocks are fun and beautiful.
They say to Sam, "We don't want your toys. We like our rocks. They are not boring. They have value to us. We can play with them. We can make patterns, or pretend they are animals, or use them as treasure. They are our friends."
Sam does not understand. He thinks Lily and Ben are silly. He shrugs and goes back to his toys.
Lily and Ben smile at each other. They hold their rocks tight. They are happy with their collection. They think their rocks are the best.




Anna likes to look at the magazine with many pictures of animals. She likes to point at the animals and say their names. She also likes to cut out some pictures and stick them on her wall.
One day, she finds a big tear in the magazine. She is sad and cries. She does not want to lose her favorite pictures. She runs to her mom and shows her the tear.
"Mom, can you fix it?" she asks.
Mom looks at the magazine and smiles. She hugs Anna and says, "Don't worry, sweetie. I can fix it. We just need some tape and scissors. Come, let's go to the kitchen."
Mom and Anna go to the kitchen and find the tape and scissors. Mom carefully tapes the tear and makes the magazine look like new. Anna is happy and claps her hands. She thanks mom and gives her a kiss.
"Can I look at the magazine now?" she asks.
"Of course, you can. But be careful not to tear it again. And don't cut out too many pictures. You need to leave some for the next time." Mom says.
Anna nods and takes the magazine to her room. She sits on her bed and looks at the pictures. She sees a lion, a monkey, a giraffe, and a bird. She likes the bird the most. It has bright colors and a long tail. She decides to cut out the bird and stick it on her wall.
She takes the scissors and starts to cut. But she cuts too fast and too loud. She makes a big noise. She does not hear mom calling her name.
"Anna, what are you doing? Why are you so loud?" Mom says as she opens the door.
Anna looks up and sees mom. She feels scared. She knows she did something wrong. She drops the scissors and the magazine. She sees the bird picture on the floor. She sees another tear in the magazine. She starts to cry.
"Mom, I'm sorry. I wanted to cut the bird. But I cut too loud. And I tore the magazine again. Can you fix it?" she says.
Mom sighs and shakes her head. She picks up the scissors and the magazine. She sees the bird picture and smiles. She picks it up and gives it to Anna.
"It's okay, Anna. I know you like the bird. But you need to be more careful with the scissors and the magazine. They are not toys. They can hurt you and the magazine. Next time, ask me before you cut anything. And don't be so loud. You might disturb the neighbors." Mom says.
Anna nods and wipes her tears. She hugs mom and says, "I'm sorry, mom. I love you. Thank you for fixing the magazine. Can I keep the bird?"
Mom hugs Anna back and says, "I love you too, Anna. Yes, you can keep the bird. But only one. And put it somewhere safe. And don't forget to clean up your mess."
Anna smiles and says, "Okay, mom. I will. Thank you, mom. You are the best."
Mom smiles and says, "You're welcome, Anna. You are the best too."




Ben and Mia were playing in the tent in the backyard. It was dark outside and they had a flashlight to see. They liked to tell stories and make funny faces with the light.
Suddenly, they heard a loud noise. It was thunder. They saw a bright light in the sky. It was lightning. They were scared and hugged each other.
"Mommy! Daddy!" they cried.
Mommy and Daddy came running to the tent. They saw Ben and Mia and smiled.
"Don't be afraid, sweeties. It's just a storm. It will go away soon," Mommy said.
She gave them a big hug and a kiss.
"Here, take this flashlight. You can use it to make shadows on the wall. It will be fun," Daddy said.
He gave them a small flashlight and showed them how to make a rabbit and a bird.
"Wow, thank you, Daddy. You are so kind," Ben said.
"Yes, thank you, Daddy. You are the best," Mia said.
They took the flashlight and started to play. They forgot about the thunder and the lightning. They felt safe and happy in the tent with Mommy and Daddy.




Emma and Max were twins who loved to look at the moon. Every night, they would go to their window and say hello to the big, bright ball in the sky. They liked to imagine that the moon was their friend who watched over them while they slept.
One night, Emma had a bad dream. She dreamed that a scary monster came and took the moon away. She woke up crying and ran to Max's bed. "Max, Max, wake up!" she sobbed. "The moon is gone! The monster took it!"
Max rubbed his eyes and hugged Emma. "Don't worry, Emma. It's just a dream. The moon is still there. Look!" He pointed to the window, where the moon was shining as usual.
Emma looked and felt better. She smiled and hugged Max back. "You're right, Max. The moon is still there. Thank you for making me feel better. You're the best brother ever."
They went back to their beds and snuggled under their blankets. They said good night to the moon and to each other. The moon smiled and winked at them. It was happy to have such amazing friends.




Tom and Amy went to the port with their dad. They liked to observe the big boats and the people who worked on them. They saw a boat with a big crane that lifted boxes and put them on the dock. They saw another boat with a lot of flags that waved in the wind. They saw a boat with a lot of fish that smelled bad.
"Look, dad, look!" Tom said. "That boat has a lot of fish!"
"Yes, it does, Tom," dad said. "That boat is a fishing boat. The people on it catch fish and sell them to the market."
"Can we buy some fish, dad?" Amy asked.
"Maybe later, Amy," dad said. "First, let's go and see the cheerful boat."
"The cheerful boat?" Tom and Amy asked.
"Yes, the cheerful boat," dad said. "It's a boat that takes people for a ride and makes them happy. It has music and games and snacks. Do you want to go on the cheerful boat?"
"Yes, yes, yes!" Tom and Amy said.
Dad bought tickets for the cheerful boat and they got on board. They saw a lot of other people who were smiling and laughing. They heard a lot of songs and noises. They played with balls and balloons and puzzles. They ate popcorn and candy and ice cream. They had a lot of fun on the cheerful boat.
Tom and Amy observed the port from the cheerful boat. They saw the big boats and the people who worked on them. They saw the sun and the water and the birds. They felt the wind and the waves and the joy. They hugged their dad and thanked him for the wonderful day. They were very happy.




Sara and Tom were friends who liked to play with blocks and cars. One day, Sara found a bottle of glue in the art room. She had an idea to make a funny joke on Tom. She put some glue on one of his cars and waited for him to come back.
When Tom came back, he saw his car and picked it up. He tried to roll it on the floor, but it was stuck. He pulled hard, but it did not move. He felt something sticky on his hand. He looked at the car and saw the glue. He was very angry and sad. He shouted at Sara, "Why did you do this? This is not funny! This is mean! You ruined my car!"
Sara laughed and said, "It is funny! It is a joke! You are silly! I can do what I want!" She did not care that Tom was upset. She thought she was clever and funny.
Tom ran to the teacher and told her what Sara did. The teacher was not happy. She scolded Sara and made her apologize to Tom. She also made her clean the car and the glue. She said, "Sara, you should not tease your friends. Teasing is not nice. It can hurt their feelings and make them angry. You should be kind and respectful to your friends. How would you feel if someone did that to you?"
Sara felt ashamed and sorry. She realized that she was wrong and that she hurt Tom. She said sorry to Tom and gave him back his car. She said, "Tom, I am sorry. I was not nice. I will not tease you again. Can we still be friends?"
Tom was still a little angry, but he also felt sorry for Sara. He saw that she was anxious and sad. He said, "Sara, I forgive you. I am glad you said sorry. We can still be friends, but please do not do that again. Friends should not hurt each other. Friends should help each other and have fun together."
Sara and Tom hugged and smiled. They learned a lesson that day. They learned that teasing is not funny, but cruel. They learned that friendship is more important than jokes. They learned to be kind and respectful to each other. They played with their blocks and cars again, and had a good time.




Tom and Lily are friends. They like to play in the park. They see a big dog. The dog is brown and has a long tail. Tom and Lily want to pet the dog.
"Can we pet the dog?" Tom asks a man. The man is holding a leash. The leash is for the dog.
"Yes, you can. He is gentle and friendly. His name is Rex." The man says. He smiles at Tom and Lily.
Tom and Lily go near the dog. They touch his fur. The fur is soft and warm. The dog licks their hands. Tom and Lily giggle.
"Rex, you are so nice. Do you want to play with us?" Lily asks the dog.
The dog barks. He wags his tail. He looks happy.
"OK, let's play. What do you want to do?" Tom asks the dog.
The dog runs to a ball. The ball is red and bouncy. The dog picks up the ball in his mouth. He brings it to Tom and Lily.
"Let's play catch. You throw the ball and I catch it." The dog seems to say.
Tom and Lily nod. They take turns throwing the ball. The dog chases the ball. He catches it and brings it back. They have fun.
But then, something bad happens. A loud noise scares the dog. The noise is from a car. The car is fast and noisy. The dog drops the ball. He runs away from the noise. He runs across the street.
"Rex, come back!" The man shouts. He drops the leash. He runs after the dog.
Tom and Lily watch. They are scared. They see the car. The car does not see the dog. The car hits the dog.
The dog yelps. He falls to the ground. He does not move. He is hurt.
The man reaches the dog. He cries. He hugs the dog. He calls for help.
Tom and Lily cry too. They are sad. They liked the dog. They wanted to play more.
The end.




Ben and Mia were playing in the bathroom. They liked to pretend they were grown-ups and use the things they found there. Ben saw a shiny thing on the sink. He picked it up and looked at it.
"What is this?" he asked Mia.
"It is a razor. Daddy uses it to make his face smooth," Mia said.
"Can I use it too?" Ben asked.
"No, Ben, it is not for playing. It is sharp and can hurt you. Put it back," Mia said.
But Ben did not listen. He wanted to imagine he was shaving like Daddy. He rubbed the razor on his cheek. He felt a sting and saw blood. He dropped the razor and started to cry.
"Mia, Mia, help me! It hurts!" he screamed.
Mia ran to him and saw his cut. She was scared and sorry. She hugged him and said, "I'm sorry, Ben, I'm sorry. Let me get Mommy. She will make it better."
She ran out of the bathroom and called for Mommy. Mommy came and saw what happened. She was angry and worried. She took Ben to the kitchen and cleaned his wound. She put a band-aid on it and kissed him.
"Ben, you were very naughty. You should never touch Daddy's razor. It is dangerous and can hurt you very badly. Do you understand?" she said.
"Yes, Mommy, I understand. I'm sorry, Mommy. I won't do it again," Ben said.
Mommy hugged him and said, "I love you, Ben, but you have to be careful and listen to Mia. She is your big sister and she knows better. Now go and say sorry to her too."
Ben nodded and went to find Mia. She was in their room, playing with her dolls. He walked up to her and said, "I'm sorry, Mia. You were right. The razor is not for playing. It is smelly and ouchy. I love you, Mia."
Mia smiled and said, "I love you too, Ben. I'm glad you are okay. Next time, let's play with something else. How about we imagine we are pirates and sail the seas?"
Ben liked that idea. He said, "Okay, Mia, let's do that. You can be the captain and I can be the matey. Arrr!"
They hugged and went to get their hats and swords. They forgot about the razor and the blood. They had fun imagining they were pirates and sailing the seas.




Ben and Mia like to play in the park. They run and jump and slide and swing. They have fun with their friends and their toys. But sometimes they get hot and thirsty. Then they look for a place to rest and drink.
One day, they find a big rock under a tree. The rock is cool and smooth. They sit on the rock and pause. They drink some water from their bottles. They feel better. They talk and laugh and watch the birds and bugs.
But then they hear a loud noise. It is a big truck. The truck comes to the park. It has a big shovel and a big bucket. It digs up the dirt and the grass. It makes a big hole. Ben and Mia are scared. They wonder what the truck is doing.
They see a man get out of the truck. He has a hat and a vest and a tool. He walks to the rock. He puts the tool on the rock. He pushes a button. The tool makes a loud noise. It breaks the rock. Ben and Mia are sad. They like the rock. They do not want the rock to break.
They run to the man. They shout and wave. They ask him to stop. They tell him the rock is their friend. They tell him the rock is cool and smooth. They tell him they sit on the rock and pause. They tell him they drink water on the rock. They tell him they love the rock.
The man hears them. He looks at them. He smiles. He stops the tool. He puts it down. He walks to them. He kneels. He talks to them. He tells them he is sorry. He tells them he did not know. He tells them he needs the rock. He tells them the rock is hot. He tells them the rock has fire inside. He tells them he uses the fire to make things. He tells them he makes things for people. He tells them he makes things for them.
Ben and Mia listen. They are curious. They ask him questions. He answers them. He shows them the truck. He shows them the shovel and the bucket. He shows them the hole. He shows them the rock. He shows them the fire. He shows them the things. He tells them stories. He makes them laugh.
Ben and Mia are happy. They learn new things. They make a new friend. They understand why he needs the rock. They say goodbye to the rock. They thank the rock for being cool and smooth. They thank the rock for letting them sit and pause. They thank the rock for giving them fire. They hug the rock. They hug the man. They run back to the park. They play some more. They have fun. They are hot and thirsty. They look for a new place to rest and drink. They find a new rock. They hope the truck does not come.




Sam liked to help his mom with the dishes. He would put the dirty plates and cups in the dishwasher and press the buttons. Mom said he was a good helper. But sometimes, Sam wanted to play with the dishwasher too. He liked to open and close the door, and pull out the racks, and spin the spray arms.
One day, when mom was busy in the living room, Sam decided to play with the dishwasher again. He opened the door and saw a shiny spoon. He grabbed it and ran to his room. He pretended the spoon was a rocket and made zooming noises. He did not hear mom calling him for lunch.
Mom came to Sam's room and saw the spoon. She was angry. She said, "Sam, where did you get this spoon? This is not a toy. This is for the dishwasher. You have to put it back. Now!" Sam felt bad. He said, "Sorry, mom. I was playing. I like the dishwasher." Mom said, "I know you like the dishwasher, but you can't take things from it. It can break. And then we can't wash the dishes. Do you understand?" Sam nodded. He said, "Yes, mom. I understand. I don't want to break the dishwasher. I want to help." Mom said, "That's good. Now, let's go and put the spoon back. And then we can have lunch."
They went to the kitchen and opened the dishwasher. But something was wrong. There was water everywhere. And the dishwasher was making a loud noise. Mom gasped. She said, "Oh no! What happened?" She looked inside and saw that one of the spray arms was missing. She said, "Sam, did you take the spray arm too?" Sam shook his head. He said, "No, mom. I only took the spoon. I don't know where the spray arm is." Mom said, "Well, it must have fallen off. And now the water is spraying everywhere. And the dishwasher is broken. You destroyed the dishwasher, Sam. You destroyed it!"
Sam started to cry. He said, "I'm sorry, mom. I'm sorry. I didn't mean to destroy the dishwasher. I didn't know it would break. I just wanted to play. Please don't be mad at me." Mom sighed. She said, "I'm not mad at you, Sam. I'm just disappointed. And frustrated. And wet. You have to be more careful, Sam. You have to listen to me. And you have to respect the things we have. They are not toys. They are tools. And they are not always available. Do you understand?" Sam nodded. He said, "Yes, mom. I understand. I'm sorry. I love you." Mom hugged him. She said, "I love you too, Sam. But we have a big problem now. We have to fix the dishwasher. Or get a new one. And we have to clean up this mess. And we have to wash the dishes by hand. And we have to eat cold lunch. Do you want to help me?" Sam said, "Yes, mom. I want to help. I want to be a good helper. And I don't want to play with the dishwasher anymore." Mom said, "That's good, Sam. That's very good. Now, let's get to work."




Lily was a gifted girl. She could jump very high and do many tricks. She liked to jump on her bed, on the sofa, and on the grass. She also liked to jump in the kitchen, but her mom did not like that.
One day, Lily was jumping in the kitchen when her mom was making a cake. She jumped on the table, on the chairs, and on the counter. She wanted to see what her mom was doing. She said, "Mom, what are you making?"
Her mom said, "I'm making a cake for your birthday, Lily. But you have to stop jumping in the kitchen. You can make a mess or hurt yourself. Why don't you go and play with your toys in your room?"
Lily said, "But I like to jump, mom. Jumping is fun. And I want to see the cake. Can I help you?"
Her mom said, "No, Lily. The cake is a surprise. And jumping is not fun in the kitchen. It's dangerous. You can burn yourself or break something. Please go and play with your toys in your room. I'll call you when the cake is ready."
Lily was sad. She did not want to leave the kitchen. She wanted to jump and see the cake. But she knew her mom was right. Jumping in the kitchen was not a good idea. She said, "Okay, mom. I'm sorry. I'll go and play with my toys in my room. But can I jump on my bed?"
Her mom said, "Yes, Lily. You can jump on your bed. But be careful. And don't jump too high. I love you, Lily. Happy birthday."
Lily said, "I love you too, mom. Thank you for the cake. I can't wait to see it." She gave her mom a hug and a kiss. Then she ran to her room and jumped on her bed. She was a gifted girl. She could jump very high and do many tricks.




Tom and Mia were playing in the woods. They liked to pretend they were brave hunters. They had sticks for spears and leaves for hats. They ran and jumped and laughed.
But then they heard a loud howl. It came from behind a big rock. Tom and Mia stopped and looked at each other. They felt scared.
"What is that?" Mia whispered.
"Maybe it is a wolf," Tom said. "Wolves are big and bad. They have sharp teeth and claws. They like to eat hunters."
Mia nodded. She wanted to go back home. She tugged on Tom's hand. "Let's go, Tom. The wolf might find us."
But Tom was stubborn. He wanted to see the wolf. He wanted to be brave. He shook off Mia's hand. "No, Mia. I want to see the wolf. Maybe I can scare it away with my spear. You stay here. I will go and look."
Mia did not understand. She did not want to stay alone. She did not want Tom to go. She tried to stop him. "No, Tom. Don't go. The wolf might hurt you. Please, Tom. Come with me."
But Tom did not listen. He ran to the big rock. He peeked behind it. He saw a big, black wolf. The wolf saw him too. It growled and bared its teeth. It jumped at Tom.
Tom screamed. He dropped his stick. He turned and ran. He ran back to Mia. He grabbed her hand. He said, "Mia, you were right. The wolf is big and bad. Let's go home. I am sorry I was stubborn."
Mia hugged him. She said, "It's okay, Tom. I am glad you are safe. Let's go home. Maybe we can play something else tomorrow."
They ran out of the woods. They did not look back. They did not hear the wolf howl again.




Sara and Ben were playing with their toys in the living room. They had a big box that they used as a house, a car, or a boat. They liked to pretend that they were on adventures.
"Let's go to the beach!" Ben said, putting on his hat and sunglasses. He grabbed a towel and a bucket. "We can make sand castles and find shells."
"OK!" Sara agreed, following him. She took her doll and a shovel. They dragged the box to the backyard, where there was a sandbox.
They put the box in the sand and climbed inside. They pretended that they were sailing on the ocean. They used the shovel and the bucket to make sand castles and dig holes. They found some rocks and sticks and pretended that they were shells and fish.
They had a lot of fun, but they also got very dirty. Sand was everywhere: on their clothes, in their hair, and on their toys. The sun was very hot and harsh. It made them thirsty and sweaty.
"Let's go inside and wash," Sara said, feeling sticky and itchy. "We can have some juice and cookies."
"OK," Ben said, feeling tired and thirsty. He grabbed the towel and the bucket. He helped Sara carry the box and the doll. They left the sandbox and went to the door.
But when they got there, they saw Mom waiting for them. She looked angry. She saw the sand and the dirt on them and on the floor.
"What have you done?" she asked, in a loud and harsh voice. "You made a big mess! You can't bring the box and the toys inside. They are too dirty. You have to wash them outside first. And then you have to wash yourselves. Go to the hose and spray everything. Now!"
Sara and Ben felt scared and sad. They did not mean to make Mom angry. They just wanted to have fun. They did not like the hose. It was cold and wet. They did not want to wash their toys. They liked them the way they were.
They started to cry. They dropped the box and the toys. They hugged each other.
"Please, Mom, don't be harsh," Sara said, in a small and soft voice. "We are sorry. We love you."
Mom saw their tears and heard their words. She felt sorry too. She realized that she was too harsh. She knelt down and hugged them.
"I'm sorry too," she said, in a gentle and kind voice. "I love you too. I know you were just playing. But you have to be careful. Sand can hurt your skin and your eyes. And dirt can make you sick. You have to wash it off. It's good for you. I'll help you. Come on, let's go to the hose. It will be fun. And then we can have some juice and cookies. OK?"
Sara and Ben nodded. They felt better. They smiled. They took the box and the toys. They followed Mom to the hose. They washed everything. They laughed and splashed. They had fun.
They learned that washing was not so bad. And that Mom was not so harsh. She was just trying to keep them safe and clean. They loved her. And she loved them.




Anna and Ben are twins. They like to play with their toys and eat snacks. One day, their mom makes them a new snack. It is called salsa. She puts it in a bowl with some chips.
"Try this, Anna and Ben. It is spicy. It will make your mouth hot," mom says.
Anna and Ben look at the bowl. They are curious. They each take a chip and dip it in the salsa. They put it in their mouths.
"Wow!" Anna says. "This is spicy! I like it!"
"Ow!" Ben says. "This is spicy! I don't like it!"
He spits out the chip and drinks some water. He makes a face.
"Mom, I don't want this snack. I want cookies," he says.
He demands cookies. He holds out his hand.
"Sorry, Ben. No cookies today. You have to eat something healthy first," mom says.
She does not give him cookies. She gives him a carrot.
Ben does not want a carrot. He wants cookies. He is angry. He throws the carrot on the floor.
"Ben, that is not nice. You have to pick up the carrot and say sorry," mom says.
She is not happy. She points at the carrot.
Ben does not want to pick up the carrot. He does not want to say sorry. He crosses his arms and pouts.
Anna sees Ben. She feels sorry for him. She likes her brother. She has an idea.
"Ben, do you want to trade?" she asks.
She holds out her chip with salsa.
Ben looks at Anna. He looks at the chip. He thinks.
"OK," he says.
He takes the chip from Anna. He gives her the carrot.
Anna smiles. She eats the carrot. She likes carrots.
Ben smiles. He eats the chip. He likes chips.
Mom sees Anna and Ben. She smiles. She is proud of them.
"Good job, Anna and Ben. You are sharing and trying new things," she says.
She gives them each a hug and a kiss.
Anna and Ben are happy. They hug and kiss mom back.
They finish their snack. They go back to play with their toys. They are good twins.




Tom and Lily were friends who liked to play outside. They both had wagons that they used to carry their toys and books. Tom had a new wagon that was shiny and red. Lily had an old wagon that was brown and rusty.
One day, Tom saw Lily's wagon and said, "Your wagon is ugly and bad. My wagon is pretty and good. You should throw your wagon away and get a new one like mine."
Lily felt sad and angry. She said, "My wagon is not ugly and bad. My wagon is old and loved. My grandpa gave me this wagon when I was a baby. He said it was his wagon when he was a boy. He said this wagon has a lot of stories and memories. I value my wagon very much. You are mean and rude. You don't value anything but yourself."
Tom felt ashamed and sorry. He said, "I'm sorry, Lily. I was mean and rude. I didn't know your wagon was so special to you. I don't value anything but myself. You are right. I should value things that have stories and memories, not things that are shiny and new. Can you forgive me and be my friend again?"
Lily smiled and nodded. She said, "I forgive you, Tom. You are my friend again. Do you want to play with me and my wagon? We can share our stories and memories."
Tom smiled and nodded. He said, "Yes, I want to play with you and your wagon. We can share our stories and memories. Thank you, Lily. You taught me a lesson. I learned to value things that are old and loved, not things that are shiny and new."
The end.




Tom and Lily liked to play near the pond. They saw many frogs, ducks and fish there. But they also knew there was an alligator in the pond. The alligator was enormous and scary. It had big teeth and a long tail. Tom and Lily always stayed away from the alligator.
One day, Tom and Lily found a balloon. It was red and shiny. They wanted to play with it. They took turns holding it and throwing it in the air. They had a lot of fun. But then, the balloon flew away from them. It went over the pond and landed near the alligator.
Tom and Lily were afraid. They wanted their balloon back. But they did not want to go near the alligator. They thought of a plan. They found a long stick. They used the stick to poke the balloon. They hoped the balloon would pop and release the air. Then, the balloon would be small and light. They could pull it back with the stick.
But the plan did not work. The balloon did not pop. It only bounced. The alligator saw the balloon. It thought it was a toy. It opened its mouth and bit the balloon. The balloon popped and released a loud noise. The alligator was surprised and angry. It roared and splashed the water.
Tom and Lily were scared. They dropped the stick and ran away. They did not want to play near the pond anymore. They learned a lesson. They should not bother the alligator. The alligator did not like balloons.




Anna and Ben were playing hide and seek in the big house. Anna was the seeker and Ben was the hider. Ben ran to the living room and saw a long curtain that touched the floor. He thought it was a good place to hide behind. He moved the curtain a little and went inside.
Anna counted to ten and then opened her eyes. She looked around and tried to find Ben. She saw the toys, the sofa, the table, and the window. She did not see Ben. She wondered where he was. She walked to the living room and saw the curtain. She thought maybe Ben was behind it.
She walked to the curtain and pulled it back. She saw Ben, but she also saw something else. It was a big, furry, unknown animal. It had sharp teeth and claws and it growled at them. Anna and Ben were very scared. They did not know what to do.
They remembered what their mom had told them. She had said, "If you ever see an unknown animal, do not touch it or run away. Stay calm and trust me. I will come and help you." Anna and Ben trusted their mom. They held hands and said, "Mom, mom, help us!"
Their mom heard them and came to the living room. She saw the animal and recognized it. It was a bear that had escaped from the zoo. She grabbed a broom and chased it away. She hugged Anna and Ben and said, "You are very brave and smart. You did the right thing. I am proud of you." Anna and Ben were happy and relieved. They thanked their mom and said, "We love you, mom." They decided to play a different game.




Sam was a poor boy who lived in a small house with his mom and dad. He did not have many toys or clothes, but he was happy and kind. He liked to play with his red cap that his mom gave him for his birthday. He wore it every day, even when it was hot or cold.
One day, he saw a new boy in his street. The boy had a big bike and a blue cap. He looked very rich and proud. He rode his bike very fast and did not say hello to anyone. Sam wanted to be his friend, but he was afraid that the boy would not like him.
"Hi, I'm Sam. What's your name?" Sam said to the boy, holding his red cap in his hand.
The boy stopped his bike and looked at Sam. He saw his old clothes and his dirty shoes. He laughed and said, "My name is Max. And you are a poor and silly boy. Look at your cap. It is ugly and old. My cap is new and cool. You can't play with me. Go away!"
Sam felt very sad and hurt. He ran back to his house and cried. His mom saw him and hugged him. She said, "Don't mind Max. He is a rude and mean boy. He does not know how to be a good friend. You are a smart and sweet boy. You have a beautiful cap that I made for you with love. You can play with anyone you want. Why don't you invite some of your friends to come over and have some cookies?"
Sam smiled and wiped his tears. He said, "Thank you, mom. You are the best. I love you and I love my cap. I will invite Tom and Lily and Ben. They are my good friends. They like me and my cap. We will have fun and share our cookies."
Sam called his friends and they came to his house. They played with his cap and his toys. They ate the cookies and drank some milk. They laughed and talked and had a good time. Sam was happy and forgot about Max. He learned that being rich or poor does not matter. What matters is being kind and generous. He also learned that his cap was not ugly and old. It was special and precious. It was a cap of friendship.




Lily was a spoiled girl who always wanted new toys. She did not like to share or play with her old toys. She only wanted the toys that she saw on TV or in the store. One day, she saw a big, shiny car that could seat four dolls. She asked her mom to buy it for her, but her mom said no. It was too expensive and Lily had enough toys already.
Lily was very angry and sad. She cried and screamed and threw a tantrum. She did not listen to her mom or say sorry. She ran to her room and slammed the door. She looked at her toys and hated them. She wished she had the big, shiny car.
The next day, Lily's mom had to go to work at the factory. She made clothes and shoes for other people. She asked Lily to come with her, because she could not find a babysitter. Lily did not want to go, but she had no choice. She put on her coat and shoes and followed her mom.
At the factory, Lily saw many machines and people working hard. They were noisy and busy and dirty. Lily did not like it. She wanted to go home and play with her toys. She told her mom that she was bored and hungry and tired. Her mom said that she had to work for a few hours and then they could go home. She gave Lily a sandwich and a juice and told her to seat on a chair and be quiet.
Lily ate her sandwich and drank her juice, but she was still bored. She looked around and saw a big pile of boxes. She wondered what was inside them. She got up from her chair and walked to the boxes. She opened one and saw a big, shiny car that could seat four dolls. It was the same car that she wanted. She was very happy and excited. She took the car out of the box and put it on the floor. She found four dolls in another box and put them in the car. She pretended that she was driving the car and having fun. She did not care that the boxes and the car and the dolls belonged to the factory and not to her. She did not care that she was being naughty and selfish. She only cared about the car.




Tom and Lily were playing in the bathroom. They liked to pretend they were pirates and use the towels as sails and the brushes as swords. They saw a shiny thing on the sink. It was a razor. Tom wanted to play with it.
"Look, Lily, a treasure!" he said. "Let's see what it can do."
He picked up the razor and tried to cut the towel. But the razor was sharp and it cut his finger. He cried out in pain and dropped the razor. It broke into pieces and they scattered on the floor.
"Ow, ow, ow!" Tom shouted. "It hurts, it hurts!"
Lily ran to him and saw the blood on his finger. She was scared and sorry.
"Tom, I'm sorry, I'm sorry!" she said. "You shouldn't play with that. It's not a treasure, it's a razor. It's for grown-ups, not for kids. It's dangerous and disgusting."
She wrapped his finger with a tissue and hugged him. She heard their mom coming.
"Mom, mom, help!" she called. "Tom cut his finger with a razor. It was an accident, we were playing pirates."
Their mom came into the bathroom and saw the mess. She was angry and worried.
"What have you done?" she asked. "How did you get the razor? You know you're not allowed to touch it. It's very sharp and it can hurt you. Look at all the blood and the broken pieces. It's disgusting and unsafe. You could have cut yourself worse or stepped on them."
She took Tom and Lily to the kitchen and cleaned and bandaged Tom's finger. She gave them both a hug and a kiss.
"I'm glad you're okay, Tom," she said. "But you have to be more careful and listen to me. Razors are not toys, they are tools. And you have to respect them and leave them alone. Do you understand?"
Tom nodded and said he was sorry. He felt bad and stupid.
"I understand, mom," he said. "I'm sorry, mom. I won't play with razors again. I don't like them. They're disgusting and they hurt."
Lily nodded and said she was sorry too. She felt guilty and sad.
"I'm sorry, mom," she said. "I should have stopped Tom. I don't like razors either. They're disgusting and they scare me."
Their mom smiled and said she forgave them. She told them to be more careful and to play with safer things. She said she loved them and they were her treasures. She took them to their room and gave them some books and toys. They said they loved her too and they were sorry. They hugged and kissed her and said they would be good. They learned their lesson and never played with razors again.




Tom and Anna are friends. They like to play and eat together. One day, they go to the park with their moms. They see a big truck with a picture of a waffle on it. They want to try a waffle.
"Mom, can we have a waffle, please?" Tom asks.
"Me too, me too!" Anna says.
Their moms smile and nod. They walk to the truck and wait in line. The man in the truck is very busy. He makes many waffles for many people. He is humble and kind. He says hello and thank you to everyone.
When it is Tom and Anna's turn, he asks them, "What kind of waffle do you want? I have chocolate, strawberry, and vanilla."
Tom and Anna look at each other. They do not know what to answer. They like all the kinds of waffles. They think hard.
"Um, can we have one of each?" Tom says.
"Yeah, one of each!" Anna says.
The man in the truck laughs. He says, "Sure, why not? You are very brave and curious. Here you go, one chocolate, one strawberry, and one vanilla waffle. Enjoy!"
Tom and Anna are very happy. They say thank you to the man and take their waffles. They sit on a bench and share their waffles. They taste each kind and say which one they like best.
"I like chocolate best. It is sweet and yummy," Tom says.
"I like strawberry best. It is pink and fruity," Anna says.
"I like vanilla best. It is white and creamy," the man in the truck says. He comes to the bench and sits with them. He has a waffle too.
Tom and Anna are surprised. They did not see him come. They smile and offer him some of their waffles.
"Thank you, that is very nice of you. But I have my own waffle. I like to eat one every day. It makes me happy," the man says.
Tom and Anna nod. They understand. They like to eat waffles too. They make them happy. They finish their waffles and lick their fingers. They say goodbye to the man and thank him again. They hug their moms and go home. They had a fun and tasty day. They are good friends.




Lily and Ben were best friends. They liked to play at the park together. They liked to go on the slide, the swings, and the seesaw. But today, there was a problem. There was a big girl on the slide. She wore a pink dress and a pink bow. She did not let anyone else go on the slide. She said it was her slide and she was the queen.
Lily and Ben waited and waited. They wanted to go on the slide too. They asked the big girl nicely, but she said no. She said they were too small and too silly. She laughed at them and pushed them away. Lily and Ben felt sad and angry. They did not like the big girl. They did not think she was a good queen.
Then, they had an idea. They whispered to each other and smiled. They ran to the swings and the seesaw. They had fun and made a lot of noise. They pretended they did not care about the slide. They hoped the big girl would get bored and leave.
But the big girl did not leave. She stayed on the slide. She watched Lily and Ben. She felt lonely and jealous. She wanted to play with them too. She wanted to have friends. She got off the slide and walked towards them. She tried to say hello, but they ignored her. They turned their backs and kept playing. They did not want to talk to her. They did not want to share with her.
The big girl felt sad and angry. She did not like Lily and Ben. She did not think they were nice. She cried and ran away. She wished she had been nicer. She wished she had shared the slide. She learned a lesson. She learned that being mean does not make you happy. She learned that being kind does.




Sara and Tom are playing with blocks. They want to make a big tower. Sara puts a block on top of another block. Tom puts a block next to Sara's block. They are happy.
But then, Ben comes. Ben is not nice. He likes to break things. He sees Sara and Tom's tower. He runs to it and pushes it. The blocks fall down. Sara and Tom are sad and angry.
"Ben, why did you do that?" Sara asks. "That was our tower. We worked hard to make it."
"I don't care. I like to break things. It's fun." Ben says. He laughs.
Sara and Tom don't like Ben. They want to make him stop. They look around. They see a big box. They have an idea.
They pick up the box and carry it to Ben. They put the box over Ben. Ben is under the box. He can't see or move. He is scared.
"Help! Let me out!" Ben cries.
Sara and Tom smile. They say, "Now you know how it feels to have your things broken. Maybe next time you will be nice and not break things."
They leave Ben under the box. They go back to their blocks. They start to make a new tower. They are grateful for their blocks and for each other. They are happy.




Lily and Max are playing in the kitchen. They want to make a cake for Mom. They have flour, eggs, milk, sugar, and chocolate. They put everything in a big bowl.
"Let's mix, mix, mix!" Lily says. She takes a big spoon and stirs the bowl. Max helps her. The bowl makes a funny sound. "Squish, squish, squish!"
"What is this?" Max asks. He looks at the bowl. The bowl is brown and sticky. It does not look like a cake. It looks like a mystery.
"Maybe we need more chocolate," Lily says. She breaks a big piece of chocolate and puts it in the bowl. She mixes again. The bowl makes a different sound. "Crunch, crunch, crunch!"
"Now what is this?" Max asks. He looks at the bowl again. The bowl is darker and harder. It does not look like a cake. It looks like a rock.
"Maybe we need more milk," Lily says. She pours some milk in the bowl. She mixes one more time. The bowl makes a smooth sound. "Swish, swish, swish!"
"Is this a cake?" Max asks. He looks at the bowl for the last time. The bowl is soft and shiny. It looks like a cake. It smells like a cake. It tastes like a cake.
"Yes, this is a cake!" Lily says. She smiles. Max smiles too. They are happy. They made a cake for Mom. They clean the kitchen and put the cake on a plate. They write a note for Mom. It says: "We love you, Mom. We made you a cake. It is a mystery cake. We hope you like it. Love, Lily and Max." They put the note next to the cake and wait for Mom to come home. They are proud of their cake. They are proud of their mix.




Lily liked to draw figures on paper. She drew people, animals, and things she saw. She used many colors and shapes. She wanted to show her drawings to someone.
One day, she saw a big poster on the wall. It had a figure of a man with a funny hat and a long beard. He was holding a book and a pen. The poster said: "Come and meet the famous writer Mr. Brown. He will show you his new book and sign it for you."
Lily was curious. She asked her mom: "Who is Mr. Brown? Why is he famous?"
Her mom said: "Mr. Brown is a writer. He writes stories for children. He is famous because many people like his stories. He is coming to the library today. Do you want to go and see him?"
Lily nodded. She said: "Yes, I want to see him. Maybe he will like my drawings. Can I show him my drawings?"
Her mom smiled. She said: "Sure, you can show him your drawings. Maybe he will be inspired by them. Let's go to the library."
They went to the library. There were many people waiting in line to meet Mr. Brown. Lily held her drawings in her hand. She was excited and nervous.
When it was their turn, Mr. Brown smiled at them. He said: "Hello, I'm Mr. Brown. What's your name?"
Lily said: "I'm Lily. I like your stories. I also like to draw figures. Can I show you my drawings?"
Mr. Brown said: "Of course, I would love to see your drawings. Let me see what you have."
Lily showed him her drawings. He looked at them carefully. He said: "Wow, these are amazing. You have a lot of talent and imagination. You are a very good artist. Can I keep one of your drawings?"
Lily was surprised and happy. She said: "Yes, you can keep one. Which one do you like?"
Mr. Brown said: "I like this one. It has a figure of a girl with a big hat and a long scarf. She is holding a book and a pen. She looks like a writer. Can I have this one?"
Lily said: "Yes, you can have it. It's me. I want to be a writer like you."
Mr. Brown said: "You do? That's wonderful. Maybe one day, you will be a famous writer too. Here, let me sign this book for you. It's my new book. It's about a girl who likes to draw figures and write stories. Maybe you will like it."
He signed the book and gave it to Lily. He said: "Thank you for your drawing. It's very special to me. Keep drawing and writing, Lily. You have a bright future ahead of you."
Lily hugged him. She said: "Thank you, Mr. Brown. You are very kind. I will read your book and write my own stories. Maybe one day, I will show them to you."
They said goodbye and left. Lily was very happy. She had met a famous writer and showed him her drawings. He had liked them and given her a book. She felt proud and inspired. She couldn't wait to read the book and write her own stories. She had a big smile on her face.




Anna and Ben are playing with their toy animals. Anna has a lion and Ben has a giraffe. They make the animals talk to each other.
"Hello, lion. I am giraffe. Do you want to be friends?" Ben says.
"Yes, giraffe. I want to be friends. You are very tall and I am very strong. We can help each other," Anna says.
They play for a long time, making the animals run, jump, and eat. They have fun and laugh a lot.
Soon, it is evening. The sky is dark and the stars are bright. Anna and Ben's mom calls them.
"Anna, Ben, it is time to go to bed. Come and brush your teeth and put on your pajamas," mom says.
Anna and Ben do not want to stop playing. They want to play more with their animals.
"Mom, can we play a little more? Please, please, please?" Anna says.
"Mom, we are having so much fun. Just a little more?" Ben says.
Mom smiles and shakes her head. She is patient with them.
"No, my loves. You have played enough for today. You need to sleep and rest. You can play more tomorrow. Come on, let's go," mom says.
Anna and Ben sigh. They know mom is right. They pick up their animals and hug them.
"Good night, lion. Good night, giraffe. Thank you for being my friend," Anna says.
"Good night, giraffe. Good night, lion. You are my best friend," Ben says.
They put their animals on their beds and follow mom. Before they go to their rooms, they bow to each other.
"Good night, Anna. Good night, Ben. You are my best sister/brother," they say.
They kiss mom and go to sleep. They dream of their animals and their friendship.




Jen and Ben liked to play with blocks. They had many blocks of different colors and shapes. They could make towers, bridges, houses, and more. They had a big box to keep their blocks in when they were done.
One day, Jen had an idea. She wanted to make a zigzag with the blocks. A zigzag is a line that goes this way and that way, like a snake. She took out many blocks and started to make a zigzag on the floor. She used red blocks, blue blocks, yellow blocks, and green blocks. She made the zigzag very long and very pretty.
Ben saw what Jen was doing and wanted to join. He took out more blocks and added them to the zigzag. He used orange blocks, purple blocks, white blocks, and black blocks. He made the zigzag longer and longer. He said, "Look, Jen, our zigzag is almost as long as the room!"
Jen and Ben were having fun, but they did not notice that they had used almost all the blocks in the box. The box was very empty. They also did not notice that their mom was coming to check on them. She wanted them to be tidy and put their toys away.
When mom opened the door, she saw the zigzag on the floor. She saw the blocks of many colors and shapes. She saw the empty box. She was not happy. She said, "Jen and Ben, what have you done? You have made a big mess with your blocks. You have filled the floor with a zigzag. You have not been tidy at all. You need to clean up right now!"
Jen and Ben looked at each other. They looked at the zigzag. They looked at the box. They looked at mom. They knew they had done something wrong. They said, "Sorry, mom. We were just playing. We will put the blocks back in the box. We will be tidy."
Mom nodded. She said, "Thank you, Jen and Ben. I know you like to play with blocks, but you also need to be responsible. Next time, please do not fill the floor with a zigzag. Please keep some blocks in the box. Please be tidy."
Jen and Ben said, "OK, mom. We will." They started to pick up the blocks and put them in the box. They learned their lesson. They still liked to play with blocks, but they also liked to be tidy.




Tom and Lily were very happy. They were going to camp with Mom and Dad. They packed their bags and got in the car. They sang songs and played games on the way.
When they got to the camp, they saw a big tent. Mom and Dad helped them open the tent and put their bags inside. Then they went to explore the camp. They saw a lake, a fire, and some other kids.
"Hi, I'm Tom and this is Lily. We are new here. Do you want to play with us?" Tom asked a boy and a girl who were throwing a ball.
"Sure, we are Jack and Anna. We are adventurous. We like to do fun things. Do you want to join us?" Jack said.
"Yes, we do. We are adventurous too. What do you like to do?" Lily said.
"We like to swim, fish, and hike. There is a lot to see and do here. Come on, let's go!" Anna said.
Tom and Lily followed Jack and Anna. They had a lot of fun at the camp. They made new friends and learned new things. They were very happy. They thanked Mom and Dad for taking them to the camp. They said they wanted to come back again.




Mia and Leo were playing with blocks in the living room. They liked to build towers and bridges and houses with the colorful blocks. Sometimes they would knock them down and start again.
"Look, Mia, I made a big tower!" Leo said, pointing to his creation. "It is taller than you!"
Mia looked at Leo's tower and felt a little jealous. She wanted to make a big tower too, but she only had a few blocks left. She looked around and saw a block on Leo's tower that he did not need. She had an idea.
She walked over to Leo's tower and reached for the block. She was about to remove it when Leo saw her.
"Hey, Mia, what are you doing?" Leo asked, frowning. "That is my block! You cannot take it!"
Mia felt scared and guilty. She quickly put the block back and hid her hand behind her back. She put her thumb in her mouth and looked down.
"I'm sorry, Leo," she mumbled. "I just wanted a big tower too."
Leo looked at Mia and saw that she was sad. He felt a little sorry for her too. He was thoughtful and had another idea.
He took a block from his tower and gave it to Mia.
"Here, Mia, you can have this block," he said. "We can share the blocks and make big towers together."
Mia smiled and took the block from Leo. She removed her thumb from her mouth and hugged him.
"Thank you, Leo," she said. "You are a good friend."
They both smiled and continued to play with the blocks. They made big towers and bridges and houses together. They had fun and were happy.




Tom and Ben are brothers. They like to play with their toy cars. They have many cars of different colors and sizes. Some cars are fast, some cars are loud, some cars are big.
One day, Tom finds a new car in his room. It is a steel car. It is shiny and heavy. It has four big wheels and a long nose. Tom thinks it is the best car ever. He wants to play with it alone.
"Look, Ben, this is my new car!" Tom says. "It is a steel car. It is strong and cool. You cannot play with it. It is only for me."
Ben feels sad and angry. He likes cars too. He wants to play with the steel car. He thinks Tom is not nice. He says, "No, Tom, that is not fair. The steel car is not only for you. It is for both of us. We can share it and play together. That is more fun."
Tom shakes his head. He does not want to share. He says, "No, Ben, go away. The steel car is mine. You have your own cars. Leave me alone."
Ben does not go away. He tries to grab the steel car from Tom. Tom holds it tight. They pull and push. They yell and cry. They fight over the steel car.
Mom hears the noise. She comes to the room. She sees Tom and Ben fighting. She is not happy. She says, "Stop, boys, stop! What are you doing? Why are you fighting over a toy? That is not nice. That is not how brothers should be."
She takes the steel car from them. She says, "This steel car is not for anyone now. It is for the shelf. You cannot play with it until you learn to share and be kind. Now, say sorry to each other and hug."
Tom and Ben feel sorry. They say sorry to each other and hug. They say sorry to Mom too. They understand that sharing is better than fighting. They decide to play with their other cars together. They are happy again. They are good brothers.




Anna likes to go to the gym with her mom. The gym has many fun things to play with. Anna can jump on the big mat, swing on the rope, and roll on the ball. She likes to part her hair in two and tie it with ribbons. She thinks it makes her look like a star.
One day, Anna meets a new friend at the gym. Her name is Lily. Lily has long hair and a pink dress. She also likes to part her hair in two and tie it with ribbons. Anna and Lily play together on the big mat. They take turns jumping and clapping. They laugh and giggle.
Anna and Lily are very happy. They decide to share their ribbons. Anna gives Lily one of her blue ribbons, and Lily gives Anna one of her yellow ribbons. They part their hair again and tie it with the new ribbons. They think they look like twins.
Anna and Lily hug and say goodbye. They promise to play again next time. Anna runs to her mom and shows her the yellow ribbon. Her mom smiles and says, "You are very lucky, Anna. You have a new friend and a new ribbon. I am proud of you." Anna feels warm and fuzzy. She loves her mom, her friend, and her ribbon. She thinks she is the luckiest girl in the world.




Tim and Sam were brothers who liked to go camping with their dad. They had a small cabin in the woods where they could sleep and play. One night, they heard a loud noise outside. They were scared and ran to their dad.
"Dad, what is that?" Tim asked.
"It sounds like a bear, boys. Stay inside and be quiet," their dad said. He grabbed a flashlight and a stick and went out to scare the bear away.
Tim and Sam waited in the cabin, but they did not hear their dad come back. They heard more noises, like growls and thumps and screams. They were very troubled and hugged each other.
"Dad, where are you?" Sam cried.
But their dad did not answer. The bear had found him and hurt him very badly. He could not move or talk. The bear was hungry and angry and wanted more food. It smelled the boys in the cabin and broke the door with its claws. Tim and Sam saw the bear and screamed, but it was too late. The bear attacked them and ate them. They could not sleep or play anymore. They were gone.




Tom and Sam are friends. They like to play together. They have a big box of toys. They have cars, balls, dolls, and books. They share their toys and have fun.
One day, Tom finds a suit in the box. It is a blue suit with a tie and a hat. Tom likes the suit. He puts it on and says, "Look at me, Sam. I am a boss. I can tell you what to do."
Sam does not like the suit. He thinks Tom is silly. He says, "No, you are not a boss. You are my friend. Take off the suit and play with me."
Tom does not listen. He says, "No, I like the suit. It is mine. You can play with the other toys. Go away."
Sam is sad. He does not want to play with the other toys. He wants to play with Tom. He says, "Please, Tom. Don't be mean. The suit is not yours. It is ours. We can take turns. Don't separate from me."
Tom is stubborn. He says, "No, I don't want to take turns. I don't want to play with you. You are not loyal. You are not my friend. Go away."
Sam is hurt. He does not understand why Tom is so rude. He says, "Fine. I will go away. But you are wrong. I am loyal. I am your friend. You are the one who is not loyal. You are the one who is not my friend."
Sam leaves the box. He finds another friend to play with. He is happy.
Tom stays in the box. He wears the suit. He is alone. He is not happy.
