Ben and Lily are twins. They like to play in the park with their dog, Spot. Spot is big and brown and likes to run and bark.
One day, they see a new dog in the park. The new dog is small and white and has a pink bow on its head. The new dog's name is Fluffy. Fluffy's owner is a lady in a blue dress. She is sitting on a bench and reading a book.
"Hello, Fluffy," Ben says. He wants to pet the new dog. He thinks Fluffy is cute.
"Hello, Ben," Fluffy says. She wags her tail and licks Ben's hand. She thinks Ben is nice.
Lily is surprised. She did not know that dogs can talk. She looks at Spot. Spot does not talk. He only barks.
"Can you talk, Spot?" Lily asks.
Spot barks. He does not understand Lily. He does not care about Fluffy. He smells something good. He sees a man with a bag of meat. The man is walking to his car. Spot wants the meat. He runs after the man.
"Spot, come back!" Ben and Lily shout. They run after Spot. They are worried. They do not want Spot to get in trouble.
Fluffy and her owner watch them go. Fluffy is confused. She does not know why Spot wants the meat. She does not like meat. She likes dog food and treats.
"Are they your friends, Fluffy?" the lady asks.
Fluffy nods. She says, "Yes, they are. They seem fine. But Spot is silly. He does not know how to talk. He only knows how to bark."




Lily wanted to whistle like her big brother Tom. She saw him make a funny shape with his mouth and blow air. Then he made a nice sound that sounded like a bird. Lily tried to do the same, but she only made a puff of air. She tried again and again, but she could not whistle.
"Whistling is hard," she said to Tom. "How do you do it?"
Tom smiled and said, "You have to put your tongue behind your teeth and make a small hole with your lips. Then you blow gently and move your tongue a little. Like this." He whistled again and Lily watched him carefully.
She copied his mouth and tongue and blew softly. She heard a faint sound that was almost like a whistle. She was happy and tried again. She whistled louder and louder, until she was very proud of herself.
She ran to show her mom and dad her new skill. She did not see the shoe that was on the floor. She tripped over the shoe and fell down. She was clumsy and hurt her knee. She cried and dropped her mouth.
Mom and dad came to help her. They hugged her and kissed her knee. They said, "It's okay, Lily. You are not clumsy. You are brave and smart. You learned how to whistle today. That's amazing. Can you show us?"
Lily nodded and wiped her tears. She made the funny shape with her mouth and blew air. She whistled again and smiled. Mom and dad clapped and cheered. They said, "You are a great whistler, Lily. We are very proud of you." Lily felt happy and whistled some more. She forgot about the shoe and the pain. She only remembered the nice sound.




Anna loves her parrot, Max. Max is a playful bird who likes to talk and sing. He can say many words that Anna teaches him. He can also copy sounds that he hears, like the phone or the doorbell.
One day, Anna and Max are playing in the living room. Anna has a toy phone and pretends to call her friends. She says, "Hello, this is Anna. How are you?" Max listens and repeats, "Hello, this is Anna. How are you?" Anna laughs and says, "You are so smart, Max. You sound just like me."
Then, the real phone rings in the kitchen. Anna runs to answer it. She says, "Hello, this is Anna. Who is this?" She hears a familiar voice, but it is not her friend. It is Max. He says, "Hello, this is Anna. How are you?" Anna is surprised and confused. She says, "Max, is that you? How did you get the phone?"
She runs back to the living room and sees Max holding the phone in his beak. He has flown to the kitchen and picked up the phone when it rang. He is very proud of his trick. He says, "Hello, this is Anna. How are you?" Anna shakes her head and smiles. She says, "You are so silly, Max. You are not Anna. You are a parrot. But you are a very clever and playful parrot. I love you, Max." She hugs him and gives him a treat. Max says, "I love you, Anna. Thank you." They go back to playing with the toy phone.




Ben and Lily liked to play on the beach. They had a big surf that they could ride on the waves. They had fun splashing and laughing in the water.
One day, a new boy came to the beach. His name was Sam. He saw Ben and Lily's surf and he wanted it. He did not ask if he could play with them. He just ran and grabbed the surf from Lily's hands. He shouted, "This is mine now!"
Lily was sad and angry. She cried, "That is not nice! That is our surf! Give it back!" Ben was also sad and angry. He tried to get the surf back from Sam, but Sam was too strong. He pushed Ben away and ran to the water with the surf.
But Sam did not know how to ride the surf. He fell off and the waves took the surf away. He was scared and wet. He cried, "Help! Help! I want my surf!"
Ben and Lily saw Sam in trouble. They were still mad at him, but they also wanted to help him. They swam to him and pulled him to the shore. They gave him a towel and a hug. They said, "Are you okay? We are sorry you lost the surf."
Sam felt sorry too. He said, "I am sorry I was mean. I should have asked you if I could play with you. I should not have grabbed your surf. Can you forgive me?"
Ben and Lily nodded. They said, "We forgive you. We can share our surf with you. But you have to be nice and tidy. You have to put the surf back where you found it when you are done."
Sam agreed. He said, "Thank you. You are good friends. I will be nice and tidy. I will put the surf back where I found it when I am done."
They all smiled and played together on the beach. They learned that sharing is better than grabbing, and that being nice and tidy is better than being mean and messy.




Lily and Sam were hungry. They wanted to eat something yummy. They asked their mom to take them to the subway.
The subway was a big train that went under the ground. It was fast and loud. Lily and Sam liked to watch the lights and the people on the subway.
When they got off the subway, they saw a big shop with a sign that said "Pizza". They smelled cheese and tomato and pepperoni. They wanted to eat pizza.
"Mom, can we have pizza?" they asked.
Mom looked at the sign and saw a number. The number was very big. The pizza was expensive.
"Sorry, kids, we can't have pizza. It costs too much money. We have to find something cheaper to eat," she said.
Lily and Sam were sad. They loved pizza. They did not want to eat something else.
They walked around the street and saw other shops. They saw a shop with a sign that said "Hot Dogs". They smelled meat and bread and mustard. They wanted to eat hot dogs.
"Mom, can we have hot dogs?" they asked.
Mom looked at the sign and saw a number. The number was smaller than the pizza, but still big. The hot dogs were expensive.
"Sorry, kids, we can't have hot dogs. They still cost too much money. We have to find something cheaper to eat," she said.
Lily and Sam were very sad. They liked hot dogs. They did not want to eat something else.
They walked some more and saw a shop with a sign that said "Bananas". They smelled fruit and sweetness. They wanted to eat bananas.
"Mom, can we have bananas?" they asked.
Mom looked at the sign and saw a number. The number was very small. The bananas were cheap.
"Yes, kids, we can have bananas. They are good for you and they don't cost a lot of money. Let's buy some and eat them," she said.
Lily and Sam were happy. They liked bananas. They ate them and felt full and healthy.
They thanked their mom and hugged her. They went back to the subway and rode it home. They had a good day.




Lily wanted a haircut. She had long hair that got in her eyes and mouth. She asked her mom to take her to the salon. Mom said yes, but first they had to print a coupon.
Lily and mom went to the computer. Mom typed some letters and clicked the mouse. The printer made a noise and spit out a paper. Lily looked at the paper. It had a picture of scissors and a word she did not know.
"What is this?" Lily asked.
"That is a coupon, sweetie. It means we can pay less money for your haircut. We have to show it to the lady at the salon," mom explained.
Lily nodded. She liked saving money. She took the coupon and put it in her pocket. She and mom got in the car and drove to the salon.
At the salon, Lily saw a lot of people with different hair. Some had short hair, some had curly hair, some had colorful hair. She also saw a lady with a wide smile. She was holding scissors and a comb.
"Hello, I'm Sue. I'm going to give you a haircut. Do you have a coupon?" the lady asked.
Lily reached into her pocket and gave the lady the paper. The lady looked at it and smiled wider.
"Wow, you are a smart girl. You have a good coupon. Come with me, I have a special chair for you," the lady said.
Lily followed the lady to a big chair. The lady put a cape around Lily's neck and lifted her up. Lily looked at herself in the mirror. She was ready for her haircut. She hoped it would look nice.




Tim and Lily were playing in the park. They saw a big tower made of blocks. They wanted to climb it and see how high they could go.
"Let's go to the tower!" Tim said.
"OK, but be careful!" Lily said.
They ran to the tower and started to climb. They were having fun, but they did not see the dark clouds in the sky. Soon, it started to rain. The rain was heavy and cold. It soaked their clothes and hair. The blocks became wet and slippery.
"Oh no, the rain is bad!" Lily said.
"We have to go down!" Tim said.
But as they tried to go down, the tower started to fall. The blocks were cheap and weak. They could not hold the weight of the rain and the children. The tower crashed to the ground with a loud noise. Tim and Lily fell with it. They were not hurt, but they were very wet and dirty.
They got up and looked at the mess. The tower was gone. The blocks were broken and scattered. They felt sad and angry.
"Who made this tower? It was cheap and bad!" Tim said.
"I don't know, but they should make a better one!" Lily said.
They ran to their mom, who was waiting for them with an umbrella. She saw them and smiled.
"Did you have fun, my darlings?" she asked.
They shook their heads and told her what happened. She hugged them and said.
"I'm sorry, that was not a good tower. But don't worry, we can make a new one at home. We have good blocks and glue. And we can dry your clothes and hair. Come on, let's go home!"
They nodded and followed her. They still felt sad, but they also felt hopeful. They wanted to make a new tower, a better one. A tower that would not fall or soak. A tower that they could be proud of.




Sara and her family moved to a new house. They drove a long time in their big automobile. Sara was tired and bored. She wanted to play with her toys and see her friends.
When they got to the new house, Sara saw a lot of boxes. Her mom and dad said they had to unpack them. Sara did not like unpacking. It was hard and boring. She wanted to play with her toys and see her friends.
Sara saw a box with her name on it. She opened it and found her favorite doll, Lily. She hugged Lily and smiled. She was happy to see her. She wanted to play with her and see her friends.
Sara saw a girl next door. She was about her age and had curly hair. She was playing with a ball. Sara wanted to play with her and see her friends.
Sara asked her mom if she could go and say hi. Her mom said yes, but be careful and polite. Sara took Lily and ran to the girl. She said hi and asked her name. The girl said her name was Mia. She smiled and asked Sara if she wanted to play. Sara said yes and thanked her. Mia was compassionate. She shared her ball and played with Lily. Sara was happy. She made a new friend. She still wanted to see her old friends, but she felt better. She liked her new house. She liked unpacking.




Tom and Lily were playing in the park. They liked to pretend they were superheroes. Tom wore a red mask and a cape. Lily wore a blue mask and a skirt. They ran around and made noises.
"Zap! I am Red Flash, the fastest and most powerful superhero!" Tom said.
"Pow! I am Blue Star, the smartest and most powerful superhero!" Lily said.
They saw a big dog near the swings. The dog was barking and growling. It looked angry and scary.
"Help! It is a bad dog! It wants to bite us!" Tom said.
"No, it is not a bad dog. It is just lonely and sad. It needs a friend. Watch me!" Lily said.
She took off her mask and walked slowly to the dog. She smiled and talked softly.
"Hello, dog. You are a good dog. Do you want to play with us?" Lily said.
The dog stopped barking and growling. It wagged its tail and licked Lily's hand. It was a friendly dog.
"Wow, you are brave and kind, Lily. You are a powerful superhero!" Tom said.
He took off his mask and joined Lily and the dog. They petted the dog and threw a ball for it. The dog was happy and so were they.
They had a new friend. They were the best superheroes.




Bunny and Squirrel were best friends. They liked to play in the forest and find nuts and carrots. One day, they saw a big pile of nuts near a tree. They ran to the pile and started to eat.
"Yum, these nuts are so good!" said Bunny.
"Let's take some to our homes!" said Squirrel.
They filled their cheeks with nuts and ran to their holes. But they did not see that the pile of nuts belonged to Bear. Bear was sleeping under the tree. He woke up and saw his nuts were gone.
"Who took my nuts?" he roared. He followed the trail of nuts to Bunny's hole. He saw Bunny hiding inside.
"Bunny, did you take my nuts?" he asked.
Bunny felt guilty. He knew he did a bad thing. He nodded his head.
"I'm sorry, Bear. I was hungry and I did not know they were yours," he said.
Bear was angry. He wanted his nuts back. He reached into the hole and tried to grab Bunny. But the hole was too small for his paw. He got stuck.
"Ow, ow, ow!" he cried.
Squirrel heard Bear's cry. He ran to Bunny's hole. He saw Bear's paw in the hole. He saw Bunny's scared face.
"Bunny, are you okay?" he asked.
"No, Squirrel. Bear is mad at me. He wants his nuts back. But I ate them all," said Bunny.
Squirrel felt sorry for Bunny. He also felt guilty. He knew he did a bad thing too. He had some nuts in his hole. He decided to share them with Bear.
"Squirrel, what are you doing?" asked Bunny.
"I'm going to give some of my nuts to Bear. Maybe he will forgive us and let us go," said Squirrel.
He ran to his hole and brought some nuts. He gave them to Bear.
"Here, Bear. These are some of the nuts we took. We are sorry. Please let us go," he said.
Bear looked at the nuts. He looked at Squirrel. He looked at Bunny. He saw they were sorry. He felt a little better.
"Thank you, Squirrel. That was very nice of you. I forgive you and Bunny. But don't take my nuts again. They are mine," he said.
He pulled his paw out of the hole. He took his nuts and walked away.
Bunny and Squirrel came out of the hole. They hugged each other.
"Thank you, Squirrel. You are a good friend," said Bunny.
"Thank you, Bunny. You are a good friend too," said Squirrel.
They learned their lesson. They never took nuts that were not theirs again. They played in the forest and found nuts and carrots that were free. They were happy.




Lily and Ben were playing in the sandbox. They liked to make castles and roads with the sand. But sometimes they found pebbles in the sand. Pebbles were hard and round and not good for building.
"Look, I found a big pebble!" Ben said. He held it in his hand and showed it to Lily.
"Wow, that is a big pebble!" Lily said. "Can I see it?"
Ben gave the pebble to Lily. She felt it with her fingers. It was smooth and heavy.
"Can I keep it?" Lily asked. "I like it. It is pretty."
"No, it is mine!" Ben said. He tried to take the pebble back from Lily. But Lily held it tight.
"Give it back!" Ben said. He pulled harder.
"No, it is mine!" Lily said. She pulled harder too.
They both wanted the pebble. They both pulled and pulled. It was difficult to remove the pebble from each other.
"Stop!" a voice said. It was Mom. She saw them fighting over the pebble.
"What are you doing?" Mom asked. She came to the sandbox.
"We found a pebble and we both want it!" Ben said.
"It is mine!" Lily said.
"No, it is mine!" Ben said.
Mom looked at the pebble. It was not very special. It was just a pebble.
"Listen, children," Mom said. "It is not nice to fight over a pebble. There are many pebbles in the sandbox. You can find another one. Or you can share this one. Or you can trade it for something else. But you cannot pull and hurt each other. Do you understand?"
Lily and Ben nodded. They felt sorry for fighting.
"OK, then," Mom said. "Why don't you say sorry to each other and give each other a hug?"
Lily and Ben said sorry and hugged. They felt better.
"Good," Mom said. "Now, do you want to keep the pebble or give it to me?"
Lily and Ben looked at the pebble. It was not very important anymore.
"You can have it, Mom," they said together.
"Thank you," Mom said. She took the pebble and put it in her pocket.
"Come on, let's go inside and have some juice," Mom said.
Lily and Ben followed Mom. They left the pebble and the sandbox behind. They did not care about them anymore. They were happy to be friends.




Lily and Ben are twins. They like to play and have fun. Today is their birthday. Mom and Dad have a big surprise for them. They make a big cake with candles and frosting. They hide the cake in the kitchen.
Mom and Dad call Lily and Ben to the living room. They say, "We have a surprise for you. But you have to be quiet and close your eyes. No peeking!" Lily and Ben are excited. They do what Mom and Dad say. They are quiet and close their eyes.
Mom and Dad bring the cake to the living room. They put it on the table. They light the candles. They say, "Okay, you can open your eyes now. Happy birthday, Lily and Ben!" Lily and Ben open their eyes. They look at the cake. They see the candles and the frosting. They see their names on the cake. They are very happy. They say, "Wow! Thank you, Mom and Dad! The cake is so big and pretty!"
Mom and Dad say, "You're welcome, Lily and Ben! We love you very much. Now, make a wish and blow out the candles!" Lily and Ben think of a wish. They blow out the candles together. They clap and cheer. Mom and Dad cut the cake and give them a slice each. They eat the cake and enjoy it. They say, "The cake is so yummy! This is the best birthday ever!"




Tim and Kim were twins who liked to play in the garden. They had many toys, but their favorite was a big red truck. They would drive it around the grass and pretend to be workers.
One day, they saw a small green caterpillar on a leaf. They wanted to look at it, so they parked their truck under a tree and went closer. The caterpillar was very pretty, with yellow spots and a fuzzy body.
"Hello, caterpillar," said Tim. "Do you want to be our friend?"
The caterpillar did not answer, but it moved its head and waved its legs.
"Let's take it home," said Kim. "We can make a house for it and feed it leaves."
They carefully picked up the caterpillar and put it in a plastic box. They were so excited that they forgot about their truck.
But a naughty boy named Dan saw the truck and wanted to play with it. He ran to the tree and grabbed the truck. He did not care that it was not his. He drove it around the garden, but he was very rough. He bumped it into rocks and walls and made it dirty.
Soon, the truck was broken. One of the wheels came off and the horn stopped working. Dan did not care. He threw the truck on the ground and ran away.
Tim and Kim came back from their house with some leaves for the caterpillar. They were happy to see their new friend, but they were sad to see their truck.
"Who did this?" cried Tim. "Our truck is broken!"
"It was Dan," said a voice. It was Lily, their neighbor. She had seen everything. "He was very foolish. He took your truck and played with it badly. He did not ask or say sorry."
Tim and Kim were angry and sad. They loved their truck and they had taken good care of it. They did not like Dan. He was mean and selfish.
"Can we repair it?" asked Kim. She picked up the wheel and tried to put it back.
"Maybe," said Lily. She was good at fixing things. "I have some tools and glue. We can try to make it work again."
"Thank you, Lily," said Tim and Kim. They gave her a hug. They were glad to have a good friend like her.
They took the truck and the caterpillar to Lily's house. They worked together to repair the truck. They cleaned it, glued the wheel, and fixed the horn. It took some time, but they did it.
The truck looked as good as new. Tim and Kim were happy. They thanked Lily again and went back to their garden. They drove the truck around and played with the caterpillar. They had fun and they were careful.
They learned a lesson. They learned to be kind and respectful to their toys and their friends. They learned to avoid Dan, who was foolish and rude. They learned to love their truck and their caterpillar. They were good twins.




Sara liked to play with her dolls. She had a big box of dolls and clothes and shoes. She liked to dress them up and make them talk. She had a tea party with her dolls every day.
One day, she wanted to make real tea for her dolls. She saw her mom's mug on the table. It was big and blue and had a picture of a cat. Sara liked cats. She took the mug and went to the kitchen. She saw a kettle on the stove. She knew it had hot water inside.
She climbed on a chair and reached for the kettle. She was very careful. She did not want to burn herself. She poured some water into the mug. She added a tea bag and some sugar. She stirred it with a spoon. She was very proud. She made tea!
She carried the mug back to the table. She was very careful. She did not want to spill it. She put the mug next to her dolls. She said, "Here you go, dolls. I made you some tea. It is very yummy. You will like it."
She picked up one of her dolls. It was a chubby doll with curly hair and a pink dress. She pretended to make the doll drink the tea. She said, "Mmm, this is good tea. Thank you, Sara. You are a good hostess."
She paused. She heard a noise. It was her mom. She was coming back from the store. Sara knew she had to put the mug back. She did not want her mom to be mad. She quickly put the doll down and grabbed the mug. She ran to the kitchen. She hoped her mom did not see her. She hoped her mom did not see the water on the floor. She hoped her mom did not see the tea bag on the table. She hoped her mom did not see the sugar on the spoon. She hoped her mom did not see the cat on the mug.




Anna and Ben are playing in the park. They like to swing, slide and run. They are very happy and laugh a lot.
"Look, Anna, I can swing very high!" Ben says. He pushes his legs and goes up and down.
"Wow, Ben, you are very good!" Anna says. She swings too, but not as high as Ben.
Suddenly, they hear a loud noise. It sounds like a big bang. They stop swinging and look around.
"What is that?" Anna asks.
"I don't know. Let's go and see!" Ben says.
They jump off the swings and run to the noise. They see a big truck. The truck has a lot of boxes. One of the boxes has fallen from the truck and broken on the ground. There are books and papers everywhere.
"Oops!" Ben says.
"Who did that?" Anna asks.
A man comes out of the truck. He looks angry and sad. He sees the box and the books and papers.
"Oh no! This is my box! It has all my work in it!" he says.
He picks up some of the papers and looks at them. They have a lot of words and numbers that Anna and Ben don't understand.
"What is your work?" Ben asks.
"I am a teacher. I teach big kids about science and math. These are my notes and tests. They are very important. But now they are all ruined!" the man says.
He sighs and shakes his head.
"I'm sorry, mister," Anna says.
"Can we help you?" Ben asks.
The man looks at Anna and Ben. He sees their curious and kind faces. He smiles a little.
"Thank you, kids. You are very sweet. And very intelligent. You want to learn new things. That's good. Maybe you can help me. Can you help me pick up the books and papers and put them back in the box?" he asks.
"Sure, we can!" Anna and Ben say.
They start to help the man. They pick up the books and papers and put them in the box. They are careful not to tear or bend them. They work together and have fun.
The man is happy and grateful. He thanks Anna and Ben for their help. He gives them each a book. The books have pictures and stories about animals and plants.
"These are for you. You can read them and learn more about science and math. You are very smart kids. I hope you enjoy them," he says.
"Thank you, mister!" Anna and Ben say.
They hug the man and say goodbye. They take their books and run back to the swings. They are very excited and proud. They have helped someone and learned something new. They are very happy and laugh a lot.




Tom and Lily are playing in the park. They see a big stone on the grass. Tom wants to pick up the stone and throw it. Lily says no, that is bad. The stone can hurt someone or something.
Tom does not listen to Lily. He picks up the stone and throws it hard. The stone flies in the air and hits a bird. The bird falls to the ground and makes a sad sound. Lily is scared and sad. She runs to the bird and tries to help it.
The bird's mom sees what happened. She is very angry. She flies to Tom and pecks his head. Tom cries and runs away. He drops his hat on the grass. The bird's mom takes the hat and flies away with it.
Lily calls Tom. She says he is sorry and he should come back. Tom is sorry too. He does not want to hurt the bird or lose his hat. He comes back to Lily and the bird. He says he is sorry to the bird and the bird's mom. He asks for his hat back.
The bird's mom sees that Tom is sorry. She is not angry anymore. She flies back with the hat and gives it to Tom. She makes a happy sound and flies away with her bird. Tom and Lily are happy too. They hug and say they are friends. They decide to play with something else, not the stone.




Tim and Jen are friends. They like to play in the park. One day, they see a big bunch of grapes on a tree. They both want to eat the grapes. They run to the tree and try to reach the grapes.
"Give me some grapes!" Tim says.
"No, they are mine!" Jen says.
They pull and tug at the grapes. They do not yield. They do not share. They get angry and sad.
A bird flies by and sees the grapes. The bird is hungry and smart. It lands on the tree and pecks at the grapes. It eats some grapes and flies away.
Tim and Jen stop and look at the bird. They see the bird is happy and full. They see the grapes are fewer and smaller. They feel silly and sorry.
"Let's share the grapes," Tim says.
"OK, let's share," Jen says.
They pick some grapes and eat them. The grapes are cool and sweet. They smile and hug. They are friends again.




Lily and Tom were friends. They liked to play together. One day, they found a big box in the yard. They opened the box and saw many things inside. There were clothes, hats, shoes, and jewels. Lily and Tom wanted to try them on.
"Let's play marry!" Lily said. She put on a white dress and a shiny ring. She gave Tom a black coat and a hat. "You are the groom and I am the bride," she said.
Tom nodded. He liked to play with Lily. He put on the coat and the hat. He looked at Lily and smiled. "You are a pretty bride," he said.
They walked to the door of the house. They wanted to show their parents their game. But the door was locked. They tried to turn the knob, but it did not move. They pushed and pulled, but it did not open. They banged and shouted, but no one heard them.
They were scared. They did not know what to do. They sat on the floor and cried. They wished they did not play marry. They wished they stayed with their parents. They wished they were healthy and happy. But they were not. They were stuck in the box. And no one came to help them. The end.




Lily and Ben wanted to see the parade. They liked the big balloons and the loud music. They asked Mom to take them to the street. Mom said yes, but first they had to tie their shoes.
Lily and Ben tried to tie their shoes. Lily made a knot with her laces. Ben made a loop with his laces. They were proud of their work. They showed Mom their shoes. Mom smiled and said, "Good job, kids. Let's go to the parade."
Lily and Ben followed Mom to the street. They saw many people and cars. They heard horns and drums. They looked for the balloons. They saw a big red balloon shaped like a dog. They saw a big yellow balloon shaped like a star. They saw a big blue balloon shaped like a fish.
Lily and Ben wanted to touch the balloons. They ran to the balloons. They did not see the cars. They did not hear Mom. They did not feel the laces. The laces came undone. The laces tripped them. Lily and Ben fell on the street.
The cars did not see Lily and Ben. The cars did not stop. The cars hit Lily and Ben. Lily and Ben screamed. Mom screamed. The balloons flew away. The parade was over.




Lily and Ben were best friends. They liked to play together in the park. One day, they saw a big tent with many people inside. They heard music and laughter. They wanted to see what was inside.
They sneaked into the tent and saw a man and a woman in pretty clothes. The woman had a veil on her head. It was white and shiny. The man and the woman were holding hands and smiling. They looked happy.
Lily and Ben watched them for a while. They saw them kiss and hug. They heard the people clap and cheer. They learned that the man and the woman were getting married. They were uniting their hearts.
Lily and Ben thought that was nice. They wanted to do the same. They found a veil in a box. It was pink and sparkly. Lily put it on her head. Ben took her hand and smiled. They kissed and hugged. They pretended to be married. They united their hearts.
But then, a fierce dog came into the tent. It barked and growled. It saw Lily and Ben and ran towards them. It wanted to bite them. Lily and Ben were scared. They dropped the veil and ran away. They hid behind a tree. They hoped the dog would go away. They held each other tight. They were still best friends.




Lily and Tom were twins who liked to play in the garden. One day, they saw a big jar of jelly on the table. They wanted to taste it, but they were too small to reach it.
"Let's crawl to the table and get the jelly," Tom said.
"OK, but be quiet. Mommy is sleeping in the sofa," Lily said.
They crawled slowly and quietly across the grass. They saw a lot of bugs and flowers on the way. They said hello to them, but the bugs and flowers did not answer.
They reached the table and climbed on a chair. They saw the jar of jelly shining in the sun. It looked yummy and colorful.
"Wow, look at the jelly. It is red and green and yellow," Tom said.
"Can I have some?" Lily asked.
"Sure, let me open the jar," Tom said.
He tried to open the jar, but it was too tight. He twisted and pulled, but the jar did not move.
"Help me, Lily," he said.
Lily helped him, but the jar was still too tight. They pushed and pulled, but the jar did not move.
They were so busy trying to open the jar that they did not hear Mommy waking up. She saw them on the table and smiled.
"What are you doing, my little ones?" she asked.
They looked at her and smiled back.
"We want some jelly, Mommy," they said.
Mommy laughed and hugged them.
"OK, let me help you with the jar. But first, let's wash your hands. They are dirty from crawling," she said.
She took them to the sink and washed their hands. Then she opened the jar and gave them each a spoon of jelly.
They tasted the jelly and made happy noises.
"Mmm, this is good jelly, Mommy," Tom said.
"Thank you, Mommy. We love you," Lily said.
Mommy kissed them and said, "I love you too, my sweeties. Now, let's go back to the sofa and have a peaceful nap. You must be tired from crawling."
They nodded and followed her to the sofa. They cuddled with her and fell asleep. They dreamed of jelly and bugs and flowers.




Tom and Lily are twins. They like to play with toys. One day, they get a new toy from their mom. It is a metal train. It is shiny and red. Tom and Lily are happy.
"Choo choo!" Tom says. He makes the train go on the floor. He feels the metal. It is cold and hard. He likes the sound it makes.
"Let me play too!" Lily says. She wants to feel the metal. She tries to take the train from Tom. Tom does not want to share. He holds the train tight.
"No, it is mine!" Tom says. He pushes Lily away. Lily feels sad and angry. She cries.
"Hey, stop that!" Mom says. She hears the noise. She comes to see what is wrong. She sees Tom and Lily fighting over the train.
"You have to share, Tom. Lily is your sister. The train is for both of you." Mom says. She takes the train from Tom. She gives it to Lily.
"Thank you, Mom." Lily says. She smiles. She feels the metal. It is cold and hard. She likes the color.
"Sorry, Lily." Tom says. He feels sorry. He does not want to make Lily cry. He wants to play with her.
"It is okay, Tom. We can play together." Lily says. She feels happy. She gives the train back to Tom.
"Thank you, Lily." Tom says. He smiles. He feels happy too. He and Lily play with the train. They take turns. They make the train go fast and slow. They have fun. Mom feels proud. She watches them play. She hugs them. They hug her back. They love each other. The end.




Anna and Ben are friends. They like to play with their carts. They have red carts and blue carts. They push and pull their carts on the grass.
One day, they see a new boy in the park. He has a yellow cart. He does not play with anyone. He is shy.
Anna and Ben want to say hello to him. They walk to him with their carts. They smile and wave.
"Hi, I am Anna. This is Ben. What is your name?" Anna asks.
The new boy looks at them. He does not say anything. He holds his cart tight.
Anna and Ben are nice. They do not laugh or tease. They wait for him to talk.
"Hi, I am Leo. I like your carts. Can I play with you?" Leo says.
Anna and Ben are happy. They nod and say yes. They show Leo their carts. They let him try their carts.
Leo likes their carts. He likes Anna and Ben. He is not shy anymore.
They play with their carts. They have fun. They zip and zoom on the grass. They are friends.




Anna and Ben are playing with their mom's makeup. They like to put lipstick, eyeshadow and blush on their faces. They think they look funny and pretty.
"Look at me, Anna!" Ben says. "I have red lips and blue eyes!"
"You look silly, Ben!" Anna says. "I have pink cheeks and purple lips!"
They laugh and make faces at each other in the mirror.
Mom comes into the room and sees them. She is not happy. She has a gray face and a frown.
"What are you doing with my makeup?" Mom asks. "You made a big mess!"
"Sorry, Mom," Anna and Ben say. "We were just playing."
Mom sighs and shakes her head. She takes a wet cloth and wipes their faces.
"You need to reverse this, kids," Mom says. "Makeup is not for playing. It is for grown-ups."
Anna and Ben nod and say sorry again. They help Mom clean the makeup and put it away.
Mom hugs them and smiles.
"I love you, Anna and Ben," Mom says. "But next time, please ask me before you use my things."
"We love you too, Mom," Anna and Ben say. "And we will ask you next time."
They kiss Mom and go to play with their toys. They decide to play with cars and dolls instead of makeup. They think they are more fun and less messy.




Ben and Lily were twins who liked to play with toys. One day, they found a big magnet in their dad's toolbox. They wondered what it could do.
"Let's examine it," Ben said. He held the magnet near a metal spoon. The spoon jumped to the magnet and stuck to it. "Wow, this is fun!" Ben said.
"Let me try," Lily said. She took the magnet and moved it near a metal car. The car also jumped to the magnet and stuck to it. "This is amazing!" Lily said.
They took turns to examine the magnet and see what else it could attract. They found nails, coins, keys, and even a necklace. They made a pile of metal things on the floor.
"Look at all the things we found!" Ben said. "We are so smart!"
But then, they heard their dad coming. He was looking for his toolbox. He saw the mess on the floor and the magnet in Ben's hand.
"Hey, what are you doing with my magnet?" he asked. "That's not a toy. It's a tool. You could have hurt yourself or damaged something."
Ben and Lily felt sorry. They did not know the magnet was not a toy. They did not mean to make a mess or take their dad's things.
"We're sorry, dad," they said. "We were just curious. We wanted to examine the magnet and see what it could do."
Dad was not angry. He was glad they were curious and wanted to learn. But he also wanted them to be careful and respectful.
"I understand, kids," he said. "But you have to ask me before you use my tools. And you have to put things back where they belong. The magnet is very powerful and can be dangerous. It can also damage some things, like the necklace. That's your mom's necklace. She will be very sad if it's broken."
Ben and Lily felt bad. They did not want to make their mom sad. They gave the necklace back to their dad and helped him put everything back in the toolbox. They also cleaned up the floor and apologized to their dad.
Dad hugged them and smiled. He was proud of them for being honest and helpful. He also gave them a small magnet of their own. He showed them how to use it safely and have fun with it.
"Thank you, dad," Ben and Lily said. "We love you. And we love our magnet. We will be more careful and respectful next time."
They learned a lesson that day. They learned that curiosity is good, but responsibility is also important. They learned that some things are not toys, but tools. And they learned that being smart also means being respectful.




Lily and Tom were going to the park with Mom. They liked the park. It had swings and slides and a big pond with ducks. Mom said they could feed the ducks some bread.
But on the way to the park, they saw a lot of cars on the road. They were not moving. They were making loud noises. Mom said it was traffic. Traffic was bad. It made them late.
Lily and Tom were bored. They wanted to get to the park. They looked out the window and saw a big truck. It had a picture of a lion on it. Lily and Tom liked lions. They were big and strong and had manes.
"Look, Mom, a lion!" Lily said.
"Where?" Mom asked.
"On the truck!" Tom said.
Mom looked at the truck. She smiled. "That's not a real lion, sweeties. That's a picture of a lion. It's for the circus. The circus is in town. They have animals and clowns and acrobats. Do you want to go to the circus?"
Lily and Tom nodded. They wanted to go to the circus. They liked animals and clowns and acrobats. Mom said they could go to the circus after the park.
But then something bad happened. The truck with the lion picture stopped. The door opened. A man came out. He looked angry. He had a whip and a hat. He was the lion tamer. He said something to the driver. Then he went to the back of the truck. He opened another door.
Lily and Tom gasped. They saw a real lion. It was not a picture. It was alive. It had yellow eyes and sharp teeth and a big roar. It did not like the whip and the hat. It did not like the lion tamer. It jumped out of the truck. It ran away.
The lion tamer shouted. He tried to catch the lion. But the lion was faster. It ran across the road. It ran towards the park.
Lily and Tom were scared. They did not like the lion anymore. It seemed hurt and angry. It seemed dangerous. They hoped it would not go to the park. They hoped it would not find the ducks. They hoped it would not find them.




Tom and Anna liked to play in the museum. They liked to look at the old things and make up stories about them. But they had to behave, or the museum lady would be angry. She always said, "This is history, not a playground. Don't touch anything or you will break it."
One day, Tom and Anna saw a big dinosaur bone. It was very long and white and had sharp teeth. They wanted to touch it and pretend to be dinosaurs. They looked around and saw that the museum lady was busy talking to some people. They thought she would not see them.
They ran to the dinosaur bone and started to play. Tom roared like a dinosaur and Anna laughed. They did not see the sign that said, "Do not touch. Fragile." They did not see the rope that was around the bone. They did not see the other museum lady who was watching them.
The other museum lady saw them and shouted, "Stop! You are not allowed to touch that!" She ran to them and tried to pull them away. But she was too late. Tom and Anna were too clumsy. They tripped over the rope and bumped into the bone. The bone wobbled and fell to the floor. It broke into many pieces.
Tom and Anna were scared. They heard a loud noise and saw the museum lady's face. She was very angry. She said, "What have you done? You have ruined history! You are in big trouble!" She took them to the office and called their parents.
Tom and Anna learned a lesson. They learned that they should behave in the museum. They learned that history is important and fragile. They learned that playing with dinosaur bones is not a good idea.




Lily and Ben were friends who lived in a small village. They liked to play together in the fields and the woods. One day, they found a big stick and decided to pretend it was a sword.
They took turns to hold the stick and say, "I am the king of the village! You have to do what I say!" Then they would fight with the stick and try to make the other one say, "You are the king, I give up!"
They had fun fighting with the stick, but they also got angry sometimes. They did not want to lose or share the stick. They shouted and pushed each other. They forgot to be nice and kind.
Soon, their mothers heard them and came to see what was wrong. They saw Lily and Ben fighting with the stick and making a lot of noise. They were not happy. They took the stick away and said, "You two have to stop fighting! Fighting is not a good way to play. You have to share and be gentle. Say sorry to each other and hug."
Lily and Ben felt bad. They knew their mothers were right. They said sorry to each other and hugged. They did not want to fight anymore. They wanted to be friends again. They said, "Let's go and play something else. Something that does not need a stick. Something that is fun and nice."
They ran off to find a new game. They were ready to play and laugh together. They were happy.




Tom and Sam were brothers who liked to play with their toy boats. They had a big tub of water in the backyard where they could sail their boats and pretend to be pirates. Tom had a red boat and Sam had a blue boat. They always tried to make their boats go faster and farther than the other.
One day, Tom had an idea. He wanted to make his boat succeed and win the race. He saw a bottle of soap on the shelf and thought it would make his boat slippery and fast. He poured some soap on his boat and put it in the water. He said to Sam, "Look at my boat, Sam. It is so fast and shiny. You will never catch me!"
Sam looked at Tom's boat and saw that it was leaving a trail of bubbles behind. He thought it was cheating and unfair. He said to Tom, "That is not fair, Tom. You used soap on your boat. That is not how you sail a boat. You are a bad pirate!"
Tom did not care. He laughed and said, "I don't care, Sam. I just want to win. My boat is the best. You are a slow and silly pirate!"
Sam was angry and sad. He wanted to play with Tom, but Tom was being mean and selfish. He decided to teach Tom a lesson. He grabbed a stick and poked Tom's boat. The boat popped and sank in the water. The soap made the water messy and foamy. Tom was shocked and cried. He said to Sam, "What did you do, Sam? You broke my boat. You are a mean and nasty pirate!"
Sam said to Tom, "You deserved it, Tom. You were not playing fair. You were not being a good brother. You should not use soap on your boat. That is not how you sail a boat. You should be honest and kind."
Tom realized that he was wrong. He felt sorry and ashamed. He said to Sam, "I'm sorry, Sam. You are right. I was not playing fair. I was not being a good brother. I should not have used soap on my boat. I should have been honest and kind. Can you forgive me?"
Sam looked at Tom and saw that he was sincere. He said to Tom, "I forgive you, Tom. But you have to promise me that you will never use soap on your boat again. And you have to help me clean up this mess."
Tom nodded and said, "I promise, Sam. And I will help you clean up this mess. And maybe we can share our boats and play together."
Sam smiled and said, "That sounds good, Tom. Let's do that. And maybe we can be good pirates and find some treasure."
They hugged and went to clean up the mess. They learned that cheating is not the way to succeed and that being honest and kind is more important than winning.
The moral of the story is: Cheating is not the way to succeed and being honest and kind is more important than winning.




Sara and Ben were very happy. They were going to the festival with their mom and dad. The festival had many fun things to do. They had balloons, games, music, and food. Sara and Ben wanted to try everything.
They saw a big tent with a sign that said "Fly with us". Inside the tent, there were many colorful kites. Sara and Ben loved kites. They wanted to fly one in the sky. They asked their mom and dad if they could.
"Sorry, kids, but those kites are very expensive," their mom said. "We don't have enough money to buy one. Maybe we can make one at home later."
Sara and Ben felt sad. They really wanted to fly a kite. They looked at the kites with envy. They saw one that was very pretty. It had a rainbow tail and a star on it. Sara and Ben wished they had that kite.
They saw a man who worked in the tent. He was busy talking to some people. He did not see Sara and Ben. They had an idea. They sneaked into the tent and grabbed the rainbow kite. They ran out of the tent with the kite. They thought they were very clever.
They found a big field where they could fly the kite. They took turns holding the string. The kite soared high in the air. It looked beautiful. Sara and Ben felt happy. They forgot that they had stolen the kite.
But then, a strong wind came. It blew the kite away from their hands. They tried to catch the string, but it was too late. The kite flew higher and higher, until they could not see it anymore. It was gone.
Sara and Ben felt very sad. They had lost the kite. They also felt very guilty. They had done a bad thing. They had taken something that was not theirs. They had hurt the man who worked in the tent. They had lied to their mom and dad.
They decided to go back to the tent and say sorry. They hoped the man would forgive them. They also hoped their mom and dad would not be angry. They learned a lesson. They learned that stealing is wrong. They learned that flying a kite is not worth losing their honesty. They learned that the best things in life are not expensive, but priceless.




Lily and Max were playing in the park. They liked to search for shiny things in the sand. Sometimes they found coins, buttons, or beads. They put them in their pockets and showed them to their mom.
One day, they saw something very shiny in the sand. It was a gem. It was orange and sparkled in the sun. Lily and Max ran to pick it up.
"Wow, look at this!" Lily said. "It is so pretty!"
"Can I see?" Max asked. He reached for the gem, but Lily held it tight.
"No, it is mine!" Lily said. "I saw it first!"
"But I want to see it too!" Max said. He tried to grab the gem, but Lily pulled it away.
They started to fight over the gem. They pulled and pushed and shouted. They did not see the big dog that came near them. The dog saw the gem and thought it was a ball. He barked and jumped and snatched the gem from Lily's hand. He ran away with it in his mouth.
Lily and Max stopped fighting. They looked at the dog and the gem. They felt sad and sorry.
"Come back!" Lily cried. "That is our gem!"
"Bad dog!" Max yelled. "Give it back!"
But the dog did not listen. He ran to his owner and wagged his tail. He dropped the gem at his feet and licked his face.
Lily and Max ran after the dog. They tried to get their gem back, but the owner picked it up and put it in his pocket.
"Sorry, kids," he said. "This is my dog's toy. He likes shiny things too."
He walked away with the dog and the gem. Lily and Max looked at each other. They felt sad and angry.
They hugged each other and said sorry. They decided to share their other shiny things. They went back to the sand and searched for more. They hoped to find another gem someday.




Lila and Ben were playing in the park. They liked to run and jump and swing on the swings. They saw a big tree with many branches. Some branches were low and some were high.
"Look, Ben, I can pull this branch!" Lila said. She grabbed a low branch and pulled hard. The branch was old and dry. It broke with a loud snap. Lila fell on the grass.
"Ow, ow, ow!" Lila cried. She hurt her hand and her knee. Ben ran to her and helped her up.
"Are you okay, Lila?" Ben asked. He saw blood on her hand and her knee. He felt sorry for her.
"I'm not okay, Ben. It hurts a lot." Lila said. She was sad and scared. She wanted her mom.
"Let's go find your mom, Lila. She can make you feel better." Ben said. He held her hand and walked with her. He saw a bench where Lila's mom was sitting. He called her name.
"Mom, mom, Lila needs you!" Ben shouted. Lila's mom heard him and saw them. She saw Lila's hand and knee. She got up and ran to them.
"What happened, Lila? What happened, Ben?" Lila's mom asked. She hugged Lila and looked at her wounds.
"Lila pulled a branch and it broke and she fell." Ben said. He told her what happened.
"Oh, Lila, I'm sorry. That was a bad branch. Let me clean your hand and your knee. It will sting a little, but it will help." Lila's mom said. She took out a tissue and some water and some band-aids from her bag. She cleaned Lila's hand and knee and put band-aids on them.
"Thank you, mom. Thank you, Ben." Lila said. She felt a little better. She smiled at her mom and her friend.
"You're welcome, Lila. You're a brave girl. And thank you, Ben, for being a good friend." Lila's mom said. She smiled at them both.
"Can we still play, mom?" Lila asked.
"Sure, Lila, but be careful. Don't pull any more branches, okay?" Lila's mom said.
"Okay, mom. I won't pull any more branches." Lila said.
Lila and Ben went back to play. They had fun in the park. They did not pull any more branches. They played until it was time to go home.




Anna likes purple. She has a purple dress, a purple hat, and a purple ball. She likes to play with her purple ball in the park with her friend Ben. Ben likes green. He has a green shirt, a green cap, and a green bike. He likes to ride his bike in the park with Anna.
One Tuesday, Anna and Ben went to the park with their moms. They played with their ball and bike for a long time. They had fun and laughed a lot. Then they saw a big dog. The dog was brown and furry. It barked and ran towards them. Anna and Ben were scared. They dropped their ball and bike and ran to their moms.
"Mommy, mommy, help!" Anna cried.
"Mommy, mommy, save us!" Ben shouted.
Their moms hugged them and said, "Don't worry, sweeties. The dog is not mean. He just wants to play. See, he is wagging his tail. He is friendly."
Anna and Ben looked at the dog. He was holding their ball in his mouth. He dropped it and wagged his tail more. He looked happy and silly.
"Can we play with him, mommy?" Anna asked.
"Can we pet him, mommy?" Ben asked.
Their moms said, "Yes, you can. But first, you have to ask his owner. He is over there. He is wearing a blue jacket. He is nice too."
Anna and Ben walked to the man with the blue jacket. They said, "Hello, sir. Can we play with your dog? He is cute and funny."
The man smiled and said, "Hello, kids. Of course you can. His name is Spot. He loves to play with children. He is gentle and friendly. You can throw his ball and he will fetch it. You can pet him and he will lick you. He likes hugs too."
Anna and Ben were happy. They played with Spot for a long time. They threw his ball and he fetched it. They petted him and he licked them. They hugged him and he wagged his tail. They had fun and laughed a lot.
They thanked the man and said goodbye to Spot. They hugged their moms and said, "We love you, mommy. Thank you for taking us to the park. We had a great Tuesday."
Their moms hugged them back and said, "We love you too, sweeties. You are brave and kind. We are proud of you. You had a wonderful Tuesday."




Tom and Mia were playing pirates in the backyard. They had a big barrel that they pretended was a treasure chest. They filled it with rocks, sticks, and shiny things they found.
"Arrr, matey, this is our loot!" Tom said, putting on a pirate hat. "We have to guard it from the other pirates!"
Mia nodded and picked up a wooden sword. She liked to play pirates with Tom. They made funny noises and had fun adventures.
But then they heard a growl from behind the bushes. It was Rex, the big dog from next door. He had escaped from his yard and smelled the barrel. He was eager to see what was inside. He ran towards Tom and Mia, barking loudly.
"Uh-oh, it's the sea monster!" Tom shouted. "He wants to bite our treasure!"
Mia was scared of Rex. He was much bigger than her and had sharp teeth. She dropped her sword and ran to the house.
"Help, help, Mommy!" she cried.
Tom was brave. He did not run away. He stood in front of the barrel and waved his sword.
"Go away, sea monster!" he yelled. "This is our treasure! You can't have it!"
Rex did not listen. He jumped on the barrel and tried to open it with his paws. He scratched and bit the wood, making a lot of noise.
Tom was angry. He hit Rex with his sword, but it did not hurt him. It was only a toy.
"Ow, ow, ow!" Rex yelped. He did not like to be hit. He let go of the barrel and ran back to his yard.
Tom cheered. He had saved the treasure from the sea monster. He was a brave pirate.
He went to the house to find Mia. He wanted to share the treasure with her. He hoped she was not too scared.
He knocked on the door and said, "Mia, Mia, it's me, Tom. The sea monster is gone. Come out and play pirates with me!"
Mia opened the door and smiled. She was happy to see Tom. She was not scared anymore.
"OK, Tom, let's play pirates!" she said. "But can we move the barrel to a safer place?"
Tom agreed. He and Mia moved the barrel to the porch. They put a blanket over it to hide it from the other pirates.
They played pirates until it was time for dinner. They had a lot of fun. They were the best pirate friends.




Lily was a friendly girl who liked to help others. One day, she saw a boy who was sad in the park. He had lost his note from his mom. The note said when to go home and what to eat for lunch. Lily wanted to cheer him up, so she gave him a hug and a cookie.
They played together for a while, until Lily saw a piece of paper under a slide. She ran to get it, hoping it was the boy's note. But she did not see the puddle of water on the ground. She slipped and fell into the puddle. She got wet and dirty and hurt her knee.
The boy saw what happened and ran to help her. He took the paper from her hand and looked at it. It was his note! He was so happy and grateful. He thanked Lily and helped her get up. He said he was sorry she slipped and got hurt. He gave her his jacket to keep her warm and dry.
Lily smiled and said it was okay. She was glad she found his note and made him happy. She said he was a good friend. They walked together to the boy's home, where his mom was waiting. She gave them both a hug and a sandwich. She said they were very kind and brave.
Lily and the boy learned that helping others can make you happy, even if you slip and get hurt. They also learned that friendship is a precious gift that can make you feel better. They decided to play together again soon and share more cookies and notes.




Anna and Ben were playing in the sand. They wanted to make a big castle with towers and walls. Anna had a spade and Ben had a bucket. They worked hard and had fun.
"Look, our castle is almost complete!" Anna said. "We just need to make the door and the flag."
"I want to make the door!" Ben said. "You can make the flag."
"No, I want to make the door too!" Anna said. "You always get to do what you want. You are so bossy!"
Anna and Ben started to argue. They both wanted the spade and the bucket. They pulled and pushed and shouted.
"Stop it, you two!" Mom said. She came over and saw the mess. "You are ruining your castle and your friendship. Why can't you share and take turns?"
Anna and Ben felt sorry. They knew Mom was right. They said sorry to each other and hugged.
"Let's finish our castle together," Anna said.
"OK, you can make the door and I'll make the flag," Ben said.
They smiled and used the spade and the bucket to complete their castle. They were proud of their work and their teamwork. Mom took a picture and praised them.
"You are such good builders and good friends," Mom said. "Now, who wants some juice and cookies?"




Tom and Sam are two squirrels who live in a big park. They like to play and look for nuts to eat. One day, they see a large nut on a branch. It is bigger than any nut they have ever seen.
"Wow, look at that nut!" Tom says. "It is so large and shiny. I want to eat it."
"Me too," Sam says. "But how can we get it? It is too high and far."
They stare at the nut and think of a way to reach it. They see a long vine hanging from another tree. They have an idea.
"Let's swing on the vine and grab the nut," Tom says.
"OK, let's try," Sam says.
They run to the vine and take turns to swing on it. They stretch their paws and try to catch the nut. But the nut is too large and heavy. It does not move.
"Ouch, this nut is hard," Tom says.
"It hurts my paw," Sam says.
They swing and swing, but they cannot get the nut. They are tired and hungry.
"Let's give up," Tom says. "This nut is not worth it. There are many other nuts in the park."
"OK, let's go," Sam says. "Maybe we can find a smaller and softer nut."
They leave the vine and the large nut. They do not know that the nut is not a real nut. It is a plastic toy that a child left on the branch. They run and play and look for other nuts. They are happy and forget about the large nut.




Lily and Ben are excited. They are going to the park with Mom and Dad. They put on their hats and shoes. They hold hands and march to the car. They sing a song as they march.
At the park, they see a big lake. They see ducks and fish and boats. They run to the edge of the water. They wave to the ducks and the boats. The ducks quack and the boats honk. Lily and Ben laugh and clap.
Mom and Dad call them for a picnic. They march back to the grass. They sit on a blanket and eat sandwiches and fruit. They drink juice and water. They say thank you to Mom and Dad.
After the picnic, they play on the swings and the slide. They make new friends and share their toys. They have fun and are happy. They wave goodbye to their friends and the park. They march to the car and go home. They are tired but still excited. They hug Mom and Dad and say they love them. They go to bed and dream of the park.




Ben and Mia love to go to the zoo with their mom and dad. They like to see the animals and learn their names. They have a favorite animal: the parrot. The parrot is famous because it can talk. It can repeat what people say.
One day, they go to the zoo and find the parrot in its cage. They say hello to the parrot and wait for it to talk. But the parrot is quiet. It does not repeat anything. Ben and Mia are sad. They wonder why the parrot is not talking.
They ask their mom and dad. Their mom and dad say that the parrot is shy. It does not like to talk when there are many people around. They say that the parrot needs some time and space to feel comfortable. They say that if they are patient and gentle, the parrot might talk to them.
Ben and Mia decide to try. They sit on a bench near the cage and watch the parrot. They talk to the parrot softly and kindly. They say things like "You are a beautiful parrot" and "We are your friends". They do not yell or make loud noises. They do not touch the cage or throw things at the parrot.
After a while, the parrot starts to move its head and look at them. It opens its beak and makes a sound. Ben and Mia are happy. They listen carefully. The parrot says "Hello, beautiful parrot". It repeats what they said. Ben and Mia clap their hands and laugh. They say "Hello, parrot" and "We are happy to meet you". The parrot repeats them too. It says "Hello, parrot" and "We are happy to meet you". Ben and Mia and the parrot have a fun conversation. They are all happy. The parrot is not shy anymore. It is famous and friendly.




Lily was a little girl who liked to look at herself in the mirror. She thought she was very pretty and smart. She liked to wear nice dresses and ribbons in her hair. She did not like to share her toys or play with other children. She only wanted to stay in her room and admire herself in the mirror.
One day, her mother made a delicious cake for her birthday. She invited some of Lily's friends to come and celebrate. Lily did not want to go downstairs and join the party. She wanted to stay in her room and eat the cake by herself. She took the cake from the kitchen and ran to her room. She locked the door and put the cake on her bed. She looked at herself in the mirror and smiled. She thought she was the happiest girl in the world.
But then, something strange happened. The mirror started to change. It showed Lily a different image of herself. She saw herself as a greedy and lonely girl. She saw herself with no friends and no fun. She saw herself with a big belly and a sad face. She saw herself growing old and ugly. She was scared and confused. She did not like what she saw. She wanted to see her real self again.
She ran to the door and tried to open it. But it was stuck. She could not get out. She cried and shouted for help. But no one heard her. Everyone was downstairs, having a good time. They did not miss her. They did not know she was in trouble.
Lily realized she had made a big mistake. She wished she had been kind and friendly. She wished she had shared her cake and played with her friends. She wished she had not been so vain and selfish. She wished she had not stayed in her room and looked at the mirror. She learned a hard lesson. She learned that beauty is not everything. She learned that happiness comes from giving and sharing. She learned that staying alone is not good. She learned that staying in the mirror is bad.




Sam and Mia are twins. They like to play in the backyard. But sometimes they fight over toys. One day, they see a big pile of laundry on the grass. It is Mom's laundry. She is hanging it on the line to dry.
"Look, a mountain!" Sam says. He runs to the laundry and jumps on it. He makes a big mess.
"Hey, stop that!" Mia says. She runs after him and tries to pull him off. "You are ruining Mom's clothes!"
"No, I'm not!" Sam says. He pushes Mia away. "It's fun!"
They start to fight. They pull and push and shout. They are fierce. They do not see Mom coming.
"Sam! Mia! What are you doing?" Mom says. She is angry. She sees her laundry all over the ground. Some of it is dirty and torn.
"Sorry, Mom," Sam and Mia say. They look down. They are ashamed.
Mom makes them pick up the laundry and help her wash it again. She tells them to be nice to each other and share their toys. She says fighting is bad.
Sam and Mia hug and say sorry to each other. They promise to be good. They learn their lesson.




Ben likes to play the drum. He has a big drum with a white skin. He hits the drum with his sticks and makes a loud sound. He likes to make a rhythm with his drum. He taps fast and slow, loud and soft.
One day, Ben's drum skin breaks. He hits it too hard and makes a hole. He is sad. He cannot play his drum anymore. He looks for something to replace his drum skin. He tries a paper, a cloth, a lid, but nothing works. They do not make a good sound.
Then, he sees his mom's cake. She has baked a cake for his birthday. It has a white frosting. It looks like his drum skin. He thinks it will work. He takes the cake and puts it on his drum. He hits the cake with his sticks. It makes a squishy sound. He likes it. He makes a new rhythm with his cake drum.
But his mom does not like it. She sees Ben playing with her cake. She is angry. She says, "Ben, what are you doing? That is not a drum. That is a cake. You have ruined it. You cannot replace your drum skin with a cake. That is silly."
Ben is sorry. He did not mean to make his mom angry. He says, "I'm sorry, mom. I just wanted to play the drum. I did not have a drum skin. I thought the cake would work. It looked like a drum skin. It was white."
His mom sighs. She says, "I know, Ben. I know you love your drum. But you cannot use a cake for that. A cake is for eating, not for playing. Come on, let's clean up this mess. And then, I have a surprise for you."
She takes Ben to the store. She buys him a new drum skin. She helps him fix his drum. She says, "There, now you can play your drum again. And you can make a rhythm with your sticks. But please, be careful. Do not hit it too hard. And do not use a cake again."
Ben is happy. He says, "Thank you, mom. You are the best. I love my new drum skin. And I love you. And I love cake. But not for playing. Only for eating."
He hugs his mom. He plays his drum. He makes a rhythm. He is careful. He does not hit it too hard. He does not use a cake. He waits for his birthday. He hopes his mom will bake him another cake. A cake with a white frosting. A cake that he can eat. And not play.




Lily loved to sing and dance. She wanted to be a musician when she grew up. She liked to listen to different kinds of music and learn new songs.
One day, her mom took her to a park where there was a band playing. Lily was very excited. She ran to the front and watched the musicians with big eyes. They had guitars, drums, keyboards, and microphones. They played loud and fast music that made Lily want to jump and clap.
"Mom, can I talk to them?" Lily asked. "They are so cool!"
"Sure, honey, but be polite and wait for a break," her mom said.
Lily waited patiently until the band finished a song. Then she walked up to the stage and said, "Hi, I'm Lily. I love your music. You are very good musicians. How do you do that?"
The band smiled and thanked her. They were surprised and happy that a little girl liked their music. They asked her if she liked to sing and dance. Lily nodded and said, "Yes, I do. I want to be a musician too."
"That's awesome, Lily. You are very intelligent and brave to follow your dream," one of them said. "Do you want to join us for a song?"
Lily was thrilled. She nodded again and said, "Yes, please!"
The band gave her a microphone and invited her to the stage. They asked her what song she wanted to sing. Lily chose her favorite song, a nursery rhyme that she knew by heart. The band played along and Lily sang with all her heart. The people in the park clapped and cheered for her. Lily felt very happy and proud. She had made new friends and had fun. She hugged the band and thanked them. They told her to keep singing and dancing and to come back anytime.
Lily ran back to her mom and told her everything. Her mom hugged her and said, "I'm so proud of you, Lily. You are a wonderful musician. You made everyone happy with your music."
Lily smiled and said, "Thank you, mom. I love you. And I love music."




Tom and Lily are twins. They like to play in their house. Sometimes they play with their toys, sometimes they play with their dog, and sometimes they play on the stair.
One day, they decide to play on the stair. They take their pillows and blankets and make a fort. They pretend they are in a castle and they are the king and the queen. They enjoy their game very much.
But their mom is working in her room. She needs to be quiet. She does not like the noise that Tom and Lily make on the stair. She tells them to stop and play somewhere else.
Tom and Lily are sad. They do not want to leave their fort. They do not want to make their mom angry. They think of a way to play on the stair and be quiet.
They find some books and crayons. They sit on the stair and read and draw. They whisper to each other and giggle softly. They enjoy their new game too.
Their mom is happy. She can work in her room and be quiet. She is proud of Tom and Lily for being good and creative. She gives them a hug and a kiss and tells them she loves them.




Tom and Sam were brothers. They liked to play with their toys in their room. One day, their mom said they had to sell some of their toys, because they had too many. She gave them a big trunk and told them to put the toys they did not want in it.
Tom and Sam did not like this. They wanted to keep all their toys. They argued and fought over which toys to sell. Tom wanted to sell Sam's cars, and Sam wanted to sell Tom's dinosaurs. They pulled and pushed and shouted at each other.
"Stop it, you two!" their mom said. "You have to share and be nice. If you can't agree, I will choose for you."
Tom and Sam did not want their mom to choose. They decided to work together and find some toys they both did not like. They looked around their room and saw a big teddy bear. It was old and dirty and had a hole in its ear. They did not play with it anymore.
"Let's sell the teddy bear," Tom said.
"Good idea," Sam said. They picked up the teddy bear and put it in the trunk. They closed the lid and dragged the trunk to the front yard. They made a sign that said "Toys for sale".
Soon, some kids came by and looked at the toys. They saw the cars and the dinosaurs and the other toys. They liked them and asked how much they were.
"Five cents each," Tom said.
"Too much," the kids said. They walked away.
Tom and Sam were sad. They wanted to sell their toys and get some money. They waited and waited, but no one came back.
Then, they saw a girl walking by. She had long hair and a pink dress. She saw the trunk and came closer. She opened the lid and saw the teddy bear. She smiled and picked it up.
"Can I have this?" she asked.
"Sure," Tom said. "It's only one cent."
The girl gave Tom a penny and hugged the teddy bear. She said thank you and walked away.
Tom and Sam were happy. They sold their first toy. They looked at the penny and smiled.
But then, they heard a loud cry. It was their mom. She came running to the yard. She saw the girl with the teddy bear and gasped.
"What have you done?" she yelled. "That was my teddy bear! I gave it to you when you were babies. It was very special to me. How could you sell it?"
Tom and Sam were shocked. They did not know the teddy bear was their mom's. They felt very bad. They tried to get the teddy bear back, but the girl was gone. They had lost their mom's teddy bear forever. They were very sorry and very sad. They wished they had not sold it. They wished they had been more careful. They wished they had listened to their mom. They were very clumsy.




Lily and Ben are friends. They like to play at the park. There is a big plastic slide at the park. Lily and Ben want to go on the slide.
They run to the slide and take turns to climb the steps. Lily goes first. She sits on the slide and says, "Whee!" She slides down fast and laughs. Ben waits for his turn. He climbs the steps and sits on the slide. He says, "Whee!" He slides down fast and laughs too.
They do it again and again. They have fun. But then they hear a loud noise. It is a big dog. The dog barks and runs to the slide. Lily and Ben are scared. They do not like the dog. The dog jumps on the slide and slides down. He makes the slide dirty and wet.
Lily and Ben run away from the slide. They find their moms and dads. They tell them about the dog. Their moms and dads hug them and say, "It's okay. The dog is gone. You are safe. Do you want to play something else?"
Lily and Ben nod. They do not want to go on the slide anymore. They want to play with the swings and the sandbox. They hold hands and walk to the other side of the park. They are still friends. They are happy.




Ben was a dog who loved to swim. He liked to splash in the water and chase the fish. One day, he saw a big lake with many ducks. He wanted to swim with them and have fun.
He ran to the lake and jumped in. The ducks were scared and flew away. Ben felt sad. He wanted to make friends, not scare them. He looked around and saw a distant island. He thought maybe there were more ducks there. He decided to swim to the island.
He swam and swam, but the island was very far. He got tired and cold. His paws hurt and his fur was wet. He wished he had stayed on the shore. He was afraid he would not make it to the island or back to the land.
He saw a boat with a man and a girl. They saw him too. They waved and called him. "Poor dog, he is lost and in trouble. Let's help him," the man said. "Yes, let's. He looks so cute and brave," the girl said. They steered the boat to Ben and lifted him up. They wrapped him in a blanket and gave him some food and water.
Ben was happy and grateful. He licked their faces and wagged his tail. He had found new friends. He learned a lesson. He should not swim too far or chase the ducks. He should be careful and respectful. He should be happy with what he had. He thanked the man and the girl and they took him back to the shore. He ran to his home and told his family about his adventure. They were glad he was safe and smart. They hugged him and played with him. Ben was a happy dog who loved to swim.




Sara and Ben were twins who liked to play in the garden. They saw a big bush with red berries on it. Sara wanted to pick some berries, but Ben was scared of the thorns.
"Come on, Ben, the berries are yummy!" Sara said. She was enthusiastic about the berries. She reached for a branch, but it was too high.
"Help me, Ben!" Sara said. "You can support me and I can get the berries."
Ben shook his head. He did not want to support Sara. He thought the bush was prickly and the berries were sour.
"No, Sara, the bush is bad. It will hurt you and the berries will make you sick. Let's go play with the ball instead." Ben said.
Sara was angry with Ben. She wanted the berries very much. She did not want to play with the ball. She tried to climb the bush by herself, but she slipped and fell. She scraped her knee and cried.
Ben heard Sara cry and ran to her. He felt sorry for Sara. He hugged her and said, "I'm sorry, Sara. I should have supported you. Are you okay?"
Sara sniffed and nodded. She hugged Ben back and said, "It's okay, Ben. I should have listened to you. The bush was bad. The berries were not worth it."
Ben smiled and said, "Let's go inside and get a band-aid for your knee. Then we can have some cookies and milk. Maybe we can find some better berries another day."
Sara smiled and said, "Okay, Ben. That sounds good. You are a good brother. I love you."
They held hands and went inside. They were happy again.




Lila and Ben like to play with their toys on the carpet. They have cars, dolls, blocks and books. They make noises and stories with their toys. They have fun.
But sometimes the carpet is dirty. Mom says they have to fold the carpet and put it away. She says the carpet has dust and crumbs and hair. She says they have to clean the floor.
Lila and Ben do not like to fold the carpet. It is big and heavy. They have to lift it and bend it and roll it. They have to work hard. They get tired.
They wish they could keep playing with their toys on the carpet. They do not like to clean the floor. They think it is boring.
But they know Mom is right. They know the carpet is dirty. They know they have to help. They love Mom.
So they fold the carpet and put it away. They sweep the floor and wipe the dust. They make the floor shiny and clean.
Mom is happy. She hugs them and kisses them. She says they are good and helpful. She says they can play with their toys on the carpet again tomorrow. She says she loves them.
Lila and Ben are happy. They hug Mom and kiss her. They say they are sorry for the mess. They say they love her too.
They go to their room and play with their toys on the bed. They make noises and stories with their toys. They have fun.




Lila and Sam were playing in the sand. They liked to pretend they were explorers in the desert. They had a big hat, a water bottle and a map.
"Look, Sam, the map says there is an oasis over there!" Lila said, pointing to a green spot on the paper.
"Let's go and see!" Sam said, excited. They got up and started to walk.
But the sun was very hot and the sand was very dry. They felt thirsty and tired. They wished they had a camel to ride.
"Maybe we should crawl, like snakes," Lila suggested. "It might be cooler and faster."
"OK, let's try," Sam agreed. They dropped to their knees and began to crawl on the sand.
They crawled and crawled, but the oasis seemed very far away. They wondered if it was real or just a picture.
"Are we there yet?" Sam asked, panting.
"I don't know," Lila said, squinting. "I think I see something green."
They crawled a little more, and then they saw it. It was an oasis, a small pool of water with some palm trees and grass. It looked like a paradise.
"Wow, we made it!" Lila exclaimed, smiling.
"Yay, we did it!" Sam cheered, clapping.
They ran to the water and splashed their faces. They drank some water and felt refreshed. They saw some brown dates hanging from the trees and picked some to eat. They felt happy and proud.
They decided to rest under the shade of the palms. They spread their hat on the ground and lay down.
"This is the best adventure ever," Lila said, cuddling with Sam.
"I agree," Sam said, closing his eyes. "You are the best explorer ever."
They fell asleep, dreaming of more adventures.




Tim and Sam were brothers. They liked to play outside in the mud. They had a big red jacket that they shared. They took turns wearing it.
One day, Tim wanted to wear the jacket, but Sam said no. He said it was his turn. They started to fight over the jacket. They pulled and tugged and yelled.
"Stop it!" Mom said. "You are making a mess. Give me the jacket. I will wash it and then you can both wear it."
Tim and Sam did not listen. They kept fighting. They did not see the big hole in the ground. They fell into the hole with the jacket. The hole was full of water. It was very cold and deep.
"Help!" Tim and Sam cried. "We are wet and cold. We can't get out."
Mom heard them. She ran to the hole. She was scared. She tried to reach them, but she could not. She called for help. She hoped someone would come soon.
But no one came. Tim and Sam were stuck in the hole. They were very sad. They wished they had listened to Mom. They wished they had not fought over the jacket. They wished they had been happy.




Lila and Ben are twins. They like to play in the farm with their mom and dad. They see many animals, like cows, sheep, chickens and pigs. The pigs are big and pink. They make loud noises. Lila and Ben think they are funny.
One day, Lila and Ben see a new animal in the farm. It is not big and pink. It is small and brown. It has long hair and sharp teeth. It runs very fast. It is a wild pig. The wild pig is not nice. It scares the other animals. It breaks the fence. It eats the corn.
Lila and Ben are scared too. They run to their mom and dad. They say, "Mom, dad, there is a wild pig in the farm! It is bad! It is mean! Help!" Mom and dad hear them. They see the wild pig. They are not happy. They get a big stick. They chase the wild pig away. They fix the fence. They check the animals.
