"Look, Mia, there are dolphins!" Tom said, pointing to the water. He saw some gray and white shapes jumping and splashing. They were beautiful and fast. Mia smiled and clapped her hands. She loved dolphins.
But the boat did not like the dolphins. It had a big net that it threw into the water. It wanted to catch the dolphins and take them away. The dolphins were scared and tried to swim away. But the net was too big and strong. Some of the dolphins got stuck in the net. They cried and struggled.
"Stop, stop, stop!" Tom shouted at the boat. He was angry and sad. He did not want the boat to hurt the dolphins. He wanted the dolphins to be free and happy. Mia shouted too. She wanted to help the dolphins.
The boat did not hear them. It pulled the net closer and closer. The dolphins were in trouble. They had no way out. They had to surrender. They stopped fighting and waited for the boat to take them.
But then, something amazing happened. A big wave came and hit the boat. It made the boat shake and tilt. The net fell into the water and opened. The dolphins saw their chance. They quickly swam out of the net and away from the boat. They were free again. They thanked the wave and the sea for saving them.
Tom and Mia cheered and clapped. They were so happy for the dolphins. They waved at them and said goodbye. The dolphins waved back and smiled. They were grateful to Tom and Mia for caring about them. They were humble and kind. They hoped to see them again. They jumped and splashed and made a big splash. They were happy.




Anna liked to sort things. She sorted her toys by color, shape and size. She sorted her books by how big they were. She sorted her clothes by how warm they were. She liked to make neat piles and rows of things.
One day, she went to the park with her mom. She saw a man with a big bag of things. He was sorting them on a bench. He had things like hats, gloves, scarves, socks and shoes. He had many colors and patterns. Anna was curious. She walked over to the man and asked, "What are you doing?"
The man smiled and said, "I am sorting these things. I find them in the trash or on the street. I wash them and fix them. Then I give them to people who need them. I am their owner for a little while, but then I share them with others."
Anna thought that was unusual. She had never seen anyone do that before. She asked, "Why do you do that?"
The man said, "Because I like to help people. And because I like to sort things. It makes me happy. Do you like to sort things too?"
Anna nodded and said, "Yes, I do. I sort things at home. Can I help you sort these things?"
The man said, "Sure, you can. You can be my helper. But first, ask your mom if it is okay."
Anna ran back to her mom and told her what the man was doing. Her mom said it was okay, as long as she stayed close and listened to the man. Anna was happy. She went back to the man and helped him sort the things. She learned about different colors and patterns. She also learned about different people and places. She had fun and made a new friend. She thought that was unusual, but also very nice.




Tim and Mia like to play pretend. They have a stage in their room, where they act out stories. One day, they decide to play detectives. They wear hats and coats and have magnifying glasses.
"Let's solve a mystery," Tim says. "We need a clue."
Mia looks around and sees a sock on the floor. "Look, a sock!" she says. "Maybe someone lost it."
"Good clue, Mia," Tim says. "Let's follow it."
They pick up the sock and walk around the room, pretending to look for more clues. They see a shoe, a ball, and a book. They put them on the stage.
"Who do these things belong to?" Tim asks.
Mia thinks hard. She remembers that their brother Ben was playing in their room earlier. She has an idea.
"Maybe Ben is the mystery person," she says. "Let's ask him."
They go to Ben's room and knock on the door. Ben opens it and sees them holding his sock, shoe, ball, and book.
"Hey, those are mine!" he says. "What are you doing with them?"
"We are detectives," Tim says. "We solved the mystery. You left your things in our room."
Ben looks surprised. He takes his things back and says, "Sorry, I forgot to put them away. You are good detectives."
Tim and Mia smile. They are happy they solved the mystery. They go back to their room and play some more. They are not weak. They are smart and brave. They like to solve mysteries.




Lily likes to sing. She sings every day. She sings in the morning, in the afternoon, and at night. She sings when she is happy, when she is sad, and when she is bored. She sings loud and soft, fast and slow, high and low.
Tommy likes to exercise. He exercises every day. He exercises in the morning, in the afternoon, and at night. He exercises when he is happy, when he is sad, and when he is bored. He exercises hard and easy, fast and slow, up and down.
One day, Lily and Tommy are in the same room. Lily wants to sing. Tommy wants to exercise. They both think their thing is great.
"Let me sing!" Lily says.
"Let me exercise!" Tommy says.
They both start to do their thing. Lily sings loud and fast. Tommy exercises hard and fast. They make a lot of noise. They do not hear each other. They do not see each other. They bump into each other.
"Ouch!" Lily says.
"Ow!" Tommy says.
They both stop. They both look at each other. They both feel sorry.
"I'm sorry, Lily. I did not see you. I like your singing. It is great." Tommy says.
"I'm sorry, Tommy. I did not hear you. I like your exercise. It is great." Lily says.
They both smile. They both hug. They both have an idea.
"Let's sing and exercise together!" Lily says.
"Let's exercise and sing together!" Tommy says.
They both agree. They both do their thing. Lily sings soft and slow. Tommy exercises easy and slow. They match their noise. They hear each other. They see each other. They have fun.
They both think their thing is great. They both think their friend is great. They both think their day is great.




Lily and Ben were playing with paper. They liked to fold the paper and make different shapes. Lily made a hat and Ben made a boat.
"Look, I have a hat!" Lily said. She put the hat on her head and smiled.
"That's a nice hat, Lily. Can I try it?" Ben asked.
"OK, but be careful. It is very clean and pretty," Lily said. She gave the hat to Ben and took his boat.
Ben put the hat on his head and Lily held the boat in her hands. They pretended to sail on the water and have a picnic.
"Hello, hello!" a voice said. It was their uncle. He came to visit them and brought some cookies.
"Uncle, uncle!" Lily and Ben shouted. They ran to hug him and show him their paper shapes.
"Wow, you are very good at folding paper. What do you have there?" uncle asked.
"I have a hat and Lily has a boat. We made them ourselves," Ben said.
"They are very clean and pretty. Can I see them?" uncle asked.
"Sure, uncle. Here, you can have the hat and I can have the boat," Ben said. He swapped the paper shapes with uncle and smiled.
"Thank you, Ben. And thank you, Lily. You are very kind and creative. Do you want some cookies?" uncle asked.
"Yes, please!" Lily and Ben said. They took some cookies and ate them with uncle. They were very happy and had a lot of fun.




Lily and Ben are friends. They like to play outside in the sun. One day, they see a big tree with many green leaves. They run to the tree and sit under it.
"This is a good place to play," Lily says. "It is cool and nice here. We are in the shade."
"What is shade?" Ben asks. He does not know this word.
Lily points to the sun and the tree. "Shade is when something blocks the sun. The tree blocks the sun, so we are in the shade. It is not too hot or too bright here."
"Oh, I see," Ben says. He learns a new word. "Shade is good. I like shade."
They hear a noise in the tree. They look up and see a small animal with a bushy tail and a striped face. It is a raccoon. The raccoon looks at them and makes a funny sound.
"What is that?" Ben asks. He does not know this animal.
Lily knows. She has seen a raccoon before. "That is a raccoon. It is a wild animal. It lives in the woods and eats nuts and berries. It is not a pet. We should not touch it."
"Why not?" Ben asks. He is curious.
Lily shakes her head. "Because it is wild. It might bite or scratch us. It might be scared or angry. We should leave it alone."
"OK," Ben says. He learns another word. "Wild is bad. I do not like wild."
They watch the raccoon for a while. Then they decide to play something else. They leave the tree and the raccoon. They have fun and learn new things. They are happy.




Sam and Mia are friends. They like to play in the park. One day, they see a big hill. Sam says, "Let's go up the hill. It looks fun." Mia says, "OK, but be careful. The hill is high."
Sam and Mia hold hands and start to climb the hill. They feel the grass under their feet. The grass is soft and tickly. They like the texture of the grass. They see some flowers and bugs on the way. They stop to look at them and smell them.
They reach the top of the hill. They are happy and proud. They can see the whole park and the sky. The sky is blue and bright. They see some birds and clouds. They wave at them and shout, "Hello!"
Sam says, "This is the best place ever. We are so high. We can see everything." Mia says, "Yes, it is. You are a good leader, Sam. You lead us to the hill." Sam says, "Thank you, Mia. You are a good friend. You follow me to the hill."
They hug and smile. They sit on the hill and enjoy the view. They are happy and high.




Lily and Sam are friends. They like to play in the park. One day, it is rainy and windy. Lily and Sam have umbrellas. They open their umbrellas and run in the park.
The wind is strong. It blows Lily's umbrella away. Lily is sad. She cries. Sam sees Lily's umbrella in a big tree. He wants to help Lily. He is brave. He climbs the tree and gets the umbrella.
Lily is happy. She hugs Sam. She says, "Thank you, Sam. You are my hero. You win the best friend prize." Sam smiles. He says, "You are welcome, Lily. You are my best friend too. Let's go home and have some hot chocolate." They hold their umbrellas and walk home. They are happy.




Tom and Sam were brothers who liked to play in the woods. They had a big ball that they would roll down the hill and chase after. One day, they saw a big axe near a tree. Tom wanted to touch it, but Sam was fearful.
"Tom, don't touch the axe. It is sharp and can hurt you," Sam said.
"But it looks fun. I want to see how it works," Tom said. He did not listen to Sam and picked up the axe. He swung it around and tried to chop the tree.
Sam watched with fear as Tom played with the axe. He saw a big branch above Tom's head. It looked like it was going to fall. Sam shouted, "Tom, watch out! The branch is falling!"
Tom heard Sam and looked up. He saw the branch coming down fast. He dropped the axe and tried to roll away. But he was too late. The branch hit him on the leg and made him cry.
Sam ran to Tom and hugged him. He was sorry for his brother. He said, "Tom, are you okay? I told you not to touch the axe. It is dangerous."
Tom was in pain and felt sorry too. He said, "Sam, you were right. I was foolish. I should have listened to you. I'm sorry."
They learned a lesson that day. They learned to be careful and to listen to each other. They never played with the axe again. They only played with their ball. They were happy and safe.




Lily and Ben are friends. They like to play in the park. One day, they find a big club on the grass. It is brown and heavy.
"Look, a club!" Lily says. "Let's play with it!"
"OK!" Ben says. "What can we do with it?"
Lily thinks for a moment. Then she has an idea. "We can spin it!" she says. "Like this!" She holds the club with both hands and turns around fast. The club makes a whoosh sound in the air.
"Wow, that looks fun!" Ben says. "Can I try?"
"Sure!" Lily says. She gives the club to Ben. Ben tries to spin it, but it is too heavy for him. He falls down and drops the club.
"Ouch!" Ben says. "That hurts!"
Lily laughs. She helps Ben get up. "You are lazy!" she says. "You need to be strong to spin the club!"
Ben makes a face. "I am not lazy!" he says. "I am just small. You are big and strong. That's not fair!"
Lily smiles. She hugs Ben. "Don't be sad," she says. "We can play something else. How about we swing on the swings?"
"OK!" Ben says. "That sounds fun!"
They leave the club on the grass and run to the swings. They swing high and low, and laugh and sing. They are happy. They are friends.




Tom and Mia are friends. They like to play with blocks and cars. One day, they find a big box of blocks in the playroom. They are happy and start to build a network of roads and bridges.
"Look, Mia, I made a long road!" Tom says.
"Wow, Tom, that's good! I made a high bridge!" Mia says.
They play for a while, but then Tom wants to make his road longer. He sees a block that Mia is using for her bridge. He takes it and puts it on his road.
"Hey, Tom, that's my block! Give it back!" Mia says.
"No, Mia, I need it for my road! It's mine now!" Tom says.
Mia is angry. She wants her block back. She tries to pull it from Tom's road, but Tom holds it tight. They start to tug and shout.
"Let go, Mia! It's mine!"
"Let go, Tom! It's mine!"
They tug harder and harder, until the block flies out of their hands. It hits the wall and breaks in two. They both gasp and stop.
"Oh no, the block is broken!" Tom says.
"Oh no, the bridge is ruined!" Mia says.
They look at each other and feel sad. They both like the block and the network. They don't like to fight and break things.
"I'm sorry, Tom. I shouldn't have taken your block," Mia says.
"I'm sorry, Mia. I shouldn't have pulled your block," Tom says.
They hug and say sorry. They decide to share the blocks and fix the network. They are friends again. They are happy.




Sara and Ben were playing in the snow. They made a big snowman with a hat and a scarf. They gave him a carrot nose and two rocks for eyes. They were very happy.
But then, Ben saw that Sara had two mittens and he had only one. He had lost his other mitten somewhere. He felt cold and sad. He said to Sara, "You have two mittens and I have one. That is not fair. Give me your mitten."
Sara did not want to give her mitten to Ben. She said, "No, Ben. These are my mittens. You have to find your mitten. Maybe it is under the snow or behind a tree. Go and look for it."
Ben did not want to look for his mitten. He wanted Sara's mitten. He said, "No, Sara. You are mean. You have to share with me. Give me your mitten or I will tell Mom."
Sara did not like Ben's words. She said, "No, Ben. You are silly. You have to look for your mmean or you will be cold. I will not give you my mitten. You are deaf. You do not listen to me."
Ben and Sara started to argue. They raised their voices and complained to each other. They did not notice that the snowman was watching them. He felt sorry for them. He wished they would stop fighting and be friends. He had an idea. He took off his hat and scarf and gave them to Ben and Sara. He said, "Here, Ben and Sara. You can have my hat and scarf. They will keep you warm. And you can share my carrot nose and rocks. They will make you smile. Please do not complain. Please be nice."
Ben and Sara were surprised. They looked at the snowman. They saw his hat and scarf and his carrot nose and rocks. They felt ashamed. They said, "Thank you, snowman. You are very kind. We are sorry for complaining. We will share your hat and scarf and your carrot nose and rocks. We will be nice."
Ben and Sara put on the hat and scarf and played with the carrot nose and rocks. They gave the snowman a hug and a smile. They were happy again. They learned a lesson. They learned to be grateful and to share. They learned to listen and to be friends.




Lily and Sam were best friends. They liked to play with their bikes in the park. Lily had a pink bike with a basket and a bell. Sam had a blue bike with a pedal and a horn.
One day, they saw a new boy in the park. He had a big bike with a lot of stickers and lights. He rode very fast and made loud noises. He stopped near Lily and Sam and said, "Hi, I'm Max. Do you want to see my bike? It's the best bike in the world!"
Lily and Sam looked at his bike. They thought it was too flashy and noisy. They liked their bikes better. They said, "No, thank you. We're happy with our bikes. They're regular bikes, but they're fun."
Max was angry. He wanted them to admire his bike. He said, "Your bikes are boring and old. You don't know anything about bikes. You're silly and stupid."
Lily and Sam felt hurt by his words. They decided to ignore him. They rode away from him and went to the other side of the park. They played with their bikes and had a good time. They didn't care about Max and his bike. They were still best friends.




Tim and Jen are twins. They like to play in the kitchen. One day, they see a big pan on the stove. It is shiny and round. They want to touch it.
"Come, Jen, let's see what is in the pan," Tim says.
"No, Tim, we should not. Mom said the stove is hot and we can get hurt," Jen says.
But Tim does not listen. He climbs on a chair and reaches for the pan. He does not see the flame under the pan. He grabs the handle and pulls. The pan is very hot. Tim screams and drops the pan. The pan falls on the floor and makes a loud noise. The pan is full of soup. The soup spills everywhere. It is a big mess.
Mom hears the noise and runs to the kitchen. She sees Tim and Jen and the soup and the pan. She is very angry and scared.
"Tim, Jen, what have you done? You could have burned yourself or the house. How could you be so naughty?" Mom says.
Tim and Jen are very ashamed. They know they did a bad thing. They look at Mom and say sorry.
"Sorry, Mom, we were curious. We wanted to see the pan. We did not mean to make a mess," Tim and Jen say.
Mom hugs them and says, "I'm glad you are not hurt, but you have to be careful. The kitchen is not a place to play. You have to listen to me and follow the rules. Do you understand?"
Tim and Jen nod and say, "Yes, Mom, we understand. We will not do it again."
Mom says, "Good. Now help me clean up the soup and the pan. And then we can have some cookies and milk."
Tim and Jen help Mom clean up. They learn their lesson. They are sorry and ashamed, but they are also happy and grateful. They love Mom and Mom loves them.




Ben and Mia are friends. They like to play in the park. There is a big gate in the park. The gate is old and has holes.
One day, Ben and Mia find a ball in the park. They want to play with the ball. They kick the ball and throw the ball. They have fun.
But then, the ball goes to the gate. The ball gets stuck in a hole. Ben and Mia run to the gate. They try to get the ball out. They pull and push. But the ball does not move.
"Help!" Ben says. "Our ball is in the gate!"
Mia has an idea. She sees a stick on the ground. She picks up the stick. She puts the stick in the hole. She pushes the stick hard. The stick tears the hole bigger. The ball falls out.
"Yay!" Mia says. "We got the ball!"
Ben and Mia are happy. They hug each other. They thank the stick. They take the ball and the stick. They go back to play.
The park is calm. The gate is quiet. The hole is bigger. But no one sees.




Ben likes to play with his toy cars. He has many cars of different colors and sizes. He likes to make them zoom and crash on the floor. He also likes to count his cars. He knows how to say one, two, three, four, five, six, seven, eight, nine, and ten.
One day, Ben's mom gives him a new car. It is big and shiny and cool. It has a button on the side. Ben's mom says, "This is a special car, Ben. If you press the button, it will repeat what you say. Do you want to try it?"
Ben nods and presses the button. He says, "Hello, car!" The car says, "Hello, car!" Ben laughs and presses the button again. He says, "I like you, car!" The car says, "I like you, car!" Ben is very happy and hugs the car.
Ben decides to count his cars with the new car. He puts the car on the table and points to his other cars. He says, "One, two, three, four, five, six, seven, eight, nine, ten." The car says, "One, two, three, four, five, six, seven, eight, nine, ten." Ben claps and says, "Good job, car!"
Then, Ben sees a circle on the car's door. He wonders what it is. He asks the car, "What is this, car?" The car says, "What is this, car?" Ben says, "This is a circle, car." The car says, "This is a circle, car." Ben says, "No, no, car. This is not a circle. This is a zero. Do you know what a zero is, car?" The car says, "Do you know what a zero is, car?" Ben says, "A zero is nothing, car. It means you have no cars. Like this." He takes away all his other cars and leaves only the new car on the table. He says, "Zero cars, car." The car says, "Zero cars, car."
Ben thinks this is funny and laughs. He says, "Zero cars, car. Zero cars, car. Zero cars, car." He repeats it over and over. The car repeats it over and over. Ben's mom hears the noise and comes to see what is going on. She sees Ben and the car saying, "Zero cars, car. Zero cars, car. Zero cars, car." She says, "Ben, what are you doing? Where are your other cars?"
Ben looks at his mom and says, "Zero cars, car. Zero cars, car. Zero cars, car." The car says, "Zero cars, car. Zero cars, car. Zero cars, car." Ben's mom says, "Oh, no, Ben. You have to stop that. You have to share your cars with the car. The car is your friend, not your zero. Come on, let's put your cars back on the floor and play nicely."
Ben says, "Okay, mom. I'm sorry, car. You are not my zero. You are my cool car. I will share my cars with you. Come on, let's play." The car says, "Okay, mom. I'm sorry, car. You are not my zero. You are my cool car. I will share my cars with you. Come on, let's play." Ben and the car smile and play with the other cars. Ben's mom smiles and watches them. She thinks, "That was a close one. I hope Ben learned his lesson. I wonder what else the car can repeat."




Lily was a little girl who liked to mail letters to her friends. She had many stickers and crayons to make her letters pretty. One day, she found a big spider in her room. She was scared of the spider and wanted to get rid of it. She had an idea. She put the spider in a box and wrote a letter to her friend Tom. She said, "Hi Tom, I have a surprise for you. Open the box and see. Love, Lily."
She took the box and the letter to the mailman. He smiled and said, "What a nice letter, Lily. I'm sure Tom will be happy to get it." He put the box and the letter in his bag and drove away.
Tom was excited when he saw the letter from Lily. He liked Lily and wanted to be her friend. He opened the letter and read it. He wondered what the surprise was. He opened the box and saw the spider. He screamed and threw the box away. The spider crawled out and bit him on the hand. It hurt a lot and his hand swelled up. He ran to his mom and cried. She took him to the doctor and he got a shot. He was very angry at Lily and never wanted to talk to her again.
Lily did a bad thing. She was mean to Tom and the spider. She hurt them both and lost a friend. She learned that you should not mail spiders to people. You should mail nice things, like flowers or cards or cookies. You should be kind and gentle to animals, even if you are afraid of them. They have feelings too and can be mighty. You should treat others the way you want to be treated. That is the golden rule.




Lily and Sam were playing with crayons. They liked to draw and color on paper. Lily had a red crayon and Sam had a blue one. They were having fun.
But then Sam wanted to use the red crayon too. He tried to take it from Lily's hand. Lily did not like that. She said, "No, Sam, this is my crayon. You have your own crayon. Go away!"
Sam did not listen. He pulled harder on the red crayon. Lily pulled back. They both started to yell. "Stop, stop, stop!" they said.
Mom heard the noise. She came to see what was wrong. She saw Lily and Sam fighting over the crayon. She was angry. She said, "Lily and Sam, what are you doing? You are not being nice to each other. You are not sharing. You are making a mess. Stop it right now!"
Lily and Sam stopped. They looked at Mom. They felt sorry. They said, "Sorry, Mom. We were being bad. We will share. We will be good."
Mom smiled. She said, "That's better. I'm glad you are sorry. Now, why don't you draw a picture together? You can use both crayons. You can make a new color. What color do you get when you mix red and blue?"
Lily and Sam thought for a moment. Then they said, "Purple!"
Mom said, "That's right. Purple is a beautiful color. Why don't you draw a purple flower? Or a purple butterfly? Or a purple anything you like?"
Lily and Sam nodded. They took the crayons and the paper. They started to draw and color. They were happy. They said, "Thank you, Mom. We love you. We love purple."




Tom and Lily were hungry. They wanted to eat lunch. They looked in the fridge. They saw a bowl of salad. It had lettuce, tomatoes, cheese and eggs.
"Can we have salad, Mom?" Tom asked.
"Sure, honey. But be careful. Some of the salad is old. It might rot. Rot means bad and yucky. You don't want to eat rot salad. It will make you sick." Mom said.
"How do we know which salad is rot and which is not?" Lily asked.
"Look at the color and the smell. If the salad is brown or green or smells funny, it is rot. If the salad is fresh and crisp and smells good, it is not rot. You can also ask me if you are not sure." Mom said.
Tom and Lily took some salad from the bowl. They checked the color and the smell. They found some good salad and some rot salad. They put the good salad on their plates and threw the rot salad in the trash.
"Mom, can we have some dressing for the salad?" Tom asked.
"Of course, dear. What kind of dressing do you like?" Mom asked.
"I like ranch dressing. It is creamy and yummy." Tom said.
"I like honey mustard dressing. It is sweet and tangy." Lily said.
Mom smiled. She was generous. She gave Tom and Lily some dressing for their salad. They poured the dressing on their salad and mixed it well. They ate their salad and enjoyed it.
"Thank you, Mom. The salad was delicious." Tom and Lily said.
"You're welcome, my loves. I'm glad you liked it. And I'm proud of you for being smart and careful with the salad. You don't want to eat rot food. It is bad for you." Mom said.
They hugged Mom and gave her a kiss. They were happy and full. They cleaned their plates and put them in the sink. They went to play with their toys. They had a good lunch.




Lila and Ben are friends. They like to play in the park. One day, they see a big house near the park. It has many windows and a big door. Lila says, "Who lives in that house?"
Ben says, "I don't know. Maybe someone wealthy. Wealthy means they have a lot of things and money."
Lila says, "I want to see what they have. Maybe they have toys and books and candy. Can we go inside?"
Ben says, "No, we can't. That is not our house. We can't take things that are not ours. That is wrong."
Lila says, "But I'm curious. Maybe they have something interesting. Maybe they have history. History means things that happened a long time ago."
Ben says, "History is not a thing you can take. History is a story you can learn. You can learn history from books or from people who know. But you can't take history from someone else's house. That is rude."
Lila says, "Oh, I see. You are right. History is not a thing you can take. History is a story you can learn. Maybe we can ask someone who lives in that house to tell us their history. Maybe they will be nice and share."
Ben says, "Maybe. But we have to be polite and ask first. We can't just go inside. We have to knock on the door and say hello. And we have to say thank you and goodbye. And we have to listen and not touch anything. Do you understand?"
Lila says, "Yes, I understand. Let's go and knock on the door and say hello. Maybe we will learn something new. Maybe we will make a new friend."




Tom is a cat. He has a long tail. He likes to play with his tail. He chases it and bites it. He thinks it is fun.
One day, Tom sees a mouse. The mouse has a long tail too. Tom wants to catch the mouse. He runs after the mouse. The mouse runs into a hole. Tom follows the mouse.
"Come out, come out, little mouse!" Tom says. "I want to play with you and your tail!"
But the mouse does not come out. The mouse is scared of Tom. The mouse knows Tom does not want to play. Tom wants to eat him.
Tom sticks his head into the hole. He tries to find the mouse. He does not see the mouse. He only sees darkness. He feels something move. He thinks it is the mouse. He bites it.
But it is not the mouse. It is a snake. The snake has a long tail too. The snake is angry. The snake bites Tom back.
Tom screams. He pulls his head out of the hole. He feels pain. He sees blood. He sees the snake. The snake hisses at him.
Tom runs away. He is hurt. He is sad. He does not want to play with his tail anymore. He does not want to play with any tail anymore. He learned a hard lesson. He should not search for trouble.




Lily and Ben were playing in the kitchen. They wanted to make a cake for Mom. They had a big bowl, some flour, some eggs, some milk and some sugar. They also had a spoon to stir the batter.
"Let me stir, Lily!" Ben said. He grabbed the spoon from Lily's hand.
"No, Ben, it's my turn!" Lily said. She pulled the spoon back.
They both tugged on the spoon, making the batter splash out of the bowl. Some of it landed on the fan that was on the counter. The fan was on, so it blew the batter all over the kitchen.
"Oh no!" Lily and Ben said. They saw the mess they made. They saw Mom coming into the kitchen.
"What are you two doing?" Mom asked. She looked at the batter on the walls, the floor, the fan and her children.
"We wanted to make a cake for you, Mom," Lily said.
"But we had a fight over the spoon," Ben said.
Mom sighed. She was not happy. She turned off the fan and got a cloth to clean the kitchen.
"Next time, you have to share and take turns," Mom said. "And ask me before you use the kitchen."
Lily and Ben felt sorry. They hugged Mom and said they were sorry.
"It's okay, sweeties," Mom said. "I love you both. And I appreciate your jolly idea. But maybe we can make a cake together another day."
Lily and Ben nodded. They helped Mom clean the kitchen. They learned their lesson. They decided to make a card for Mom instead of a cake. They used crayons and stickers and wrote "We love you, Mom" on it. Mom smiled when she saw the card. She gave them a big hug and a kiss. She said they were the best children ever.




Lily and Ben were hungry. They wanted to eat lunch. But Mom said they had to wait. She was making a tasty thing in the oven.
"What is it, Mom?" Lily asked.
"It's a surprise, sweetie. You'll see soon," Mom said.
Lily and Ben looked at the oven. They smelled something good. They heard a beep.
"Is it ready, Mom?" Ben asked.
"Not yet, honey. The oven says we have to delay a little more. It needs more time to cook," Mom said.
Lily and Ben sighed. They were very hungry. They went to the living room. They played with their toys. They tried to forget about the tasty thing.
But they could not. They kept looking at the clock. They kept hearing the oven. They kept smelling the food.
Finally, Mom called them. "Lunch is ready, kids! Come and see what I made!"
Lily and Ben ran to the kitchen. They saw a big thing on the table. It was round and brown and cheesy. It had slices of tomato and ham on top.
"It's a pizza!" Lily and Ben shouted.
"Yes, it is! I made it for you. Do you like it?" Mom asked.
"We love it, Mom! Thank you!" Lily and Ben said.
They sat down and ate the pizza. It was very tasty. They forgot about the delay. They were happy.




Ben and Lily are twins. They like to play outside with their dog, Spot. One day, they go to the park with Mom. There is a big pond in the park. Ben and Lily want to see the pond.
They run to the pond with Spot. They see ducks and fish in the water. They see frogs and bugs on the grass. They hear birds and bees in the air. They are happy and curious.
But then, Spot sees a big goose. The goose is angry and loud. It flaps its wings and hisses at Spot. Spot is fearful and barks at the goose. Ben and Lily are fearful too. They do not like the goose.
Mom hears the noise and comes to the pond. She sees the goose and Spot. She calls Spot and holds him. She tells Ben and Lily to stay away from the goose. She says the goose is not nice and can hurt them.
Ben and Lily nod and hug Mom. They are glad Mom is here. They do not want to play near the pond anymore. They want to go to the swings and the slide. They say bye to the ducks and the fish and the frogs and the bugs. They say bye to the birds and the bees. They do not say bye to the goose. They are still fearful of the goose.




Lily and Ben are twins. They like to play in the water. One day, they go to the lake with Mom and Dad. Mom and Dad have a big kayak. They let Lily and Ben sit in the kayak with them.
"Look, Lily, we are on the water!" Ben says. He sees a fish jump out of the water. He points at the fish. "Splash! Splash!"
Lily laughs. She sees a duck swim by. She waves at the duck. "Quack! Quack!"
Mom and Dad paddle the kayak. They show Lily and Ben the trees and the flowers on the shore. They sing a song. Lily and Ben sing along.
Suddenly, the kayak hits a rock. The kayak tips over. Lily and Ben fall into the water. They are scared. They cry.
Mom and Dad are quick. They grab Lily and Ben and pull them to the kayak. They flip the kayak over. They help Lily and Ben get back in the kayak. They hug them and dry them with a towel.
"It's okay, Lily and Ben. You are safe. We are here." Mom says.
"Sorry, Mom and Dad. We did not mean to make the kayak fall." Lily says.
"It's not your fault, Lily and Ben. It was an accident. You did well. You stayed close to us. You were brave." Dad says.
Lily and Ben smile. They are happy. They are not scared anymore. They thank Mom and Dad for being helpful. They hug them and say they love them.
Mom and Dad smile too. They love Lily and Ben. They say they are proud of them. They paddle the kayak back to the shore. They have a picnic. They eat sandwiches and cookies. They drink juice. They have fun. They are a happy family.




Sara and Ben liked to play near the pond. The pond had many fish and frogs and ducks. Sara and Ben liked to watch them swim and jump and quack. Sometimes they threw bread for the ducks and they came closer.
One day, Sara and Ben saw a bright yellow duckling in the pond. It was very small and fluffy and cute. Sara and Ben wanted to pet it and hold it. They went to the edge of the pond and called the duckling.
"Come here, little duckling, we want to be your friends," Sara said.
"Quack, quack," the duckling said and swam towards them.
Sara and Ben reached out their hands and gently touched the duckling. It felt soft and warm. The duckling liked Sara and Ben and nuzzled their fingers.
"Can we take it home, please?" Sara asked.
"No, we can't," Ben said. "The duckling belongs to the pond. It has a family here. See, there is its mother and its brothers and sisters. They are looking for it."
Sara and Ben looked and saw a big white duck and four other yellow ducklings swimming in the pond. They were quacking loudly and looking for the missing duckling.
"You're right, Ben," Sara said. "The duckling belongs to the pond. We should let it go."
Sara and Ben gently put the duckling back in the water. The duckling swam to its mother and siblings and they all quacked happily. The mother duck thanked Sara and Ben with a nod and a wink.
"Bye, little duckling, we hope to see you again," Sara and Ben said.
They waved to the duckling and went back to their house. They felt happy that they had made a new friend and that they had done the right thing.




Lily and Tom like to play in the park. They like to swing on the big swings. They go up and down, up and down. They feel happy and free.
One day, they see a goat in the park. The goat is thin and hungry. It has no grass to eat. It sees the swings and thinks they are food. It runs to the swings and starts to bite them.
"Hey, stop that!" Lily shouts. "That is our swing, not your food!"
The goat does not listen. It keeps biting the swing. It makes a big hole in it.
"Go away, goat!" Tom yells. "You are ruining our fun!"
The goat does not care. It moves to the next swing and bites it too.
Lily and Tom are angry and sad. They love their swings. They do not want the goat to destroy them. They look for help.
They see a man with a hat and a rope. He is the goat's owner. He is looking for his goat.
"Sir, sir!" Lily and Tom call. "Your goat is here! Your goat is eating our swings!"
The man sees his goat and runs to it. He throws the rope around its neck and pulls it away.
"I'm sorry, kids," he says. "My goat is very naughty. He escaped from his pen. He is always looking for something to eat. I will take him home and give him some hay."
Lily and Tom are glad. They hope the man will keep his goat away from the park. They look at their swings. They are broken and torn.
They feel sad. They cannot swing anymore. They decide to play something else. They hope someone will fix their swings soon. They still like to swing on the big swings.




Tim and Lily are twins. They like to play with their toys. But sometimes they fight over the same toy. One day, they both want to play with the red car.
"Give me the car!" Tim says. He tries to pull the car from Lily's hand.
"No, it's mine!" Lily says. She holds the car tight.
They tug and tug. The car breaks in two. Tim and Lily both cry.
Mom hears them and comes to see what is wrong. She sees the broken car and the sad twins.
"Oh, no! What happened?" Mom asks.
"We both wanted the car. It was a bad fight. Now the car is gone." Tim says.
"I'm sorry, Mom. We were not nice to each other." Lily says.
Mom hugs them both. She says, "I'm sorry, too. The car was a gift from Grandma. But you know what? You can gain something better than a toy. You can gain love and forgiveness. Can you say sorry to each other and hug?"
Tim and Lily look at each other. They feel sorry for what they did. They say sorry and hug.
Mom smiles. She says, "That's good. I love you both. Now, let's see if we can fix the car together."




Ben likes math. He likes to count and add and take away. He has a math book with many pages. He likes to turn the pages and see the pictures and numbers.
One day, Ben finds a new page in his math book. It is a page with a big hairy monster. The monster has four eyes and six legs and ten teeth. The monster says, "Hello, Ben. Do you want to play math with me?"
Ben is scared. He does not like the monster. He wants to turn the page and see something else. But the monster says, "No, Ben. You cannot turn the page. You have to play math with me. If you answer my math questions, I will let you go. If you answer wrong, I will eat you."
Ben does not know what to do. He thinks hard. He remembers what his mom and dad taught him about math. He decides to try and answer the monster's questions.
The monster asks, "How much is two plus two?" Ben says, "Four." The monster says, "Good. How much is three minus one?" Ben says, "Two." The monster says, "Good. How much is four times two?" Ben says, "Eight." The monster says, "Good. You are smart, Ben. I will not eat you. You can turn the page now."
Ben is happy. He turns the page and sees a picture of a rainbow and a butterfly. He says, "Bye, monster. Thank you for playing math with me." The monster says, "Bye, Ben. You are welcome. You are brave and clever. Maybe we can play math again someday." Ben smiles and says, "Maybe." He closes his math book and hugs it. He likes math. He likes to turn the pages and see the pictures and numbers. He likes to learn new things. He is not afraid of monsters. He is a math hero.




Ben likes to ride his bike. He has a red bike with two big wheels and a handle. He can balance on his bike and go fast. He likes to go to the park with his bike and play with his friends.
One day, he sees a new bike in the park. It is a blue bike with one big wheel and one small wheel. It has no handle. It is a unicycle. Ben thinks it looks fun. He wants to try it.
He asks the boy who has the unicycle if he can ride it. The boy says yes. He helps Ben get on the unicycle. Ben tries to balance on the unicycle, but it is hard. He falls off. He tries again. He falls off again. He tries many times, but he cannot balance on the unicycle.
Ben feels sad. He thinks he is bad at riding the unicycle. He thinks the boy will laugh at him. He thinks his friends will not like him. He thinks the unicycle is not fun.
But the boy does not laugh at him. He says, "Don't worry, Ben. Riding a unicycle is hard. I had to practice a lot to learn how to balance on it. You are good at riding your bike. Your bike is cool. Do you want to swap bikes for a while? I can show you how to ride your bike with one hand. It is fun."
Ben smiles. He says, "Yes, please. Thank you for letting me try your unicycle. It is cool, too. Maybe I can learn how to ride it someday. You are very good at it. You are popular. Do you want to be my friend?"
The boy smiles, too. He says, "Yes, I do. My name is Sam. What is yours?"
Ben says, "My name is Ben. Nice to meet you, Sam. Let's swap bikes and play together."
They swap bikes and play together. They have fun. They balance on their bikes and do tricks. They make new friends. They are happy.




Lily and her mom went to the park. Lily liked to play on the swings and the slide. Mom liked to sit on the bench and read a book. She had a big purse with many things inside.
One day, it started to rain. Lily and mom ran to the bench to get the purse. But the purse was not there. Someone had taken it. Mom was very sad and angry. She said, "Where is my purse? Who took my purse?"
Lily saw a friendly dog near the trees. The dog had something in its mouth. It was the purse. The dog had found it and wanted to play with it. The dog ran to Lily and mom and wagged its tail. It dropped the purse on the ground.
Mom picked up the purse. It was very wet and dirty. The dog had soaked it with its saliva. Mom said, "Oh, no! My purse is ruined. Look at this mess."
Lily petted the dog. She said, "Don't be mad, mom. The dog is nice. He did not know. He just wanted to have fun. Can we keep him?"
Mom looked at Lily and the dog. She smiled a little. She said, "Well, he is a friendly dog. And he did bring back my purse. Maybe we can give him a bath and a name. What do you think?"
Lily hugged the dog. She said, "I think he is a good dog. I want to call him Spot. Can we, mom? Please?"
Mom nodded. She said, "OK, Lily. We can keep Spot. But first, let's go home and dry off. And clean my purse."




Lila and Ben are playing in the kitchen. They have a big bowl, a spoon, and some cups. They want to make a treat for Mom and Dad.
"What do we need?" Lila asks.
"We need milk and cereal," Ben says. "And some honey."
They find the milk and cereal in the fridge and the honey in the cupboard. They pour some milk into the bowl. Then they pour some cereal on top. They stir with the spoon.
"Can I have some honey?" Lila asks.
"Sure," Ben says. He pours some honey on Lila's cereal. "But not too much. Mom and Dad don't like it too sweet."
They fill their cups with the cereal mix. They carry them to the living room. They see Mom and Dad on the couch. They are reading a book.
"Look what we made for you!" Lila and Ben say.
Mom and Dad smile. They put down their book. They take the cups from Lila and Ben.
"Thank you, sweeties," Mom says. "This looks like a yummy treat."
They taste the cereal. They make a happy sound.
"Mmm, this is good," Dad says. "You are very good cooks."
Lila and Ben beam. They sit next to Mom and Dad. They share their treat. They feel warm and light. They love their family.




Ben and Sam were brothers. They liked to play with their toy cars and trucks. One day, they decided to measure how far their cars could go. They used a long tape that their dad had. They put the tape on the floor and marked the end with a crayon.
"Ready, set, go!" Ben said. He pushed his red car as hard as he could. It zoomed along the tape and stopped at the crayon. "Wow, that's far!" Ben said. He looked at the tape and saw the number 10.
"My turn!" Sam said. He pushed his blue car with all his might. It went faster than Ben's car and passed the crayon. "Ha, I win!" Sam said. He looked at the tape and saw the number 12.
"No fair!" Ben said. He was angry. He grabbed Sam's car and threw it across the room. It hit the wall and broke into pieces.
"Hey, that's my car!" Sam said. He was sad. He ran to his car and tried to put it back together. But it was too late. The car was ruined.
"Mom!" Sam cried. He ran to their mom, who was in the kitchen. He showed her his broken car and told her what Ben did.
Mom was not happy. She scolded Ben and told him to say sorry to Sam. She also told him to go to his room and think about what he did. Ben felt bad. He wished he didn't throw Sam's car.
Mom hugged Sam and told him she was sorry. She said she would buy him a new car. She also said they had to go to the hospital soon. She said their grandpa was very old and sick. He needed to see a doctor.
Sam and Ben loved their grandpa. He always told them stories and gave them candy. They wanted him to get better. They forgot about their fight and hugged each other. They said they were sorry and that they loved each other. They went to get ready to go to the hospital. They hoped their grandpa would be okay.




Lily and Max were playing with their toys in the yard. Lily had a doll and Max had a truck. Max liked to make loud noises with his truck and pretend it was driving on the grass. Lily liked to imagine that her doll was a princess and talk to her softly.
"Vroom, vroom, beep, beep!" Max shouted, as he moved his truck closer to Lily and her doll. "Move out of the way, princess! My truck is faster and stronger than you!"
"Stop it, Max!" Lily said, as she hugged her doll. "You are being mean and ignorant. You don't know anything about princesses. They are kind and smart and beautiful. And they don't like noisy trucks!"
"Ha, ha, ha!" Max laughed, as he pushed his truck into Lily and her doll. "You are silly and boring, Lily. You don't know anything about trucks. They are fun and powerful and cool. And they don't care about stupid dolls!"
Lily and Max started to argue and fight. They did not listen to each other or share their toys. They did not have fun or learn anything new.
Mom heard the noise and came to the yard. She saw Lily and Max crying and angry. She saw the doll and the truck on the ground. She was not happy.
"What is going on here?" Mom asked, as she picked up the doll and the truck. "Why are you fighting over your toys? Why are you not playing nicely?"
Lily and Max tried to explain, but they only blamed each other. They said that the other one was ignorant and did not understand their toys.
Mom shook her head and sighed. She sat down with Lily and Max and gave them back their toys. She looked at them with love and said:
"Lily and Max, you are both wrong. You are not ignorant, but you are acting like it. You are not respecting each other or your toys. You are missing a chance to imagine and explore together. You can learn from each other and have more fun if you share your toys and your ideas. Do you understand?"
Lily and Max nodded and felt sorry. They said sorry to each other and hugged. They decided to try to play together and imagine new things. They asked Mom to join them and tell them stories about princesses and trucks. They smiled and laughed and had fun. They were not ignorant anymore.




Lily and Max were twins who liked to play in the garden. They had many toys, but their favorite was a big ball that looked like the earth. They liked to roll it, bounce it, and pretend they were flying around the world.
One day, they had a big fight over the ball. Lily wanted to play with it first, but Max said he had it first. They both pulled and pushed the ball, and shouted at each other. They were not polite at all.
Their mom heard the noise and came to see what was wrong. She saw the twins fighting over the ball, and was not happy. She said they had to choose: either they share the ball nicely, or they lose the ball for the rest of the day. She said she would count to three, and then take the ball away.
Lily and Max looked at each other, and then at the ball. They both loved the ball, and did not want to lose it. They remembered how much fun they had playing with it together, and how big and beautiful the earth was. They decided to be polite and share the ball.
They said sorry to each other, and gave each other a hug. They said thank you to their mom, and took turns playing with the ball. They had a lot of fun, and learned to be kind and fair. Their mom was proud of them, and gave them a big smile. She said they had made a good choice.




Lily liked to bake with her mom. They made cakes and pies and cookies. Lily liked to eat them too. She liked to lick the spoon and the bowl. Mom said baking was fun and yummy.
One day, Lily wanted to bake with mom, but mom was busy. Mom had to work on her laptop. She said she had a lot of things to do. Lily was sad and bored. She looked for something to do. She saw the hose in the yard. She had an idea.
Lily took the hose and turned it on. She sprayed water everywhere. She sprayed the flowers and the grass and the car. She sprayed the dog and the cat and the bird. She sprayed the window and the door and the wall. She laughed and giggled. She thought it was fun and funny.
But mom did not think it was fun or funny. Mom saw the water and the mess. She heard the dog and the cat and the bird. She saw Lily with the hose. She was angry and upset. She ran outside and took the hose from Lily. She turned it off and scolded Lily. She said Lily was naughty and bad. She said Lily had to clean up and say sorry.
Lily was scared and sorry. She did not mean to make mom angry or upset. She did not mean to make a mess. She just wanted to have fun. She cried and hugged mom. She said she was sorry and she loved mom. Mom hugged Lily back. She said she was sorry too and she loved Lily. She said Lily had to be careful and normal. She said they could bake together later. Lily smiled and nodded. She helped mom clean up. She hoped they could make cookies. She liked cookies.




Ben and Mia are twins. They like to play with their stuff. They have many toys, books, and games. But they do not like to share. They always want the same stuff.
One day, they find a big box in their room. It has a label that says "Match and Learn". Inside the box, there are many cards with pictures and words. The cards are in pairs. The twins want to play with the cards.
"Let me have this card!" Ben says. He grabs a card with a picture of a dog.
"No, I want it!" Mia says. She pulls the card from Ben's hand.
"It is mine!" Ben says. He pushes Mia.
"Ow!" Mia says. She cries.
Mom hears the noise. She comes to the room. She sees the twins fighting over the cards.
"What is going on here?" Mom says. She is not happy.
"Ben is spoiled!" Mia says. "He took my card!"
"Mia is spoiled!" Ben says. "She wanted my card!"
Mom shakes her head. She picks up the box. She reads the label.
"These cards are for matching and learning," Mom says. "You have to find the card that matches the picture or the word. Then you can learn something new. But you have to play nicely and share. Do you understand?"
The twins nod. They feel sorry.
"Can we try again?" Ben says.
"Yes, please," Mia says.
Mom smiles. She gives them the cards. She helps them to match and learn. The twins have fun. They share their stuff. They are not spoiled. They are happy.




Lily and Max were best friends. They liked to play with toys, sing songs and eat snacks. One day, they found a big box in the basement. They opened it and saw many clothes and hats and shoes.
"Wow, look at this!" Lily said. She took out a long white dress and a shiny crown. "I want to be a princess!"
"And I want to be a king!" Max said. He put on a red coat and a golden top. He thought he looked very attractive.
They pretended to live in a castle and have a party. They danced and laughed and had fun. Then Max had an idea.
"Lily, do you want to marry me?" he asked. He gave her a ring made of paper.
Lily smiled and nodded. "Yes, Max, I want to marry you!" she said. She put the ring on her finger.
They hugged and kissed and said "I love you". They were very happy. They did not know that their moms were watching them from the door. They smiled and took pictures of their cute kids.




Lily and Max were playing in the backyard. They had many toys and books and clothes. They made a big mess. Mommy came and said, "It is time to organize your things. Put them in the right places."
Lily and Max did not want to organize. They wanted to play more. They said, "No, Mommy, we are having fun. We do not want to organize."
Mommy said, "If you do not organize, you will lose your things. And some of them are fragile. They can break easily. Like this umbrella. It is fragile. It can rip or bend. You have to be careful with it."
Lily and Max looked at the umbrella. It was pink and purple and had flowers on it. It was Lily's favorite umbrella. She did not want it to break. She said, "Okay, Mommy, we will organize. I will put the umbrella in the closet. Where should I put the other things?"
Mommy smiled and said, "You are a good girl, Lily. You can put the books on the shelf, the toys in the box, and the clothes in the drawer. And Max, you can help Lily. You can be a good boy, too."
Lily and Max nodded and started to organize. They put the things in the right places. They were careful with the fragile things. They worked together. They made the backyard neat and tidy. Mommy was proud of them. She said, "You did a great job, Lily and Max. You are very smart and helpful. Now you can play again. But remember to organize when you are done."
Lily and Max hugged Mommy and said, "Thank you, Mommy. We love you. We will remember to organize." They ran to the swing and the slide. They had more fun. They were happy.




Anna and Ben are friends who like to play at the park. They both love to swing on the swings, but they also like to win. They are very competitive and always try to swing higher and faster than each other.
One day, they decide to have a swing contest. They ask their mom to help them. Mom brings some tape and a marker. She tapes a line on the swing pole and marks it with the marker. She says, "This is the highest point. Whoever swings and touches the line first is the winner."
Anna and Ben get on their swings and start to pump their legs. They swing back and forth, higher and higher. They look at each other and smile. They want to touch the line and be the winner.
"Look at me, I'm almost there!" Anna shouts.
"No, I'm closer, watch me!" Ben replies.
They swing harder and harder, but they are both very good. They are almost at the same height. They stretch their arms and try to touch the line.
Suddenly, they hear a snap. The tape breaks and falls to the ground. Anna and Ben stop swinging and look at the tape. They look at each other and start to laugh.
"Oops, we broke the tape!" Anna says.
"That was too much fun!" Ben says.
They get off their swings and hug each other. They are still friends and still love to swing. They don't care who is the winner. They just want to have fun.




Tim and Lily were playing with their toy cars and trucks in the living room. They liked to pretend they were drivers who had to deliver things to different places. Tim had a red truck and Lily had a blue car.
"Beep beep, I have a big box for you," Tim said, driving his truck to Lily's car. "What is in it?"
Lily opened the box and smiled. "It is a cake for my birthday! Thank you, Tim. You are a good driver."
They decided to share the cake and have a pretend party. They put the cake on a small table and got some plates and forks. But before they could cut the cake, they heard a loud noise.
"Ruff ruff, what is that?" Lily asked, looking around.
It was their dog, Max, who had smelled the cake and wanted some too. He ran into the living room and jumped on the table, knocking over the cake. The cake fell on the floor and broke into pieces. Max licked his lips and ate some of the cake.
"Max, no!" Tim and Lily shouted. "That is our cake!"
They tried to stop Max, but he was too fast and too big. He ate all of the cake and left only some crumbs. Tim and Lily were sad and angry. They looked at the empty box and the messy floor.
"That was a bad turn," Tim said. "Now we have no cake for our party."
Lily nodded. "And Max has a brown face from the chocolate. He is a bad dog."
They decided to tell their mom what happened and ask for another cake. They hoped she would not be too mad and that Max would not get sick. They learned that they should not leave their cake alone with a hungry dog.




Lily liked to play with her mom's makeup. She wanted to look like a princess. She took the lipstick, the eyeshadow, and the blush from the drawer and put them on her face. She looked in the mirror and smiled. She thought she was very pretty.
She went to show her mom what she had done. Her mom was in the kitchen, making cookies. When she saw Lily, she was surprised. She said, "Lily, what did you do to your face? You look like a clown!"
Lily felt sad. She did not want to look like a clown. She wanted to look like a princess. She said, "I'm sorry, mom. I wanted to play with your makeup. I wanted to be like you."
Her mom hugged her and said, "Lily, you don't need makeup to be like me. You are beautiful just the way you are. Makeup is for grown-ups, not for little girls. And makeup does not change who you are inside. You are my sweet and humble daughter, and I love you very much."
Lily hugged her mom back and said, "I love you too, mom. Can I help you make cookies?"
Her mom said, "Of course, you can. But first, let's go wash your face. You will look much better without makeup."




Tom and Lily are friends. They like to play with toys and books. One day, Tom has a new sock. It is orange and has a picture of a lion on it.
"Look, Lily, I have a new sock!" Tom says. He shows Lily his foot. "It is orange and has a lion. Do you like it?"
Lily nods. She likes Tom's sock. It is bright and fun. She wants to see the lion better.
"Can I touch your sock, Tom?" Lily asks. She reaches for Tom's foot.
Tom smiles. He likes to share with Lily. He lifts his foot and lets Lily touch his sock.
"Wow, your sock is soft and warm," Lily says. She feels the lion's mane and nose. "And the lion is cute. Can I have a sock like this, too?"
Tom thinks. He has another orange sock in his drawer. He does not need two orange socks. He has an idea.
"Wait here, Lily," Tom says. He runs to his room and gets his other orange sock. He comes back and gives it to Lily.
"Here, Lily, you can have this sock," Tom says. "Now we both have orange socks with lions. We are twins!"
Lily is very happy. She hugs Tom and puts on the sock. She shows Tom her foot.
"Thank you, Tom, you are very nice," Lily says. "I love my new sock. And I love you, too!"
Tom and Lily hug again. They are happy. They have orange socks with lions. And they have each other. They are the best friends.




Lily and Ben were playing with crayons. They liked to draw on paper, but sometimes they also drew on other things. Lily saw a white shirt on the sofa. She thought it was boring. She wanted to make it more fun.
She took a red crayon and started to mark on the shirt. She made big circles and lines and dots. She smiled and said, "Look, Ben, I made a pretty shirt!"
Ben looked at the shirt and frowned. He knew it was not their shirt. It was Mom's shirt. She wore it to work. He said, "Lily, no! You can't mark on Mom's shirt! She will be mad!"
Lily did not listen. She kept marking on the shirt. She used more colors. She said, "No, Ben, it's fine. Mom will like it. It's a gift!"
Ben tried to stop her. He grabbed the shirt and pulled it. Lily pulled it back. They both tugged and twisted the shirt. They got dizzy and fell on the floor.
Mom came home and saw them. She saw the shirt. She was very mad. She said, "What did you do to my shirt? It's ruined!"
Lily and Ben looked at each other. They felt sorry. They said, "We're sorry, Mom. We wanted to make you a pretty shirt."
Mom sighed. She said, "I know you meant well, but you can't mark on things that are not yours. You have to ask first. And you have to use paper, not clothes. Do you understand?"
Lily and Ben nodded. They said, "We understand, Mom. We won't do it again."
Mom hugged them. She said, "I love you, but you have to be careful. Now, let's go and wash the shirt. Maybe we can save it."




Tommy was very enthusiastic about cleaning. He liked to help his mom and dad with the chores. He would sweep the floor, wipe the table, and put away his toys. He felt happy and proud when he saw how nice the house looked.
One day, Tommy wanted to help his mom make a pie. She told him he could wash the apples for her. Tommy was excited. He loved apples. They were red and sweet and crunchy. He took a big basket of apples and went to the sink. He turned on the water and started to clean the apples.
He rubbed each apple with his hands until it was shiny and wet. He put the clean apples in a bowl. He counted them as he did. One, two, three, four, five, six, seven, eight, nine, ten. He had ten clean apples. He smiled and called his mom.
"Mom, I cleaned the apples for you. Can I help you make the pie now?"
Mom came to the kitchen and saw the bowl of apples. She was very happy and proud of Tommy. She hugged him and said, "Thank you, Tommy. You did a great job. You are such a good helper. Yes, you can help me make the pie. Let's roll the dough and cut the apples together."
Tommy and his mom had fun making the pie. They put it in the oven and waited for it to bake. It smelled delicious. Tommy could not wait to taste it. He knew it would be the best pie ever. He was very enthusiastic about cleaning and cooking. He liked to help his mom and dad with the chores. He felt happy and proud when he saw how nice the house looked and how yummy the pie was.




Tom and Jen were friends who liked to play in the woods. One day, they found a big cave with a white door. They wanted to see what was inside, but they had a quarrel.
"I want to go first!" Tom said.
"No, I want to go first!" Jen said.
They pushed and pulled each other, but no one could open the door. They got angry and shouted.
"Go away, you are mean!" Tom said.
"Go away, you are silly!" Jen said.
They stopped being friends and went to different sides of the cave. They did not see the big bear that was sleeping inside. The bear heard the noise and woke up. He was hungry and angry. He saw Tom and Jen and roared.
"Who are you? This is my cave!" the bear said.
Tom and Jen were scared and tried to run away, but it was too late. The bear caught them and ate them. He closed the white door and went back to sleep. Tom and Jen were no more.




Sara and Ben were twins who liked to play together. One day, their mom gave them a big purple gift to share. She said, "This is a special gift for both of you. You have to yield and take turns with it, okay?"
Sara and Ben nodded and thanked their mom. They opened the gift and saw a shiny purple bike. They both wanted to ride it first. Sara said, "I want to go first, I am older by two minutes." Ben said, "No, I want to go first, I am bigger by two inches." They started to fight and pull the bike.
Their mom heard them and came back. She said, "Stop fighting, you two. You have to yield and take turns with the bike, or I will take it away." Sara and Ben said, "Sorry, mom." They decided to flip a coin to see who would go first. Sara won the coin toss and got to ride the bike first.
She put on her helmet and rode the bike around the yard. She felt happy and proud. She did not want to yield and let Ben have a turn. She said, "This is my bike, I won the coin toss. You can wait." Ben felt sad and angry. He said, "That is not fair, you have to yield and let me have a turn. Mom said so." Sara said, "No, I don't. Go away." She rode the bike faster and faster.
She did not see the big rock in her way. She hit the rock and fell off the bike. She hurt her knee and cried. The bike was broken too. Ben ran to help her. He said, "Are you okay, Sara?" Sara said, "No, I am not. I hurt my knee and the bike is broken. Mom will be mad at us." Ben said, "I am sorry, Sara. I wish you had yielded and let me have a turn. Maybe we could have avoided the rock." Sara said, "I am sorry too, Ben. I was selfish and greedy. I should have yielded and let you have a turn. Maybe we could have enjoyed the bike together."
Their mom came and saw what happened. She said, "Oh, no. What did you do, Sara and Ben? You broke the bike and hurt yourselves. You did not yield and take turns with the gift, did you?" Sara and Ben said, "No, mom. We did not. We are sorry, mom." Their mom said, "I am sorry too, Sara and Ben. You have to learn to yield and share with each other, or you will lose what you have and hurt yourselves and others. The bike was a gift, not a prize. You have to be grateful and generous, not selfish and greedy. Do you understand?" Sara and Ben said, "Yes, mom. We understand. We will try to do better next time."
The moral of the story is: You have to yield and share with others, or you will lose what you have and hurt yourselves and others.




Tom and Sue are friends. They like to play in the park. One day, they see a big dog. The dog is black and white. It has a red collar. The dog looks sad.
"Hello, dog," Tom says. "What is your name?"
The dog does not answer. It wags its tail. It licks Tom's hand.
"Can we pet you?" Sue asks. "You are so soft and nice."
The dog nods. It lets Sue and Tom pet it. It is happy.
But then, a man comes. The man is angry. He has a stick. He yells at the dog.
"Bad dog! Bad dog! You ran away from me! You are a poor dog! You have no life!"
The man hits the dog with the stick. The dog cries. It is hurt.
"Stop! Stop!" Tom and Sue shout. "Don't hurt the dog! He is our friend!"
The man does not listen. He hits the dog again. The dog tries to run away. But the man is faster. He grabs the dog by the collar.
"Come with me, you poor dog! You have no life! You have no home! You have no love!"
The man drags the dog away. The dog looks at Tom and Sue. It whimpers. It wants to stay with them.
"Help! Help!" Tom and Sue scream. "Someone help the dog! He needs a life! He needs a home! He needs love!"
But no one hears them. No one helps them. The man and the dog are gone.
Tom and Sue are sad. They cry. They hug each other.
"We have to hurry," Tom says. "We have to find the dog. We have to save him. We have to give him a life. We have to give him a home. We have to give him love."
Sue nods. She wipes her tears. She holds Tom's hand.
"Let's go," she says. "Let's hurry. Let's find the dog. He is our friend. We love him."
Tom and Sue run. They run after the man and the dog. They hope they can catch them. They hope they can help them. They hope they can make them happy.




Tom and Lily were playing hide and seek in the big house. Tom was the seeker and Lily was the hider. Lily ran to the living room and saw a big armchair. She thought it was a good place to hide. She crawled behind the armchair and waited for Tom to find her.
Tom looked in the kitchen, the bathroom, the bedroom, but he could not find Lily. He was getting tired of looking. He went to the living room and saw the armchair. He thought maybe Lily was hiding there. He walked to the armchair and peeked behind it.
"Boo!" Lily shouted and jumped out. She scared Tom and made him laugh.
"I found you!" Tom said. "You are a good hider, Lily."
"Thank you, Tom. You are a good seeker, too. But I think we are both tired now. Can we stop playing and rest on the armchair?" Lily asked.
"Okay, Lily. That sounds good. The armchair is very soft and cozy. Let's cuddle on the armchair and take a nap." Tom agreed.
They climbed on the armchair and snuggled together. They closed their eyes and fell asleep. They did not lose each other. They were happy.




Sara liked to gaze at the parrot in the pet shop. The parrot had many colors on its feathers. It was a beautiful bird. Sara wanted to have the parrot as a friend.
One day, Sara asked her mom if she could buy the parrot. Her mom said no. She said the parrot was too noisy and too messy. She said they had no space for a cage. Sara was sad. She begged her mom to change her mind. Her mom said no again.
Sara was angry. She decided to take the parrot anyway. She waited until the pet shop owner was busy. She opened the cage and grabbed the parrot. She ran out of the shop with the parrot in her arms.
But the parrot did not like Sara. The parrot bit Sara's hand hard. Sara screamed and dropped the parrot. The parrot flew away. Sara cried. Her hand was bleeding. The pet shop owner saw what Sara did. He was very mad. He called Sara's mom and the police. Sara was in big trouble. She wished she had listened to her mom. She lost the parrot and her mom's trust.




Lily was eager to wear her new dress. It was pink and had flowers on it. She wanted to show it to her friends at school. She put it on and looked at herself in the mirror. She felt happy and pretty.
She ran downstairs to eat her breakfast. Mommy gave her a bowl of cereal and a glass of milk. Lily ate quickly and drank her milk. She was ready to go to school. She grabbed her backpack and ran to the door.
But Mommy stopped her. "Lily, wait a minute. You can't wear your new dress today. It's too cold outside. You need to wear your coat and your hat and your gloves. And you need to bring your board. You can slide on the snow with it."
Lily felt sad and angry. She didn't want to wear her coat and her hat and her gloves. She wanted to wear her new dress. She didn't want to bring her board. She wanted to play with her friends. She said, "No, Mommy, no. I want to wear my dress. I don't want to slide on the snow. I want to go to school."
Mommy was firm. "Lily, you have to listen to me. It's very cold outside. You can get sick if you don't wear warm clothes. And you can have fun with your board. You can slide on the snow with your friends. You can wear your dress another day. Now, please, put on your coat and your hat and your gloves. And take your board. We have to go."
Lily didn't want to argue with Mommy. She knew Mommy loved her and wanted her to be safe and happy. But she still felt sad and angry. She put on her coat and her hat and her gloves. She took her board. She followed Mommy to the car. She hoped that maybe, just maybe, she could wear her new dress tomorrow.




Lily was a little girl who liked to play in the garden. She liked to look at the pretty flowers and the busy bees. One day, she saw a big jar of honey on the table. She wanted to taste the honey, because it looked sweet and yummy.
She tried to reach the jar, but it was too high for her. She looked around and saw a chair. She had an idea. She pushed the chair to the table and climbed on it. She was very careful not to fall. She stretched her arm and tried to lift the jar of honey.
But the jar was too heavy for her. She could not lift it. She pulled and pulled, but the jar did not move. She felt sad and frustrated. She started to cry.
Then, she heard a voice. It was her mom. She came to the garden and saw Lily on the chair. She asked her what was wrong. Lily pointed to the jar of honey and said, "I want honey, but I can't lift it. It's too heavy."
Her mom smiled and hugged her. She said, "Don't cry, Lily. I can help you. Honey is very heavy, but it is also very sticky. If you lift it, it might spill and make a mess. How about we share some honey on a slice of bread? That way, you can taste the honey and not waste it."
Lily nodded and smiled. She liked that idea. She got down from the chair and followed her mom to the kitchen. They made some honey bread and ate it together. It was delicious. Lily thanked her mom and gave her a kiss. She was happy. She learned that honey is heavy and sticky, but also sweet and yummy. And she learned that mom is always there to help her.




Lily and Ben love to play at the beach. They like to make castles with sand and shells. They also like to decorate their castles with flowers and stones.
One day, they find a big pink bucket near the water. They are very happy. They think it is a gift for them. They fill the bucket with sand and turn it over. They make a big pink tower.
They want to decorate the tower with shells and flowers. They look around and see many pretty things. They see a starfish, a feather, a leaf and a coin. They run to get them and put them on the tower.
But when they come back, they see a big wave. The wave is coming to the tower. They are scared. They shout, "No, no, no! Stop, wave, stop!"
But the wave does not stop. It hits the tower and washes it away. The sand, the shells, the flowers, the starfish, the feather, the leaf and the coin are gone. The bucket is gone too.
Lily and Ben are sad. They cry. They want their tower back. They want their bucket back.
But then they see something shiny in the water. It is the coin. The wave brought it back to them. They smile. They think it is a gift for them. They run to get it and put it in their pocket.
They say, "Thank you, wave, thank you!"
They hug each other. They are happy again. They decide to make a new castle with sand and shells. They also decide to decorate it with the coin. They think it will make it very special.




Sara and Ben are playing in the garden. They like to pretend they are chefs and make food with leaves, flowers and dirt. Sara is very creative. She makes a pizza with a big leaf as the base and puts some olives on top. Olives are small and round and black or green. Sara likes olives. Ben does not.
"Look, Ben, I made a pizza. Do you want some?" Sara says.
Ben kneels down to see the pizza. He does not like olives. He thinks they are yucky. He makes a face.
"No, thank you, Sara. I do not like olives. They are yucky. Can I have something else?" Ben says.
Sara is sad. She worked hard on her pizza. She thinks it is yummy. She does not want to waste it.
"Please, Ben, try a bite. Maybe you will like it. Olives are good for you. They are healthy." Sara says.
Ben does not want to hurt Sara's feelings. He is a good friend. He decides to try a bite. He picks up a small piece of the pizza and puts it in his mouth. He chews slowly. He is surprised. The pizza is not yucky. It is yummy. He likes olives.
"Mmm, Sara, this is yummy. You are a good chef. I like olives. Can I have some more?" Ben says.
Sara is happy. She smiles. She is glad Ben likes her pizza. She shares it with him. They eat the pizza together. They are good friends. They have fun.




Tim and Sam are friends. They like to play at the gym. The gym has many toys and games. They can run, jump, swing, and slide. They have fun at the gym.
One day, Tim and Sam see a new boy at the gym. His name is Ben. Ben has no toys and no games. He has only a ball. He kicks the ball by himself. He looks sad.
Tim and Sam want to play with Ben. They go to him and say, "Hi, Ben. Do you want to play with us? We have many toys and games. You can share with us."
Ben looks at Tim and Sam. He says, "No, thank you. I have my own toys and games. They are at home. They are better than yours. I don't need to share."
Tim and Sam are surprised. They think Ben is lying. They say, "Really? What toys and games do you have at home? Can you tell us?"
Ben thinks for a moment. He says, "I have a big car, a big train, a big robot, a big dinosaur, and a big castle. They are all mine. They are all shiny and new. They are all fun."
Tim and Sam are more surprised. They think Ben is lying more. They say, "Wow, that sounds amazing. Can we see them? Can we come to your home?"
Ben shakes his head. He says, "No, you can't. My home is far away. You can't find it. You can't come. You can't see. You can only play with your toys and games. I can only play with my ball."
Tim and Sam are sad. They think Ben is poor. They think he has no toys and games at home. They think he is lying to hide his sadness. They want to help him. They want to be his friends.
They say, "Ben, we are sorry. We don't believe you. We think you are lying. We think you are poor. We think you have no toys and games at home. We think you are sad. We want to help you. We want to be your friends. Please, don't lie to us. Please, play with us. Please, share with us. We have enough for all. We can have fun together."
Ben looks at Tim and Sam. He sees their kind eyes and their smiling faces. He feels their warm hearts and their gentle words. He feels ashamed of his lies. He feels sorry for his pride. He feels lonely for his ball. He feels happy for their offer. He says, "Tim, Sam, thank you. You are right. I am lying. I am poor. I have no toys and games at home. I am sad. I need your help. I need your friendship. Please, let me play with you. Please, let me share with you. I have only a ball, but I can give it to you. We can have fun together."
Tim and Sam are glad. They hug Ben. They say, "Ben, welcome. You are our friend. You don't need to lie to us. You don't need to be poor. You don't need to be sad. You have us. We have you. We have many toys and games. We have a ball. We have fun together."
They take Ben to the gym. They show him their toys and games. They play with his ball. They run, jump, swing, and slide. They have fun at the gym. They are friends.




Lila and Ben were playing in the backyard. They had a big box and some shiny paper. They wanted to make a pretend spaceship.
"Let's deliver some crystals to the moon," Lila said. She had a necklace with a blue crystal that sparkled in the sun.
"OK, but we have to be careful. There are fierce aliens on the moon," Ben said. He had a toy laser gun that made funny noises.
They climbed into the box and pretended to fly. They made whoosh and beep sounds. They saw the moon in the sky. It was round and white.
"Look, there's a landing spot," Lila said. She pointed to a patch of dirt. "Let's go and give the crystal to the moon people."
They got out of the box and walked slowly. They held hands. They saw something move behind a bush. It was green and hairy. It had big eyes and sharp teeth. It was an alien!
"Roar!" The alien jumped out and ran towards them. It wanted the crystal.
"Help!" Lila and Ben screamed. They dropped the crystal and ran back to the box. They closed the flap and locked it.
"Go away, you fierce alien!" Ben shouted. He waved his laser gun. "We don't want to play with you!"
The alien picked up the crystal and looked at it. It liked the shiny thing. It smiled and made a friendly noise. It wanted to play with Lila and Ben.
"Hello, I'm Zog. I'm not fierce. I'm lonely. Can I be your friend?" The alien said. It knocked on the box.
Lila and Ben heard the alien. They were scared, but also curious. They opened the flap and peeked out. They saw the alien holding the crystal. It looked sad.
"Hi, I'm Lila. This is Ben. We're sorry we ran away. We thought you were fierce," Lila said.
"I'm sorry I scared you. I just wanted to see the crystal. It's so pretty. Can I share it with you?" Zog said.
Lila and Ben nodded. They came out of the box and smiled. They gave Zog a hug. They played with the crystal and the laser gun. They had fun.
They became friends. They delivered the crystal to the moon people. They flew back to Earth. They had a great adventure.
